THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joseph Dickerson       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-002
Submitted December 15, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of 
  Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Meyers, Eleventh Circuit Solicitor's Office, 
  of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Joseph Dickerson was convicted 
  of criminal conspiracy and four counts of armed robbery.Â  Dickerson appeals 
  his conviction, arguing the trial court erred by denying Dickersonâ€™s motion 
  for mistrial, or alternatively, refusing to grant a new trial after a witness 
  offered testimony which improperly placed Dickersonâ€™s character in issue.Â  We 
  affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), 
  SCACR, and the following authorities: State v. Howard, 296 S.C. 481, 
  483, 374 S.E.2d 284, 285 (1988) (the decision to grant or deny a motion for 
  a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be 
  overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of 
  law); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 227, 522 S.E.2d 845, 851(Ct.App. 
  1999) (â€œ[a] mistrial should only be granted in cases of manifest necessity and 
  with the greatest caution for very plain and obvious reasons.â€); State v. 
  Council, 335 S.C. 1, 13, 515 S.E.2d 508, 514 (1999) (the moving party has 
  the burden to show not only error, but resulting prejudice);Â  State v. Kelsey, 
  331 S.C. 50, 70, 502 S.E.2d 63, 73 (1998) (â€œ[t]he granting of the motion for 
  a mistrial is an extreme measure which should be taken only where an incident 
  is so grievous that prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCAR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jerry Randall Simpson, Jr.       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-003
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 7, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, of Columbia; W. Townes Jones, IV, 
  Eighth Circuit Solicitor's Office, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Simpson was indicted for driving 
  under the influence (DUI), failing to stop for a law enforcement vehicle, and 
  possession of a sawed-off shotgun.Â  Simpson contends the trial court erred in 
  failing to suppress all evidence resulting from the unreasonable seizure of 
  himself and his automobile.Â  He asserts that the court erred as the stop was 
  unreasonable and the evidence was fruit of a poisonous tree. We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: State 
  v. Dorce, 320 S.C. 480, 483, 465 S.E.2d 772, 773 (Ct.App. 1995) (the admission 
  of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge whose ruling will 
  not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion); State v. Wilson, 
  345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (in criminal cases, this court sits 
  to review errors of law only, and we are bound by the trial court's factual 
  findings unless they are clearly erroneous); State v. Nelson, 336 S.C. 
  186, 192, 519 S.E.2d 786, 789 (1999) (an officer who lacks probable cause, but 
  whose observations lead him reasonably to suspect that a particular person has 
  committed, is committing, or is about to commit a crime, may detain that person 
  briefly in order to investigate the circumstances that provoke that suspicion); 
  State v. Woodruff, 344 S.C. 537, 546, 544 S.E.2d 290, 295 (Ct.App. 2001) 
  (if the officer's suspicions are confirmed or are further aroused, the stop 
  may be prolonged and the scope enlarged as required by the circumstances).Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCAR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Case No.: 1999-DR-07-119
Luella H. Bauer,       
Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard K. Bauer,       
Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  



  
    
      
        Case No.:Â  2000-DR-07-94
Richard K. Bauer,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Luella H. Bauer,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-004
Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  8, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Mary Kay Siren, Esquire; Lee S. Bowers, of Estill; for Appellant-Respondent.
John S. Nichols, of Columbia; William Randall Phipps, of Hilton 
  Head Island; for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action for 
  separate maintenance and support, the family court divided the marital property 
  equally and ruled Luella H. Bauer (â€œWifeâ€) was not entitled to alimony.Â  In 
  addition, the family court ordered the parties to have the marital home appraised 
  before Wife was to purchase Richard K. Bauerâ€™s (â€œHusbandâ€) interest or to immediately 
  list the home for sale.Â  For more than six months after the home was appraised,Â  
  Wife failed to list it for sale.Â  In a subsequent order, the family court awarded 
  Husband post-judgment interest for the time period from the date sixty days 
  after the appraisal until the date the house was listed for sale.Â  Wife appeals, 
  arguing the family court erred by failing to award her alimony and by not considering 
  certain facts that supported her claim for alimony.Â  Husband appeals, arguing 
  the family court should have awarded him post-judgment interest from the date 
  of the order, or the date of the appraisal, until the date the home was sold.Â  
  We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife were married on December 
  6, 1958.Â  The parties separated in January 1999 because Wife believed Husband 
  was having an affair.Â  An order for separate maintenance and support was issued 
  January 20, 2000.Â  The family court ordered the marital assets to be equally 
  divided between the parties.Â  Because Wife desired the marital home as part 
  of the equitable distribution, the family court gave Wife sixty days to purchase 
  Husbandâ€™s interest or to list the home for sale.Â  The family court declined 
  to award alimony to either party.Â  
 Both parties filed motions for reconsideration, 
  and an amended final order was issued on April 12, 2000.Â  In the amended order, 
  the family court stated â€œsince both parties are retired and the assets have 
  been divided equally, including the IBM defined benefit annuity, neither party 
  is entitled to alimony from the other.â€Â  The family court also required that 
  a new appraisal of the home be conducted before Wife purchased Husbandâ€™s interest.Â  
  After the parties obtained an appraisal, Wife was ordered to purchase Husbandâ€™s 
  interest or â€œimmediatelyâ€ list the home for sale. 
On May 30, 2000, the home was appraised 
  at $315,000.00.Â  On December 22, 2000, after failing to obtain financing or 
  to sell the marital home herself, Wife listed the home with a real estate agent.Â  
  During the next six months, the parties received two offers to purchase the 
  home.Â  The first offer of $325,000.00 was rejected.Â  Husband and Wife agreed 
  to accept the second offer of $340,000.00 and entered into a contract to sell 
  the home on June 25, 2001.Â Â  
Both parties appealed the amended order.Â  Because 
  several issues needed clarification, including post-judgment interest, the appeals 
  were stayed, and the matter was remanded for a hearing before the family court.Â  
  Husband later abandoned his appeal of the amended order.Â  
On remand, the family court held a hearing 
  and filed its final order on October 16, 2001.Â  In the order, the family court 
  ruled the IBM income would be divided evenly between the parties.Â  The family 
  court also ordered Wife to pay post-judgment interest on Husbandâ€™s share of 
  the marital home for the time period when she failed to list the home for sale 
  as required by the amended order.Â  Husband appealed the family courtâ€™s order 
  on remand.Â  Husbandâ€™s and Wifeâ€™s appeals were consolidated for review.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Â Â Â Â Â  Wifeâ€™s Appeal
Wife argues the family court erred by failing to 
  award her alimony.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe decision to grant or deny alimony rests within 
  the discretion of the family court . . . . [and] will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent abuse thereof.â€Â  Dearbury v. Dearbury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 
  S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).
In making an award of alimony, the family court 
  must consider and weigh the following factors: (1) â€œduration of the marriage;â€Â  
  (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) â€œeducational backgroundâ€ 
  of the parties; (4) â€œemployment history and earning potentialâ€ of the parties; 
  (5) â€œstandard of living established during the marriage;â€ (6) â€œcurrent and reasonably 
  anticipated earningsâ€ of the parties; (7) â€œcurrent and reasonably anticipated 
  expensesâ€ of the parties; (8) â€œmarital and nonmarital properties of the parties;â€ 
  (9) â€œcustody of the children;â€ (10) â€œmarital misconduct or fault;â€ (11) â€œtax 
  consequences;â€ (12) prior support obligations; and (13) â€œother factors the court 
  considers relevant.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(1)-(13) (Supp. 2002).Â  
â€œOur inquiry on appeal is not whether the family 
  court gave the same weight to particular factors as this court would have; rather, 
  our inquiry extends only to whether the family court abused its considerable 
  discretion in assigning weight to the applicable factors.â€ Allen v. Allen, 
  347 S.C. 177, 186, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001); see S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (stating that in making an award of alimony, the family court 
  must consider all relevant factors and â€œgive weight in such proportion as it 
  finds appropriateâ€ to these factors); see also Long v. Long, 247 
  S.C. 250, 252, 146 S.E.2d 873, 875 (1966) (â€œThe [decision to award] alimony 
  is [a] matter with[in] the discretion of the trial judge, to be exercised in 
  the light of the facts of each particular case, and will not be disturbed on 
  appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€). Â 
In deciding not to award alimony in the present 
  case, the family court considered the following factors outlined in section 
  20-3-130: (1) the parties had been married for forty years; (2) Wife was 65 
  years old; Husband was 67 years old; and both parties were in reasonably good 
  health; (3) Wife obtained her Masterâ€™s degree in psychology while Husband had 
  a Bachelorâ€™s degree in psychology; (4) Wife was predominantly a homemaker during 
  the course of the marriage while Husband was a retired IBM executive, and neither 
  had any future earning potential; (5) the parties maintained a moderate standard 
  of living during the marriage; (6) Wife had a monthly income of $1,318.03 and 
  Husband had an income of $1,998.03; (7) the current expenses of each party exceeded 
  current income, with Wife having a monthly deficit of $509.36 and Husband having 
  a monthly deficit of $424.97; (8) the parties owned a marital home located on 
  Hilton Head Island valued at $290,000.00, [1]  as well as various savings accounts, investment accounts, retirement 
  accounts, and insurance policies valued at approximately $300,000.00; (9) the 
  parties have five children, each of whom had reached the age of majority; and 
  (10) no marital misconduct by either party was substantiated. Â 
Because the family court reviewed the factors outlined in 
  section 20-3-130, we conclude the family court considered the appropriate factors 
  in deciding not to award alimony. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C).Â  
  Furthermore, based on our review of the record, we hold the family court did 
  not abuse its discretion. See Allen, 347 S.C. at 186, 554 S.E.2d 
  at 425.
In addition to arguing the family court erred by failing 
  to award her alimony, Wife also argues the family court did not consider certain 
  facts that supported her claim for alimony.Â  First, she contends the family 
  court failed to consider that she received less Social Security income than 
  Husband. We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In determining the overall earnings of Wife and Husband, 
  the family court considered each partyâ€™s monthly Social Security income and 
  monthly allotment from the IBM annuity.Â  Wife received a monthly Social Security 
  income of $554.00, and Husband received a monthly Social Security income of 
  $1,234.00.Â  Because the family court ordered Husbandâ€™s $1,528.05 monthly allotment 
  from the IBM annuity to be evenly divided between the parties, each received 
  $764.03 a month from the annuity.Â  Using these figures, the family court determined 
  Wife had a monthly income of $1,318.03, while Husband had an income of $1,998.03 
  per month. Thus, contrary to Wifeâ€™s argument, the family court considered the 
  difference in Social Security income in determining not to award alimony.Â  Furthermore, 
  we have reviewed the record in light of the fact that the family court may â€œgive 
  weight in such proportion as it finds appropriateâ€ to each of the factors outlined 
  in section 20-3-130. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C).Â  Based on our 
  review, we hold there was no abuse of discretion. 
Lastly, Wife argues the family court erred by failing to 
  consider she would be required to pay approximately $150.00 more per month to 
  maintain her health insurance coverage after a divorce.Â  We disagree.
With regards to the increase in the cost of Wifeâ€™s 
  health benefits upon divorce, Wife testified that after a divorce, her health 
  insurance premium would increase from $24.80 per month to $193.18 per month.Â  
  After listening to this testimony, the family court stated in its order, â€œthe 
  current expenses of both parties, as reflected in their financial declarations, 
  are reasonable and exceed the current income of both parties.â€Â  Therefore, Wife 
  cannot claim the family court failed to consider this factor, but instead can 
  only argue she disagrees with the weight given to this factor by the family 
  court.Â  Because the family court may â€œgive weight in such proportion as it finds 
  appropriateâ€ to each of the factors, we have reviewed the record for an abuse 
  of discretion and we hold the family court did not abuse its discretion. See 
  id.
II. Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s Appeal
Husband argues the family court erred 
  by limiting the award of post-judgment interest to the time period beginning 
  August 1, 2000, the date sixty days after the court-ordered appraisal was completed, 
  and ending December 22, 2000, the date that the home was listed for sale.Â  We 
  disagree.
In awards by the family court, statutory 
  post-judgment interest â€œapplies only to money awards entered pursuant to distribution 
  when the award is due as payable immediately or at fixed increments.â€ Casey 
  v. Casey, 311 S.C. 243, 246, 428 S.E.2d 714, 716 (1993).Â  Post-judgment 
  interest shall run until the judgment is paid or otherwise satisfied. See 
  Russo v. Sutton, 317 S.C. 441, 444, 454 S.E.2d 895, 896 (1995) (holding 
  post-judgment interest accrues on money judgments until the judgment amount 
  has been properly deposited with the court pursuant to Rule 67, SCRCP); Rule 
  67, SCRCP (stating a judgment debtor may deposit into court all or part of sum 
  due on judgment).Â  Thus, post-judgment interest was not a proper consideration. 

While the original order gave Wife sixty days to list the 
  home for sale, the amended order required Wife to obtain an appraisal of the 
  marital home before either purchasing Husbandâ€™s interest or â€œimmediatelyâ€ listing 
  the home for sale. In the event Wife listed the home for sale, the net proceeds 
  were to be divided equally between Husband and Wife. Â 
Although the home was appraised on May 30, 2000, Wife did 
  not list the home for sale until December 22, 2000, more than 200 days later.Â  
  On remand, the family court determined sixty days was a reasonable time for 
  Wife to have looked for financing to purchase Husbandâ€™s interest before listing 
  the home for sale.Â  The family court then couched its award as post-judgment 
  interest, awarded from August 1, 2000, the time by which Wife should have complied 
  with the order, to December 22, 2000, the time Wife actually complied by placing 
  the home for sale. 
Husband argues he was entitled to post-judgment 
  interest from April 12, 2000, the date of the amended order, or from May 31, 
  2000, the date of the appraisal, until June 2001, when he received his portion 
  of the proceeds from the home. We disagree.Â  
The proceeds were not payable to Husband until 
  June 2001 when the home was sold.Â  Therefore, post-judgment interest is inapplicable 
  for the time period prior to the sale.Â  See Casey, 311 S.C. at 
  246, 428 S.E.2d at 716.Â  
The family court ordered Wife to pay Husband interest 
  from August 1 to December 22, the time period when it found her to be unreasonable 
  in failing to list the home for sale.Â  In doing so, it is clear the family court 
  penalized Wife for failing to comply with the order in a timely fashion.Â  The 
  award was in the nature of compensatory relief, designed to make Husband whole 
  for the lost use of his equity in the home during Wifeâ€™s non-compliance. See 
  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1982) (â€œThe 
  power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts . . . . [and] [i]ts existence 
  is essential . . . to the enforcement of the . . . orders . . . of the courts.â€); 
  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop v. Cloyd, 350 S.C. 596, 606, 567 S.E.2d 514, 519 
  (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œCompensatory contempt is a money award for the plaintiff when 
  the defendant has injured the plaintiff by violating a previous court order.â€ 
  (quoting Curlee, 277 S.C. at 386, 287 S.E.2d at 919)).Â  Because the family 
  court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Husband interest for the time 
  period that it determined Wife failed to comply with the court order, we affirm 
  as modified. See Cloyd, 350 S.C. at 607, 567 S.E.2d at 519 (â€œâ€˜A 
  determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the 
  trial judge.â€™â€ (quoting State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 
  213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994)). 
Husband also argues the family court erred by finding 
  Wife made a reasonable effort to obtain financing on the home for the first 
  sixty days after the court-ordered appraisal.Â  We hold this argument is without 
  merit.Â  Indeed, the family court based its decision on its original order which 
  gave Wife this amount of time in which to decide whether to purchase Husbandâ€™s 
  interest or to sell the property.Â  Thus, we affirm as modified. See 
  id.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the family courtâ€™s 
  order denying alimony is affirmed.Â  The order granting Husband interest from 
  August 1, 2000, until December 22, 2000, is affirmed as modified.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
STILWELL, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   [1]  There was an associated golf membership valued 
    at $7,500.00.

Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. M. Weinberg, III, of Sumter, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Affirmed 
  pursuant to South Carolina Rules of Appellate Practice, Rule 220, and the following 
  authorities: As to Issue I: State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 
  529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000) (â€œIn reviewing a refusal to grant a directed verdict, 
  [an appellate court] must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
  State and determine whether there is any direct or substantial circumstantial 
  evidence that reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt or from which 
  his guilt may be logically deduced.â€); see State v. Morgan, 282 
  S.C. 409, 411, 319 S.E.2d 335, 336 (1984) (â€œUpon a motion for a directed verdict 
  . . . , the trial judge is concerned with the existence of evidence and not 
  its weight.â€).
As to Issue II:Â  State v. Hughey, 
  339 S.C. 439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000) (holding a circuit courtâ€™s failure 
  to give a requested jury charge must be erroneous and prejudicial to warrant 
  reversal); State v. Foust, 325 S.C. 12, 16, 479 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1996) 
  (holding a charge that is substantially correct and covers the law does not 
  require reversal); State v. Kerr, 330 S.C. 132, 144, 498 S.E.2d 212, 
  218 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding when reviewing a circuit courtâ€™s instruction to 
  the jury, the charge must be considered in its entirety). 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ethel C. Hunt,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard H. Warder, David D. Armstrong, and W. Dennis Chamberlain,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-006
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ethel C. Hunt, of Columbia, pro se.
James H. Cassidy, Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, Samuel W. Outten 
  and Langdon Cheves, III, all of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed 
  pursuant to South Carolina Rules of Appellate Practice, Rule 220, and the following 
  authorities: As to all issues: Rule 56(c), SCRCP (stating summary judgment 
  is appropriate where â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  . . . the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of lawâ€); Osborne 
  v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001) (â€œIn determining whether 
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€).Â  

As to the circuit courtâ€™s ruling in favor of 
  Richard Warder, David Armstrong, and Dennis Chamberlain on the statute of limitations 
  defense:Â  True v. Monteith, 327 S.C. 116, 119, 489 S.E.2d 615, 616 
  (1997) (â€œUnder the discovery rule, the statute of limitations begins to run 
  from the date the injured party either knows or should know, by the exercise 
  of reasonable diligence, that a cause of action exists for the wrongful conduct.â€); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2002) (stating all actions initiated under 
  section 15-3-530(5) must be commenced within three years after the person knew, 
  or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known, that a cause of 
  action existed).
 As to the circuit courtâ€™s ruling in 
  favor of Warder on the res judicata defense:Â  Town of Sullivanâ€™s 
  Island v. Felger, 318 S.C. 340, 344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995) 
  (â€œThe doctrine [of res judicata] requires three essential elements:Â  
  (1) the judgment must be final, valid and on the merits; (2) the parties in 
  the subsequent action must be identical to those in the first; and (3) the second 
  action must involve matter properly included in the first action.â€). 
As to the circuit courtâ€™s ruling in favor of 
  Armstrong and Chamberlain on the res judicata defense:Â  Id.; 
  Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 432, 480 S.E.2d 455, 458 (Ct. App. 1997) 
  (holding, in determining whether res judicata applies, the identity of 
  the parties in the first lawsuit also includes persons in privity with the named 
  parties); Richburg v. Baughman, 290 S.C. 431, 434, 351 S.E.2d 164, 166 
  (1986) (â€œâ€˜Privityâ€™ as used in the context of res judicata . . . does 
  not embrace relationships between persons or entities, but rather it deals with 
  a personâ€™s relationship to the subject matter of the litigation.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Douglas G. Davis and Brenda F. Davis,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Eddie R. Gravley,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Pickens County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-007
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Grady Jordan, of Easley, for Appellant.
James C. Alexander, of Pickens, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Eddie R. Gravley appeals the 
  trial courtâ€™s order extending a right-of-way across his property and granting 
  an easement by necessity.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Douglas G. Davis and Brenda F. Davis commenced 
  this action against Eddie R. Gravley requesting the court reform their deed 
  to establish a right-of-way across Gravleyâ€™s land or, in the alternative, grant 
  an easement by necessity.Â  
The Davises purchased a 15.8-acre tract 
  of land from Gravley in 1973.Â  This tract was part of a larger parcel owned 
  by Gravley along Highway 11 in Pickens County.Â  At the time of the transfer, 
  the tract was intentionally conveyed without means of access and did not connect 
  with a public road.Â  The deed stated that it was â€œ[u]nderstood that Grantee 
  herein will secure right-of-way from tract herein above described to highway 
  from property owners other than grantor.â€Â  To facilitate the sale, Gravley financed 
  part of the purchase price for the Davises. The parties do not dispute the terms 
  and conditions of this original conveyance.
In 1976, the parties entered into an agreement 
  whereby the Davises would pay off the balance of the purchase price early in 
  return for a right-of-way across Gravleyâ€™s property.Â  The Davises asserted Gravley 
  sought the payoff in order to build a shop on his land.Â  Gravley, on the other 
  hand, testified that the Davises were behind on the mortgage and he sought the 
  payoff in lieu of foreclosing.Â  
To finance the early termination of their 
  mortgage with Gravley, the Davises obtained a loan from First National Bank 
  of Pickens County by mortgaging the 15.8-acre tract.Â  Mr. Davis stated the loan 
  was conditioned on the tract having access to a public road.Â  Mr. Granthem, 
  the vice president of the bank at the time the loan was issued, supported this 
  testimony by stating that it was the bankâ€™s policy not to issue loans on property 
  unless there was clear access to a public road.Â  Gravley also acknowledged he 
  was aware the Davises would be unable to get the loan unless they had â€œa right-of-way 
  from Highway 11 all the way to [their] property.â€Â  
Pursuant to this agreement, on February 
  9, 1976, Gravley executed a deed conveying a right-of-way to the Davises.Â  The 
  deed states:

WHEREAS, on Jan. 29, 1973, the grantor herein did covey certain 
  property to the grantees herein by deed recorded in Book 12-P, page 263, Pickens 
  County Records, and WHEREAS, said deed stipulated that grantee therein would 
  secure a right of way from property owners other then grantor and WHEREAS, grantor 
  now has decided to convey an easement and right of way to the grantees.

The deed then sets forth a metes and bounds 
  description for the right-of-way to run from Highway 11 across Gravleyâ€™s land 
  up to another point on his land.Â  Based on this metes and bounds description, 
  however, the right-of-way falls short of connecting the highway to the Davisesâ€™ 
  property.Â  The Davises had the land surveyed in 1996 as an attempt at resolving 
  a dispute with Gravley about a driveway he was building.Â  According to the Davises, 
  it was at this time that they first learned the easement did not extend all 
  the way from Highway 11 to their property.Â  
The primary dispute among the parties 
  is whether the right-of-way was intended to extend all the way to the Davisesâ€™ 
  property.Â  The Davises assert that the parties intended it to connect their 
  property with Highway 11.Â  Gravley contends that the easement was never meant 
  to extend from Highway 11 to the Davisesâ€™ property.Â  Gravley testified that 
  the Davises wanted to use this partial right-of-way along with a right-of-way 
  they were planning to get from the abutting property owner, Mr. Davisâ€™ brother, 
  to access their land.Â  
The trial judge reformed the 1976 deed 
  based on a mutual mistake by the parties, thereby extending the right-of-way 
  from Highway 11 to the Davisesâ€™ property.Â  In the alternative, the court also 
  held that the Davises were entitled to an easement by necessity over Gravleyâ€™s 
  property.Â  Gravley argues these ruling were in error.
ISSUE
Did the trial court err by reforming the deed based on a 
  mutual mistake by the parties?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe determination of the existence 
  of an easement is a question of fact in a law action and subject to an any evidence 
  standard of review when tried by a judge without a jury.â€ Â Slear v. Hanna, 
  329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).Â  However, the question of the 
  extent of the easement is equitable.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 
  S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  â€œThus, this court may take its own 
  view of the evidence on the latter issue.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œ[T]his broad scope 
  of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial judge nor 
  does it relieve the appellant of the burden of convincing us that the trial 
  judge erred.â€Â  Calcutt v. Calcutt, 282 S.C. 565, 569, 320 S.E.2d 55, 
  57 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œThe trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was 
  in a better position to evaluate their credibility.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gravley first contends the trial court erred by reforming 
  the 1976 deed to extend the right-of-way to the Davisesâ€™ property.Â  We disagree.Â  

For equity to reform an instrument, â€œit 
  must be shown by clear and convincing evidence not simply that there was a mistake 
  by one of the parties, but that there was a mutual mistake.â€Â  Timms v. Timms, 
  290 S.C. 133, 137, 348 S.E.2d 386, 389 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  â€œA mutual mistake is 
  one whereby both parties intended a certain thing but because of a mistake in 
  drafting did not get what they intended.â€Â  Id.
Based on the testimony and evidence presented at trial, the 
  trial court found the parties intended for the right-of-way to extend completely 
  to the Davisesâ€™ property, and we agree.Â  It is undisputed that the original 
  deed conveying the 15.8-acre tract to the Davises did not provide for a right-of-way 
  across Gravleyâ€™s property.Â  In fact, the 1973 deed specifically stated that 
  it was understood â€œGrantee herein will secure right-of-way from tract herein 
  above described to highway from property owners other than grantor.â€Â  However, 
  in 1976, as part of an arrangement with the Davises to pay off the balance of 
  their mortgage, Gravley granted a right-of-way across his property.Â  The grant 
  provided in pertinent part that the â€œgrantor now has decided to convey an easement 
  and right of way to the grantees.â€Â  The purpose of the right-of-way, as stated 
  in the deed, was to provide â€œingress and egress over lands located in the State 
  of South Carolina.â€Â  As the trial court noted, the deed fails to indicate the 
  parties intended only a partial right-of-way.Â  Although Gravley testified the 
  right-of-way was never intended to completely traverse his property because 
  the Davises were going to use the neighboring property, the bulk of evidence 
  presented at trial belies this assertion.Â  For instance, both Mr. Davis and 
  Mr. Granthem testified the bank would not lend the money necessary to pay off 
  Gravley without a right-of-way connecting the parcel to a public road. Gravley 
  even acknowledged that he was aware of this requirement at the time of the conveyance.Â  
  Because there is more than enough evidence in the record to support the trial 
  courtâ€™s order, we agree the parties intended the right-of-way to extend completely 
  from the public road to the Davisesâ€™ property.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial 
  courtâ€™s order reforming the 1976 deed based on the doctrine of mutual mistake.
Furthermore, because we affirm the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision on the grounds of mutual mistake, we do not need to address Gravleyâ€™s 
  remaining issue.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 
  335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling appellate court need not 
  review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive). 
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, the 
  trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD and KITTREDGE, J.J., concur.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH 
    CAROLINA
  In The Court of 
    Appeals
  
  
    
      
        
  Ella R. Hall,       
  Appellant,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
  Anne Middleton Bell, Esquire,       
  Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Sumter 
    County
  L. Henry McKellar, 
    Circuit Court Judge
  
  Unpublished Opinion 
    No. 2004-UP-008
  Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed January 14, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
   Ella R. Hall, of Hartsville, Pro 
    Se.
  William C. Cleveland, 
    of Charleston, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Ella 
    R. Hall appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to defendant 
    Anne M. Bell.Â  We affirm. [1] 
  FACTS
  The chief complaint in this case 
    centers upon Hallâ€™s allegation that Bell committed legal malpractice in failing 
    to file an action against Hallâ€™s former employer Commander Nursing Home (â€œCommanderâ€).Â  
    Hall became the subject of an investigation by the South Carolina Board of 
    Nursing (the â€œBoardâ€) when Commander notified the Board that it suspected 
    Hall of diverting the drug Phenergan from the home. 
  Hall hired Bell to represent 
    her in August 1997.Â  Bell admits Hall spoke with her about filing an action 
    against Commander as well as defending Hall in front of the Board.Â  However, 
    Bell maintains she informed Hall they should concentrate on the case before 
    the Board first, as a determination by the Board that Hall did divert drugs 
    from the home would render a subsequent suit against Commander as moot.Â  At 
    no point did Bell agree to bring a suit against Commander on Hallâ€™s behalf.Â  
    Hall does not dispute Bell provided such advice.Â  
  Subsequently, Hall became dissatisfied 
    with Bellâ€™s representation.Â  After seeking other representation Hall terminated 
    Bellâ€™s employment in March 1998.Â  The Board subsequently dismissed the investigation 
    into the Phenergan incident at Commander in Hallâ€™s favor.Â  
  After the Boardâ€™s investigation 
    was dismissed, Hall filed suit against Bell alleging three causes of action 
    and requesting $5.5 million dollars in damages. 
    [2] Â  Hall later amended her complaint alleging two additional causes 
    of action.Â  
  Bell moved for summary judgment 
    arguing the scope of her employment involved only representing Hall in front 
    of the Board.Â  Additionally, Bell argued, even if a genuine issue of fact 
    existed, at the time of Hallâ€™s termination of her employment the statute of 
    limitations had not elapsed and Hall had retained other counsel.Â  
  The circuit court agreed and 
    granted summary judgment in favor of Bell.Â  Hall now appeals.
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  Summary judgment is proper when 
    there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is 
    entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; South Carolina 
    Prop. and Cas. Guar. Assoc. v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 
    883 (Ct.App. 2001).Â  To determine whether any material facts exist, the evidence 
    and all inferences, which can be reasonably drawn therefrom, must be viewed 
    in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.Â  Summary judgment 
    is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable 
    to clarify the application of the law.Â  Id. Â An appellate court reviews 
    the granting of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the trial 
    court.Â  Id.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Hall appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary 
    judgment and alleges thirteen instances of error in the trial judgeâ€™s ruling. 
    The allegations of error will be grouped into two categories:Â  1) whether 
    there are procedural irregularities in circuit courtâ€™s granting Bellâ€™s summary 
    judgment motion; and 2) the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment 
    as there were genuine issues of material fact.
    I.                 
  Procedural Irregularities 
     
  Hall asserts there were procedural irregularities 
    with regard to the circuit courtâ€™s granting of summary judgment.Â  We will 
    address each issue individually.
  Hall first argues error because 
    the judge failed to read the case file before conducting the hearing.Â  The 
    record reveals the circuit court was familiar with the case and was able to 
    conduct a hearing on the matter.Â  It is further apparent that any deficiency 
    in knowledge of the facts of the case Hall may have observed at the hearing 
    was cured by the circuit courtâ€™s well-reasoned order granting summary judgment.
  Second, Hall argues the circuit 
    court erred in granting Bellâ€™s motion for summary judgment, although Bell 
    had not yet filed her answer to the supplemental complaint.Â  Hall filed a 
    supplemental complaint alleging two additional causes of action on May 23, 
    2001.Â  Bell received the complaint on May 25, 2001.Â  The summary judgment 
    motion was heard on May 30, 2001.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment 
    on the following day.Â  Although nothing in the record reflects Hall had permission 
    to amend her complaint, it is apparent from the order granting summary judgment 
    the circuit court considered the supplemental complaint and viewed it as alleging 
    two additional causes of action arising out of the same set of facts as the 
    previous complaint. 
  Third, Hall again argues the 
    circuit court judge failed to read the filings before reaching its decision.Â  
    The circuit courtâ€™s order states it reviewed the initial complaint, the supplemental 
    complaint, and Bellâ€™s answer.Â  Hall does not specify what matters are present 
    in those filings that would warrant reversal of the circuit court.Â  Furthermore, 
    Hall may not rest on the allegations in her pleadings to create a cause of 
    action where those allegations are controverted by affidavits submitted by 
    Bell.Â  Yarborough v. Rogers, 306 S.C. 260, 261, 411 S.E.2d 424 (1991).
  Hallâ€™s fourth argument rests 
    upon the theory that the circuit court should not have viewed the supplemental 
    complaint as amendments to the complaint.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order states:Â  
    â€œAlthough the newly filed Complaint does not purport to amend the original 
    complaint, the Court will liberally view the pleading as an amendment that 
    adds two causes of action to the original complaint.â€Â  By considering the 
    causes of actions from the original and supplemental complaints the circuit 
    court benefited Hall by searching the complaints to find a basis on which 
    to support her suit.Â  The circuit court did not err in considering both the 
    original and supplemental complaint.
  Hallâ€™s fifth argument is that 
    Bell made numerous false and ambiguous statements in her submissions to the 
    court.Â  Hall further alleges that Bell concealed evidence.Â  Even if we accept 
    Hallâ€™s interpretations of Bellâ€™s submissions, it does not undermine the basis 
    of the circuit courtâ€™s order on two essential facts: 1) that Bell did not 
    agree to sue Commander on Hallâ€™s behalf; and 2) Hall retained other counsel 
    prior to the running of any statute of limitations on any viable claim.Â  
  Absent Hallâ€™s ability to show 
    that Bell agreed to sue Commander but failed to do so before the statute of 
    limitations expired she cannot maintain her action against Bell.Â  We find 
    no procedural irregularity on the circuit courtâ€™s behalf.
    II.              
  Genuine Issues of Material Fact 
     
  Hall first alleges there were 
    material issues of fact whether Bellâ€™s scope of representation was limited 
    to representation before the Board.Â  We disagree.
  It is clear from the record the 
    circuit court was correct in concluding no issue of material fact existed 
    over whether the scope of representation included Hallâ€™s suit against Commander.Â  
    First, at the outset of Bellâ€™s representation she had Hall prepare a summary 
    of facts of her case.Â  Although the summary does contain a reference to [j1]  Hallâ€™s desire to sue Commander, there is nothing 
    in the record to deduce that Bell agreed to represent Hall in the matter.Â  
  
  Second, the record demonstrates 
    that Bell only agreed to represent Hall during the Boardâ€™s investigation.Â  
    Bell asserts, and is uncontradicted by the record, she informed Hall that 
    suing Commander before obtaining a favorable ruling before the Board was not 
    effective, as a negative ruling by the Board would render any subsequent suit 
    moot.Â  Such statements make clear that Bellâ€™s representation extended only 
    to the Board investigation, at least until the conclusion of the case before 
    the Board.
  Third, Hallâ€™s own affidavit fails 
    to reveal testimony that Bellâ€™s scope of representation extended beyond the 
    Board.Â  Additionally, Hallâ€™s own letter to Bell terminating her services states 
    as one reason for her action Bellâ€™s â€œlack of encouragement/support [for her] 
    desire to file suit against Commander.â€
  Next, Hall asserts the Boardâ€™s 
    dismissal of Hallâ€™s case is clear evidence that Bellâ€™s â€œâ€˜Board of Nursing 
    caseâ€™ was fictitious, misleading, unfounded, and meritless ... [such that] 
    Hallâ€™s time and money were spent in Bellâ€™s pursuit of a case not in existence, 
    while Hallâ€™s lawsuit did not receive its proper attention.â€Â  It is clear from 
    the record that the case before the Board regarding the misappropriation of 
    the Phenergan existed.Â  Finally, the Boardâ€™s investigation against Hall ended 
    favorably for Hall.
  Fourth, Hall asserts Bell was incompetent because 
    she allowed the statute of limitations to expire before filing a suit against 
    Commander.Â  Hall retained counsel to represent her before the statute of limitations 
    expired with the only possible exception being applicable to a claim of racial 
    discrimination.Â  Hall had 300 days to file a claim with the EEOC to allege 
    racial discrimination in employment.Â  See Tinsley v. First Union 
    Natâ€™l Bank, 155 F.3d 435, 440 (4th Cir. 1998).Â  Accepting Hallâ€™s 
    version of events, the statute of limitations began on July 30, 1997.Â  Bell 
    was terminated by Hall and replaced by new counsel on March 12, 1998.Â  Therefore 
    225 days elapsed; the statute of limitations had not expired by the time Hall 
    retained new counsel.Â  Although South Carolina courts have not addressed this 
    issue, other jurisdictions have held an â€œattorney cannot be held liable for 
    failing to file an action prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations 
    if he ceased to represent the client and was replaced by other counsel before 
    the statute ran of the clientâ€™s action.â€Â  Knight v. Myers, 748 P.2d 
    896, 902 (Kan. 1998); see also Steketee v. Lintz, 694 
    P.2d 1153, 1159 (Cal. 1985); Harvey v. MacKay, 440 N.E.2d 1022, 1026 
    (Ill. 1982).Â  Accordingly, Bell is not liable for failing to file an action 
    where she was replaced by another attorney before the statute of limitations 
    expired.Â  
  Finally, Hall asserts the court 
    erred in granting summary judgment, as there were material issues of fact 
    whether Bell violated the statute of fraud provisions.Â  As this issue was 
    neither raised to nor ruled upon by the trial court it is not preserved for 
    our review.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs. v. Father 
    and Mother, 294 S.C. 518, 524, 366 S.E.2d 40, 43 fn. 22 (Ct.App. 1988) 
    (issue which was not raised below cannot be considered on appeal).Â  
  Even if this issue was preserved, 
    Hallâ€™s argument is meritless.Â  The failure to follow the statute of frauds 
    does not create a cause of action in tort.Â  Instead, it provides that for 
    certain types of agreements to be enforceable under contract law they must 
    be in writing.Â  See, e.g., Young v. Indep. Pub. Co., 
    273 S.C. 107, 110, 254 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1979).
  CONCLUSION
  The scope of Bellâ€™s legal representation was limited to the Boardâ€™s 
    investigation.Â  Although Hall expressed interest in suing Commander, no evidence 
    was presented proving Bell agreed to bring said suit.Â  Additionally, Bell 
    did not suffer legal harm as she retained alternate counsel within the statute 
    of limitations. Therefore the trial court did not err in granting summary 
    judgment.Â  
  AFFIRMED.
  GOOLSBY, HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


 
   [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the Court 
    in resolving any issue on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215 SCACR.

 
   [2]  Hall is also suing two lawyers in Sumter County because they 
    would not file a civil suit on her behalf.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Margie
Lane,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Donald
Lane,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Clarendon County
R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-009
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kristi F. Curtis, of Sumter, for Appellant.
Lori D. Hall, of West Columbia 
  and Cyril B. Rush Jr. of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  The family court granted 
  Margie Lane (â€œWifeâ€) and Donald Lane (â€œHusbandâ€) a divorce and apportioned the 
  marital property.Â  The apportionment allocated thirty-five percent of the marital 
  property to Wife and sixty-five percent to Husband, including the partiesâ€™ marital 
  residence.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Wife commenced an action for divorce by filing a summons 
  and complaint on March 20, 2000.Â  The complaint prayed for a divorce on grounds 
  of adultery, an order requiring Husband to maintain health insurance on Wife, 
  apportionment of the marital property, and possession of the marital home.Â  
  Husband answered and counterclaimed, also seeking a divorce on grounds of adultery.Â  
  The family court issued a temporary order, based partially on an agreement between 
  the parties, on August 8, 2000.
The parties were married in 1989.Â  Husband was employed as 
  a sergeant with the South Carolina Highway Patrol, while Wife worked part-time 
  for her brotherâ€™s cabinet making company.Â  At this point, the parties resided 
  with Wifeâ€™s mother in Chesterfield County.Â  Upon Husband receiving a promotion, 
  the parties relocated to York, South Carolina.Â  After the relocation to York, 
  Wife began working for the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (SCDMV). 
  Â She stayed at this position until 1995, when Husband received a second promotion 
  to lieutenant colonel, which required relocation to Columbia.Â  From 1995 until 
  the end of the marriage, Wife has been unemployed.Â  
The parties stipulated that the value of the marital estate 
  at the time of the hearing was $165,509.40.Â  Of particular importance, the marital 
  estate included two pieces of real property:Â  a five-acre tract of land located 
  in York County and a lakefront property used as the marital residence, located 
  in Summerton, South Carolina.Â  Wife used non-marital funds to purchase both 
  pieces of property.Â  Around 1990, Wife used non-marital funds to put a down 
  payment on a mobile home that became the marital residence on the lakefront 
  property.Â  It appears Wife made the mortgage payments on the mobile home until 
  1995, when she left her job at the SCDMV.Â  Husband made the payments from 1995 
  until 1999, when the mortgage was paid in full.
Both parties contributed to the lakefront property by making 
  several improvements.Â  Husband purchased an outdoor storage building, helped 
  build porches on the house and a shed on the property, and contributed to the 
  purchase price of a dock.Â  In addition to purchasing the property and making 
  a down payment on the mobile home, Wife contributed half the price of the dock, 
  installed a septic tank system and arranged for both electricity and water services.Â  

Although the lakefront property was initially used only on 
  weekends and special occasions, upon Husbandâ€™s relocation to Columbia in 1995, 
  the property became Wifeâ€™s primary residence.Â  Wife resided there until June 
  of 2000 when the parties separated.Â  During the interim, Husband resided in 
  an apartment in Columbia and would make the trip to the lakefront property on 
  the weekends.Â  Husband has been living on the lakefront property since the separation 
  and has lived there continuously since that time.
In the divorce decree, dated September 25, 2001, the family 
  court granted the parties a divorce on the ground of one-year continuous separation. [2] Â  The court also held that in 
  terms of financial contributions, Husband contributed eighty-two percent to 
  the marital estate and Wife contributed eighteen percent.Â  Accordingly, the 
  decree awarded sixty-five percent of the estate to Husband and thirty-five percent 
  to Wife.Â  The marital residence (the lakefront property) was included in Husbandâ€™s 
  portion of the estate.Â  The court further denied Wifeâ€™s request for an order 
  requiring Husband to maintain health insurance on her and awarded her partial 
  attorneyâ€™s fees of $2500.00.Â  It is from these rulings that Wife appeals.
ISSUES

  I.      Did the family court err in determining the percentage of marital property to 
  be apportioned among the parties?
  II.      Did the family court err in awarding the lakefront property to Husband?
  III.     Did the family court err in refusing to require Husband to continue health insurance 
  coverage on Wife?
  IV.    Did the family court err in giving Wife only a partial award of attorneyâ€™s fees?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has the authority 
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  
  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard 
  the factual findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 
  S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither are we required to ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better 
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their 
  testimony.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                 
Equitable Distribution 
   
Wife first contends the family court erred in apportioning 
  the marital property.Â  Specifically, she argues the family court judge did not 
  give enough consideration to her early contributions to the marriage, the current 
  condition of her health, and her lack of any substantial savings or retirement.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The apportionment of marital property is within 
  the discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Morris v. Morris, 295 S.C. 
  37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  South Carolina Code Ann. section 20-7-472 
  (Supp. 2002) provides the family court must consider fifteen factors and give 
  each weight as it determines.Â  On review, this court looks to the fairness of 
  the overall apportionment, and if the end result is equitable, the fact that 
  this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court 
  is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 
  107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988); Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 
  859 (Ct. App. 1996) (the reviewing court will affirm the family court judgeâ€™s 
  apportionment of marital property if it can be determined that the judge addressed 
  the relevant factors under section 20-7-472 with sufficiency for the reviewing 
  court to conclude the judge was cognizant of statutory factors).
In this case, the overall distribution was sixty-five percent 
  of the estate to Husband and thirty-five percent to Wife.Â  We find, given the 
  statutory factors, that this distribution is fair and equitable.Â  Given the 
  length of the marriage, the value of the marital property, and the incomes of 
  both parties, we find that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in its 
  distribution of the marital property.Â  In identifying, valuating, and apportioning 
  the property, the family court relied upon the testimony and discovery obtained 
  from both parties.Â  After examination of both the partiesâ€™ testimony and the 
  fifteen statutory factors listed in S.C. Code Ann. section 20-7-472, it is clear 
  that the family court divided the marital property in a fair manner.
II.Â  Lake-Front Property
Wife next maintains the family court erred by awarding 
  the lakefront property to Husband.Â  We disagree.Â  
Although Wife purchased the lakefront property 
  with non-marital funds, the parties stipulated it was marital property and agreed 
  that whichever party received it, the other party would be awarded the five-acre 
  parcel of land in York County.Â  Accordingly, the award of the property was governed 
  by the standards for equitable distribution.Â  Because there is evidence in the 
  record supporting the family courtâ€™s decision, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  

III.Â  Health Insurance
Wife argues the family court erred in allowing 
  Husband to drop her from his health insurance.Â  We disagree. 
Both parties agreed at trial to waive any right 
  either may have to alimony.Â  Because of this, the family court denied Wifeâ€™s 
  request, but ordered Husband to execute whatever documentation might be necessary 
  to allow Wife to convert her coverage to COBRA.
In its order disposing of Wifeâ€™s motion to alter 
  or amend the divorce decree, the family court denied Wifeâ€™s request.Â  The court 
  correctly noted that to require Husband to maintain health insurance, even at 
  Wifeâ€™s expense, â€œwould become an ongoing obligation as a form of spousal support.â€Â  
  Because it is undisputed the parties voluntarily waived alimony, and thus support, 
  we find no error.
IV.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wifeâ€™s final argument is that the family court 
  erred in only granting her a partial award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
A court must consider six factors in determining 
  whether to grant attorneyâ€™s fees: â€œ(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of 
  the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing 
  of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; 
  [and] (6) customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991) (citing Donahue v. Donahue, 
  299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989)).Â  Additionally, â€œan award of attorneysâ€™ 
  fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by 
  the trial court.â€Â  Donahue, 299 S.C. at 365, 384 S.E.2d at 748.
From a review of the divorce decree, it is clear 
  the family court fairly and equitably considered the necessary factors.Â  The 
  court found that the fees and expenses incurred by the respective attorneys 
  were reasonable, and that Husband was in a better position to pay the fees.Â  
  In awarding Wife fees, the court considered the fact that Wife abandoned her 
  request for alimony on the day of the trial.Â  We conclude the family court properly 
  considered the necessary factors.Â  We find no error in its award of partial 
  fees to Wife.
According, based on the foregoing, the family courtâ€™s 
  rulings are 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., concurs.
CONNOR, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
CONNOR, J. (dissenting): Although 
  I agree with the majorityâ€™s decision regarding the lakefront property, health 
  insurance, and attorneyâ€™s fees, I respectfully disagree with its decision to 
  affirm the family courtâ€™s determination of each partyâ€™s percentage of the marital 
  estate.Â  In my opinion, Husband and Wife should each receive fifty percent of 
  the marital estate.Â  Applying the requisite factors outlined in section 20-7-472 
  [3]  to the evidence presented at trial, I believe the family court erred 
  in awarding Wife only thirty-five percent of the marital estate.
The parties were married for almost eleven 
  years.Â  Even though the parties were divorced on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous 
  separation, there is evidence in the record, by way of Husbandâ€™s admission and 
  Wifeâ€™s testimony, that Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct precipitated the partiesâ€™ 
  separation.Â  Wife also significantly contributed to the marital estate.Â  Specifically, 
  Wife purchased, using her own non-marital funds, a five-acre tract of land in 
  York and a lakefront lot in Summerton, South Carolina.Â  She also used non-marital 
  funds as a down payment to purchase a mobile home for the lake property.Â  She 
  continued to make these payments until 1995 when she stopped working.Â  Additionally, 
  she paid for the installation and set up of the mobile home using her non-marital 
  funds.Â  Wifeâ€™s current health condition weighs in favor of her need for a greater 
  portion of the marital estate.Â  Because Wife suffers from severe fibromyalgia, 
  she is unable to maintain full-time employment.Â Â  In addition to Wifeâ€™s limited 
  future earnings, she also has no vested retirement and has minimal savings.Â  
  Although Wife did not earn as much income as Husband during the marriage, this 
  factor alone is not sufficient to supportâ€™s the family courtâ€™s apportionment 
  of the marital estate.Â  Based on the foregoing, I would reverse the family courtâ€™s 
  decision and award each party fifty percent of the marital estate.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The parties agreed to dismiss their requests for 
    divorce on grounds of adultery.

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code of Laws enumerates 
    fifteen factors applicable to a determination of equitable distribution.Â  
    These factors are as follows:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) marital misconduct 
    or fault and its effect on the break-up of the marriage; (3) the value of 
    the marital property and the contribution of each spouse to the acquisition 
    or appreciation in value of the marital property, including the contribution 
    of the spouse as homemaker; (4) the income and earning potential of each spouse 
    and opportunity for future acquisition of assets; (5) the health, both physical 
    and emotional, of each spouse; (6) need of either spouse for additional training 
    or education; (7) the nonmarital property of each spouse; (8) the existence 
    or nonexistence of vested retirement benefits for each spouse; (9) whether 
    alimony has been awarded; (10) desirability of awarding the family home; (11) 
    the tax consequence to each spouse as a result of the apportionment; (12) 
    the existence and extent of any support obligations of either party; (13) 
    liens and encumbrances on marital and separate property and other existing 
    debts; (14) child custody arrangements and obligations; and (15) any other 
    relevant factors as the trial court shall expressly enumerate in its order.Â Â  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2002).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Gary Gene Melton,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Deborah J. Melton,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Rolly W. Jacobs, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-010
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Melody Lynn James, of Camden, for Appellant.
Douglas J. Robinson, of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gary Gene Melton brought this 
  action against his former wife, Deborah J. Melton, seeking a termination or 
  reduction in alimony based on his substantial change of circumstances.Â  The 
  family court refused to modify Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were divorced in
2001, after thirty-one years of marriage. At the time of the divorce, Husband
had retired from the military and was employed as a bombing range manager for
the Dare County Air Force Bombing Range.  Between his retirement benefits
and his salary as a bombing range manager, Husband's monthly income was
$5,361.  Wife, on the other hand, had a monthly income of approximately
$227, which she earned from rents and from caring for her grandchildren, her
brother, and her father. [1]    The parties agreed Wife was entitled to
half of Husband's retirement benefits, and the family court awarded Wife an
additional $1,000 in alimony per month.

Approximately four months after the divorce, Husband was terminated from his job
at the bombing range.  The month following the loss of his employment,
Husband filed an action with the family court to terminate or reduce his alimony
obligation.  By way of counterclaim, Wife sought an order from the family
court that required Husband to (1) pay his monthly alimony obligation to the
court, (2) submit to a medical exam for life insurance purposes, and (3) pay her
attorney's fees and court costs. A pendente lite hearing was held in November of
2001, and at that time, the family court denied Husband's request for relief
   Two weeks after Husband filed his 
    complaint, Wife filed a rule to show cause, alleging Husband was in contempt 
    of the divorce decree for failing to pay alimony in a timely fashion.Â  Judge 
    Brooks P. Goldsmith continued the rule to show cause and ordered that it be 
    heard at the same time as the hearing on the merits for Husbandâ€™s action to 
    reduce or terminate alimony.
  In February of 2002, six months after 
    being terminated from the bombing range, Husband acquired a job at Miller 
    Trophy Room Preservation making ten dollars an hour.Â  Husband also earned 
    money from renting out a house and large tract of land he owned. 
In March of 2003, a hearing on the
merits was held.   At the hearing, Husband testified that he
received  $2,239 per month from his salary at Miller Trophy, $884 per month
in retirement benefits, and $440 per month in rental income.  Thus, his
total monthly income was $3,563.  On Husband's financial declaration, he
listed $3,767 worth of monthly expenses, which included his monthly alimony
obligation of $1,000.  

The family court found that although the loss of Husband's job was "an
important change," he was not entitled to a reduction in alimony.  The
court explained that Husband had not only replaced a great deal of his lost
income, but also that Husband's expenses had decreased significantly since
alimony had originally been set.  Specifically, the court noted that
Husband no longer paid $125 a month to rent out a mobile home lot; he no longer
paid $1,061.31 a month for his half of the mortgage on and upkeep for the
marital home; he no longer paid $238 a month toward his pension; and he no longer paid $177 a month for life 
    insurance.Â  Pursuant to its determination not to reduce Husbandâ€™s alimony, 
    the family court awarded Wife $4,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, the court 
    declined to hold Husband in contempt for his failure to make timely alimony 
    payments, noting the late payments occurred after Husband initially lost his 
    job and finding Husbandâ€™s failure to pay on time was not willful. Â 
Husband appeals, arguing the family
court erred by not reducing or terminating his alimony and by awarding Wife
attorney's fees. 
    STANDARD OF REVIEW
    The family court has the authority to alter 
      alimony payments upon a proper showing of a change of condition.Â  S.C. Code 
      Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985).Â  The modification of alimony is within the sound 
      discretion of the family court and will not be overturned absent an abuse 
      of that discretion.Â  Riggs v. Riggs, 353 S.C. 230, 236, 578 S.E.2d 
      3, 6 (2003). 
    LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Reduction or Termination of Alimony
Husband argues the family courtâ€™s failure 
  to reduce or terminate his alimony was an abuse of discretion for three reasons.Â  
  First, Husband claims the evidence in the record does not support the courtâ€™s 
  finding that his financial condition had not substantially or materially changed.Â  
  Second, Husband argues the family court abused its discretion by focusing only 
  on his circumstances rather than the circumstances of both parties.Â  Third, 
  Husband alleges the family court erred by considering â€œthe Traxler Alimony guidelinesâ€ 
  when making its decision.Â  We disagree with all of these arguments.
In regard to his financial condition, Husband 
  alleges his expenses have increased since the divorce, pointing to the $3,767 
  worth of expenses he has listed on his current financial declaration as compared 
  to the $3,484 in monthly expenses he had when alimony was originally set.Â  However, 
  included in Husbandâ€™s current financial declaration is his $1,000 alimony obligation.Â  
  Because the family court was asked to reconsider Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation, 
  the amount he currently pays in alimony should not be factored in as an expense.Â Â  
  After subtracting the $1,000 from the $3,767 in monthly expenses, Husbandâ€™s 
  monthly expenses are $717 less than they had been when alimony was originally 
  set.Â  Furthermore, the deductions from Husbandâ€™s gross pay are less now than 
  they were at the time of the partiesâ€™ divorce because he no longer pays $373 
  per month toward his pension plan. [2] Â  Thus, Husbandâ€™s expenses and deductions have 
  been reduced by nearly $1,100 since the partiesâ€™ divorce. 
Pursuant to the original divorce decree, Husband 
  was required to pay Wife $1,000 in alimony in addition to his agreement to pay 
  her half of his retirement benefits, which at the time amounted to $850. After 
  paying these sums to Wife, Husband was left with a gross monthly income of $3,511. 
  [3] Â  From this monthly income, $373 was deducted to fund his pension. His 
  monthly income therefore was $3,138 before taxes, and his monthly expenses were 
  $3,484, [4]  leaving him with a $346 deficit each month.Â  
  Now that Husband has a lower paying job, his monthly income isÂ  $3,563, [5]  and his expenses, including alimony, 
  are $3,794. [6] Â  Thus, his deficit is only $231 
  per month.Â  Based on these numbers, and despite the fact that Husbandâ€™s expenses 
  exceed his income, we agree with the family courtâ€™s finding that there has been 
  no material change to Husbandâ€™s financial circumstances.Â Â Â  Eubank v. Eubank, 
  347 S.C. 367, 372, 555 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating that, in order 
  to justify modification or termination of an alimony award, the changes in circumstances 
  must be substantial or material).Â  
Husband also argues the family court erred by 
  considering only his circumstances and not the circumstances of both parties.Â  
  We note initially that in Husbandâ€™s pleadings, the only change in circumstance 
  he specifically listed was his loss of income.Â  Moreover, the family court did 
  consider the Wifeâ€™s circumstances and found her â€œincome and ability to earn 
  income [had] not changed.â€Â  The evidence in the record supports this finding, 
  and we therefore find no error.Â  
Husband also urges us to reverse the family court 
  because it considered â€œthe Traxler alimony guidelines.â€Â  Husband asserts this 
  was error because â€œthe guidelines are not approved for use for the family court 
  . . . and results are not subject to cross-examination and confrontation by 
  the parties.â€Â  Even assuming, without deciding, that the family courtâ€™s consideration 
  of the guidelines was error, Husband fails to demonstrate how the use of these 
  guidelines prejudiced him.Â  See Blakely v. Blakely, 249 S.C. 623, 
  625, 155 S.E.2d 857, 858 (1967) (stating that an alimony order will not be reversed 
  unless the alleged error is material and prejudicial to the substantial rights 
  of the complaining party). As shown above, Husbandâ€™s income and expenses had 
  not materially or substantially changed.Â  Therefore, regardless of whether the 
  Traxler guidelines were considered, Husband was not entitled to a reduction 
  or termination of his alimony obligation. 
  II.         Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband next argues that the family courtâ€™s award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees should be reversed because of the adverse impact they have 
  on his finances. [7] Â  We find no error in the family 
  courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees. 
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within 
  the family courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 520, 586 
  S.E.2d 136, 141Â  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The factors to consider when awarding attorneyâ€™s 
  fees are (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, (2) the beneficial 
  results obtained by the attorney, (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, 
  and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M 
  v. T.A.M, 307 S.C. 471, 476-477, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In this case, 
  the family court specifically found that Husband had â€œsufficient income as well 
  as a great deal of assets out of which he can pay fees, while [Wife] generates 
  little income and has comparatively modest assets.â€Â  
The evidence in the record demonstrates that Husband 
  generates more income than Wife each month.Â  Furthermore, according to their 
  financial declarations, Husband has nearly $190,000 worth of assets, while Wife 
  has only $35,000 worth of assets. Â Thus, we find no error in the family 
  courtâ€™s decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.
Husband also argues that he should not have to pay 
  for the 2.7 hours Wifeâ€™s attorney spent working on the contempt action.Â  We 
  find the family court did not award Wife attorneyâ€™s fees for these hours.Â  
Wife requested that her attorney be reimbursed 
  for the 30.8 hours he spent on her entire case, including the contempt action.Â  
  At her attorneyâ€™s rate of $150 per hour, Wifeâ€™s total fees were $4,620.Â  The 
  family court, however, only awarded Wife $4,000 in attorneys fees.Â  Thus, Husband 
  was not required to pay for approximately four hours worth of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  fees, which presumably included the 2.7 hours Wifeâ€™s attorney spent on the contempt 
  action.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We find Husband was not entitled 
  to an alimony reduction or termination because he failed to show a material 
  or substantial change in his financial circumstances.Â  We further find the family 
  courtâ€™s award of $4,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife was not an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  In the partiesâ€™ divorce order, the family court noted that â€œ[Wife] 
    dropped out of high school in the 10th grade, marrying [Husband] 
    when she was 17 years old.Â  During the next 14 years, she and the children 
    followed [Husband] from military base to military base . . . .Â  These moves 
    were not conducive either to building up job skills or retirement funds.â€Â  
    However, the court did impute to Wife a monthly income of $922, finding she 
    was capable of working forty hours a week for minimum wage.Â  

 
   
    [2]  In its order, the family court found Husband no longer paid $238 
    per month toward his pension.Â  However, the financial declaration Husband 
    submitted at the time of the partiesâ€™ divorce lists a $373.45 deduction for 
    Husbandâ€™s â€œretirement or pension plan.â€

 
   
     
    [3]    Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income had been $5,361 at the time of the 
    divorce.Â  Taking away the $1,000 in alimony and the $850 in retirement benefits, 
    his gross monthly income was $3,511.

 
   
    [4]  Or, if we were to consider alimony as an expense like Husband does 
    in his current financial declaration, Husbandâ€™s income immediately after the 
    divorce decree was $4,138 a month and his expenses were $4,484, still leaving 
    a $346 deficit.

 
   [5]  Husband makes $2,239 per month at Miller Trophy, 
    $884 per month from his retirement, and $440 per month from rents.

 
   
    [6]  We also note that two months after the partiesâ€™ divorce, Husband 
    remarried.Â  Although Husband admittedly includes some of his new wifeâ€™s expenses 
    on his financial declaration, he did not in turn include her monthly income 
    of $1,400.

 
   [7] 
     Husband also argues that the award of attorneyâ€™s fees should be reversed 
    if we reverse the family courtâ€™s alimony decision.Â  Because we affirm the 
    family courtâ€™s decision not to reduce or terminate Husbandâ€™s alimony, we need 
    not address this issue.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 
    Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (stating that appellate 
    court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is 
    dispositive).
