THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Baird Pacific West,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Blue Water Sunset Park, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge
Thomas Kemmerlin, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.2004-UP-011
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael S. Seekings, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Joseph R. Baker, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Baird Pacific West, Inc. (â€œBairdâ€), 
  brought this action against Blue Water Sunset Park, Inc. (â€œBlue Waterâ€), alleging 
  breach of contract, fraud, and negligent misrepresentation in connection with 
  an agreement entered between the parties for the sale of land.Â  The circuit 
  court granted summary judgment in favor of Blue Water andÂ  awarded attorney 
  fees to Blue Water.Â  Baird appeals, arguing (1) summary judgment was improper; 
  and (2) the award of attorney fees was improper because Blue Water failed to 
  request attorney fees in its pleadings and Blue Waterâ€™s request for a hearing 
  concerning its motion for attorney fees was untimely, thus divesting the trial 
  court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
 In December 1996, the parties entered 
  into a contract in which Baird agreed to purchase and Blue Water agreed to sell 
  approximately eight acres of waterfront property on the north end of Hilton 
  Head Island.Â  The agreement set the purchase price at $1,725,000.
 The parties were unable to consummate 
  the original contract due to difficulties in obtaining approval from the state 
  environmental agency.Â Â  However, this approval was eventually obtained, and 
  in March 1998, Baird and Blue Water entered into an agreement to reinstate and 
  amend the earlier contract.Â  The parties agreed Baird would have until May 4, 
  1998 to conduct additional due diligence investigations.Â  They also agreed that 
  Baird was to waive its right to purchase an extension of the due diligence period, 
  as had been allowed under the terms of the original contract.Â  Baird could, 
  however, elect to withdraw from the contract at the end of the due diligence 
  period and receive a full refund of its earnest-money deposit.
Prior to the expiration of the new due 
  diligence period, Baird informed Blue Water of three problems Baird was unable 
  to resolve: a title defect, a discrepancy in the acreage of the property, and 
  an instability in some of the filled portions of the land.Â  Baird requested 
  an extension of the due diligence period in order to resolve these issues, and 
  if Blue Water was not amenable to that request, Baird alternatively suggested 
  they cancel the contract.Â  Blue Water declined to extend the due diligence review, 
  opting instead to terminate the contract.Â  The contract was cancelled, and Bairdâ€™s 
  earnest moneyÂ  was refunded. 
In March 1999, Baird brought the present 
  action, alleging Blue Water was liable to Baird for breach of contract, fraud, 
  and negligent misrepresentation due to Blue Waterâ€™s inability to convey marketable 
  title to the property.Â  Baird also sought to recover actual and consequential 
  damages.Â  
Pursuant to Blue Waterâ€™s motion for summary judgment, 
  the circuit court concluded there were no genuine issues of material fact and 
  found Blue Water was entitled to judgment as a matter of law on all of Bairdâ€™s 
  claims in a June 15, 2001 order, reserving Blue Waterâ€™s claim for attorney fees.Â  
  The circuit court granted Blue Water â€œleave to move for an award of attorney 
  fees and Court costs upon thirty (30) days notice to [Baird].â€Â  Following a 
  hearing, the circuit court awarded attorney fees and costs to Blue Water in 
  an October 2001 order.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court should grant a motion for summary 
  judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Fleming v. 
  Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  â€œIn determining whether 
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can 
  be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 
  332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  If triable issues of fact exist, 
  those issues must go to the jury.Â  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 
  333 S.C. 714, 717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Breach of Contract, Fraud, and Negligent 
  Misrepresentation
Bairdâ€™s claims for breach of contract, 
  fraud, and negligent misrepresentation all rest upon its assertion that Blue 
  Water was not able to convey marketable title as required by the terms of the 
  contract.Â  We find no merit to Bairdâ€™s position.
In construing the terms of a written contract 
  upon a motion for summary judgment, the question is one of law if the language 
  contained in the contract is plain and unambiguous.Â  MGC Mgmt. of Charleston, 
  Inc. v. Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 546, 520 S.E.2d 820, 822 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  â€œIn such a case, summary judgment is proper and a trial unnecessary 
  where the intention of the parties as to the legal effect of the contract may 
  be gathered from the four corners of the instrument itself.â€Â  First Citizens 
  Bank & Trust Co. v. Conway Natâ€™l Bank, 282 S.C. 303, 305, 317 S.E.2d 
  776, 777 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  It is well settled that, in construing a contract, 
  the court must ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties.Â  BP 
  Oil Co. v. Federated Mut. Ins. Co., Inc., 329 S.C. 631, 640, 496 S.E.2d 
  35, 40 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing D.A. Davis Constr. Co. v. Palmetto Properties, 
  Inc., 281 S.C. 415, 315 S.E.2d 370 (1984)).Â  When the intention of the parties 
  to a written agreement is at issue, the court must first look to the language 
  of the agreement.Â  C.A.N. Enterprises, Inc. v. South Carolina Health and 
  Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 377, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988);Â  
  Warner v. Weader, 280 S.C. 81, 83, 311 S.E.2d 78, 79 (1983).Â  If the 
  agreement is unambiguous, the court must construe it according to the terms 
  the parties chose.Â  Id.Â  These terms are to be understood in their ordinary 
  and popular sense.Â  Id.
With respect to title, the contract in 
  the present case provided:

TITLE. Seller shall convey marketable 
  title to the property to purchaser in fee simple by proper deed in recordable 
  form with stamps affixed and with covenants of general warranty subject to normal 
  utility easements, applicable restrictive covenants, governmental regulations 
  and assessments.Â  If an ownerâ€™s title binder can be issued by an ALTA [1]  title insurance company at standard rates with 
  standard exceptions for Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, title shall be deemed 
  to marketable. 

(emphasis added).
In compliance with these explicit terms, Blue Water 
  obtained and held at all pertinent times a title binder from the Chicago Title 
  Insurance Company (â€œChicago Titleâ€), an ATLA title insurance company.Â  The policy 
  was issued at standard rates with standard exceptions for Hilton Head Island. 
  Â We find these facts uncontroverted by the evidence contained in the 
  record.
However, Baird attempts to redirect the 
  attention of this Court from the plain language of the contract in an effort 
  to convince us Blue Water failed to honor its promise to convey marketable title.Â  
  We find these efforts unpersuasive.
For instance, Baird devotes substantial energies 
  to explaining why the title Blue Water was willing to convey would not be â€œclearâ€ 
  or â€œmarketableâ€ under general principles of real property law.Â  While this may 
  or may not be true, it is of little concern to the present inquiry.Â  Where the 
  parties have freely and knowingly entered into a contract â€“ as they did in the 
  present case â€“ our charge is only to give effect to the partiesâ€™ intentions 
  as memorialized in the contract language.Â  We see no reason, and none is alleged, 
  why we should veer from this mandate. 
Baird also claims that it could not obtain 
  title insurance with standard rates and exceptions due to the outstanding claims 
  on the title by a third party.Â  This third party claim, however, was clearly 
  contemplated and fully indemnified under the policy issued by Chicago Title.Â  
  This fact is amply demonstrated by a letter received from the insurance companyâ€™s 
  underwriting council, which confirms the insurerâ€™s obligation under the policy.Â  
  This letter reads, in relevant part:

Since Chicago Title has an outstanding 
  Ownerâ€™s Policy, we would be willing to insure over this [third-party claim] 
  problem in the policies for this property.Â  We would prefer to take exception 
  to the problem and provide affirmative coverage over it rather than issue a 
  â€œclean policy.â€ Â We prefer to reveal the problem and provide protection.Â  

However, regardless of the existence or disposition 
  of the alleged cloud on the title of the subject property, the fact remains 
  uncontroverted by the evidence in the record before us that Blue Water was able 
  at all times to provide adequate title insurance under the clear terms of the 
  contract language.
We conclude that Blue Water fully complied 
  with its obligation to convey marketable title to Baird as agreed to by the 
  parties.Â  Accordingly, Bairdâ€™s claims â€“ that Blue Water breached the contract 
  terms regarding title and that Blue Water fraudulently or negligently misrepresented 
  its ability to convey title â€“ are manifestly without merit.Â  The circuit court 
  correctly granted summary judgment in disposing of Bairdâ€™s specious claims.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorney Fees
Baird also argues the trial court erred in awarding 
  Blue Water attorney fees.Â  Specifically, it asserts two procedural defects concerning 
  Blue Waterâ€™s request for fees: first, that Blue Water failed to make its request 
  for attorney fees in its pleadings, and, second, that the circuit court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to consider the issue of attorney fees.Â  We find 
  these arguments unavailing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â Â Â Â Â  Request of Attorney Fees
We first find that, although Blue Water did not 
  make its request for attorney fees in its pleadings, its claim is not barred 
  under the circumstances of this case.Â  To be sure, the general rule is that 
  a party is entitled to seek only that relief set forth in its pleadings.Â  See 
  Premium Inv. Corp. v. Green, 283 S.C. 464, 474, 324 S.E.2d 72, 78 (Ct. 
  App. 1984).Â  In this case, however, the record reveals Blue Water raised the 
  issue of attorney fees in the affidavit accompanying its October 2000 summary 
  judgment motion.Â  Subsequently, during the May 2001 hearing on its motion for 
  summary judgment, Blue Water again sought the circuit courtâ€™s consideration 
  of the attorney fees issue.Â  Baird did not object, but rather stated: â€œI just 
  wanted to make sure that if the court takes up that issue, that I have time 
  to respond to it.â€Â  The circuit court acquiesced to Bairdâ€™s request and granted 
  Blue Water leave to move for award of attorney fees upon thirty days notice 
  to Baird.
A hearing on the request for attorney 
  fees was held, during which Baird objected, for the first time, that the claim 
  was barred for failure to plead.Â  The trial court ruled the request was allowed 
  under Rule 15(b), SCRCP, which allows amendment of the pleadings by express 
  or implied consent of the parties.Â  See Rule 15(b), SCRCP (stating â€œ[w]hen 
  issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of 
  the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised 
  in the pleadings.â€)Â  The decision to allow amendments under Rule 15(b) is entrusted 
  to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the amendment 
  bears the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 
  S.C. 303, 313, 566 S.E.2d 529, 535 (2002).Â  We are unable to discern any prejudice 
  to Baird in light of the fact that the issue of attorney fees was raised months 
  earlier.Â  We find the issue of attorney fees was properly before the circuit 
  court. 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction [2] 
Baird argues the circuit court lacked jurisdiction 
  to entertain Blue Waterâ€™s request for attorney fees.Â  Specifically, Baird claims 
  that Blue Water failed to seek attorney fees in a timely manner because it did 
  not file a motion within the ten-day time period prescribed by Rule 54, SCRCP.Â  
  The rule provides in pertinent part that a â€œmotion for costs, supported by an 
  affidavit that the costs are correct and were necessarily incurred in the action, 
  may be filed by the prevailing party within 10 days of the receipt of written 
  notice of the entry of final judgment.â€Â  Rule 54(d), SCRCP.Â  Additionally, Rule 
  54(b), SCRCP, partially provides:

[w]hen more than one claim for relief is presented in an action 
  â€¦ the court may direct the entry of a final judgment as to one or more but fewer 
  than all of the claims â€¦ upon an express determination that there is no just 
  reason for delay and upon an express direction for the entry of judgment.Â  In 
  the absence of such determination and direction, any order or other form of 
  decision, however designated, which adjudicates fewer than all the claims or 
  the rights and liabilities of fewer than all of the parties shall not terminate 
  the action as to any of the claims or parties, and the order or other form of 
  decision is subject to revision at any time before the entry of judgment adjudicating 
  all the claims and the rights and liabilities of all the parties.

Here, the circuit courtâ€™s order expressly recognized that 
  it reserved the matter of attorney fees for future determination.Â  Under these 
  circumstances, the circuit courtâ€™s continuing jurisdiction was in no manner 
  contingent upon Blue Water filing an additional motion within ten days following 
  the grant of summary judgment.Â  Moreover, the order granting summary judgment 
  contained no Rule 54(b) â€œexpress determination that there is no just reason 
  for delayâ€ of the formal entry of judgment.Â  Thus, since the matter of attorney 
  fees was reserved, we find that the trial courtâ€™s June 15, 2001 order cannot 
  be construed as an order disposing of all claims before the circuit court.Â  
  Accordingly, Bairdâ€™s reliance on the ten-day filing period provided in Rule 
  54(d) is misplaced, and the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to 
  award attorney fees and costs to Blue Water.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]    American Land Title Association.

 
   [2] Â  Blue Water argues that the issue 
    of subject matter jurisdiction is not properly before this court because Baird 
    raised it neither in the circuit court nor in its brief.Â  It is true that, 
    â€œ[a]s a general rule, an issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.â€Â  
    McKissick v. J.F. Cleckly & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 343, 479 S.E.2d 
    67, 75 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, issues related to subject matter jurisdiction 
    may be raised at any time.Â  Bunkum v. Manor Properties, 321 S.C. 95, 
    100, 467 S.E.2d 758, 761 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Thus, we find that the issue of 
    subject matter jurisdiction is properly before this court.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Thomas C. Meredith, III, and Lisa Marie Meredith,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gerald Stoudemayer, Raynold
Stoudemayer, and Loretta S. Canon,        Respondents,
And, Gerald Stoudemayer,       
Third-Party Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bob Capes Realty, Inc.,       
Third-Party Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-012
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gilbert Scott Bagnell, of Columbia, for Appellants.
G. Robin Alley and W. Joseph Isaacs, both of Columbia, for Respondents Raynold 
  Stoudemayer and Loretta S. Canon.
J. Layne Birdsong and James B. Richardson, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondent 
  Gerald Stoudemayer.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Thomas and Lisa Meredith commenced 
  this action seeking to enforce a contract of sale for the purchase of certain 
  property.Â  Loretta Canon and Raynold Stoudemayer answered and counterclaimed 
  asserting that they had a right of first refusal on the property.Â  Gerald Stoudemayer, 
  owner of the property, answered the complaint.Â  Gerald moved for summary judgment, 
  asking the court to determine which of the prospective purchasers had the right 
  to purchase his property and indicating his willingness to sell to either.Â  
  The court entered a partial summary judgment in favor of Loretta Canon and Raynold 
  Stoudemayer.Â  This appeal follows.
FACTS
At issue in this litigation is a parcel 
  of undeveloped property known as Tract 2, Stoudemayer Road located in Richland 
  Country, South Carolina.Â Â  Prior to 1998, this property was part of a single 
  150-acre tract owned by George Stoudemayer, who died on May 24, 1998, and was 
  survived by his four children: Gerald Stoudemayer, Raynold Stoudemayer, Loretta 
  Canon, and Sandra Smith.Â  A duly executed codicil to George Stoudemayerâ€™s Last 
  Will and Testament addressed the distribution of the 150-acre tract:

I give to my Personal Representatives the tract of 150 acres, 
  more or less, in Richland County inherited by me from my father, shown on a 
  plat by Arthur J. Weed, dated October 9, 1975, which is attached hereto and 
  incorporated herein, for the purposes of dividing the same among my children 
  in accordance with the division shown on said plat as follows:
Tract 1 to my son, Raynold Stoudemayer
Tract 2 to my son, Gerald Stoudemayer
Tract 3 to my daughter, Sandra S. Smith
Tract 4 with my house to my daughter, Loretta S. Canon.
Each of said children shall have the use of the road as access 
  to their tract and the use of the pond on the property.
None of my children shall sell their tract to any person without 
  first offering it to my other children at the same price as any bona fide offer 
  received.Â  Either or all of my other children shall have the right of first 
  refusal to purchase the tract on the same terms by notifying the child desiring 
  to sell of the exercise of such right, in writing, within fifteen (15) days 
  from receipt of written notice of the offer received.

Raynold Stoudemayer and Loretta Canon 
  were appointed as the estateâ€™s personal representatives and executed a deed 
  of distribution, dividing the 150-acre tract into four parcels, including the 
  property passed to Gerald Stoudemayer.
 Beginning in 1999, Gerald Stoudemayer 
  sought to sell his portion of the property.Â  On November 17, 2000, he signed 
  a contract with Thomas Meredith and Lisa Meredith for sale of the property.Â  
  As required under the codicil, Raynold Stoudemayer and Loretta Canon received 
  notice of the contract, and in turn, notified Gerald Stoudemayer of their desire 
  to exercise the right of first refusal included in the codicil.Â  On December 
  28, 2000, Raynold Stoudemayer and Loretta Canon signed a contract with Gerald 
  Stoudemayer for sale of the property.
The Merediths commenced this action seeking to 
  enforce their contract to purchase the property.Â  Loretta Canon and Raynold 
  Stoudemayer answered, asserting they had a right of first refusal on the property.Â  
  Gerald Stoudemayer answered the complaint and moved for summary judgment.Â  The 
  trial court granted partial summary judgment in favor of Loretta Canon and Raynold 
  Stoudemayer, determining the property is subject to the right of first refusal 
  described in the codicil.
ISSUE
Did the trial court correctly rule that 
  Raynold Stoudemayer and Loretta Canon have a valid right of first refusal over 
  the property owned by Gerald Stoudemayer?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
To obtain summary judgment, the moving party must 
  demonstrate there is â€œno genuine issue of material fact and the moving party 
  is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56, SCRCP; Wilson v. 
  Moseley, 327 S.C. 144, 146, 488 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1997).Â  As a conclusion 
  of law, we review the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment de novo.Â  See 
  Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 301, 501 S.E.2d 746, 749 (Ct. 
  App. 1998) (â€œAn appellate court reviews the granting of summary judgment under 
  the same standard applied by the trial court.â€).
LAW/ANALYSIS
 The Stoudemayer siblings assert that their 
  contract should prevail by virtue of the right of first refusal under the codicil.Â  
  The Merediths contend that the Stoudemayer siblingsâ€™ right of first refusal 
  under the codicil should be given no effect because the deed of distribution 
  executed by the personal representative did not include any restriction in its 
  granting clause and thus conveyed fee simple title to Stoudemayer.Â  We disagree.
We turn first to the language of the codicil to 
  determine its effect.Â  The applicable language of the codicil provides, â€œI give 
  to my Personal Representatives the tract of 150 acres, more or less . . . for 
  the purpose of dividing the same among my children.â€Â  At the outset, we think 
  it clear that the phrase, â€œgive to my personal representatives,â€ did not carry 
  with it the legal effect of creating a devise of the 150-acre tract of land 
  to the estateâ€™s fiduciary, nor does the document suggest George Stoudemayer 
  harbored such an intent.Â  We need not resort to a mechanistic recitation of 
  the canons of construction to arrive at such a conclusion.Â  Common sense compels 
  this result.Â  Buttressing this analysis is the verbiage of the codicil devising 
  the property:

If prior to my death the expense for my care, support and 
  maintenance exceeds funds which I have on hand and such expense is then paid 
  by my children, or any of them, it is my will that they share such expense in 
  proportion to the interest in the real estate above devised to them.Â  
  (Emphasis added).

George Stoudemayer devised his 150-acre tract of 
  land to his progeny, not to those with the fiduciary obligation of administering 
  his estate.Â  
We address the Probate Code for the purpose of 
  determining the precise point at which the property was transferred to the four 
  devisees.
South Carolina Code section 62-3-101 states, â€œUpon 
  the death of a person, his real property devolves to the persons to whom it 
  is devised by his last will . . . and his personal property devolves, first, 
  to his personal representative . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-101 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  This section stands as the modern codification of the common law rule first 
  stated in Executors of Crosland v. Murdock:

The executor derives his powers over the goods of his testator 
  from the grant of the ordinary, but not so with regard to lands devised, or 
  an authority to sell lands.Â  These the devisee takes directly under the will, 
  and immediately from the testator.Â  The fee cannot be in abeyance, and on his 
  death it vests eo instanti.

15 S.C.L. (4 McCord) 217, 218 (1827).Â  Thus, while 
  a deviseeâ€™s title to real property remains subject to the personal representativeâ€™s 
  handling of administrative costs and creditorâ€™s claims, the personal representative 
  never actually takes title to the devised real property.Â  In contrast, as denoted 
  by the final portion of the above statutory excerpt, personal property receives 
  an altogether different treatment.Â  Unlike its treatment of real property, the 
  Code specifically dictates that personal property actually devolves to the personal 
  representative.Â  See Gibson v. Belcher, 287 S.C. 315, 318, 338 
  S.E.2d 330, 332 (1985) (â€œIt has long been the law in South Carolina that upon 
  the testatorâ€™s death, title to the personal property vests in the executor.â€).Â  
  This disparate treatment of real property and personal property provides the 
  key to understanding the legal consequence of the deed of distribution Raynold 
  Stoudemayer and Loretta Canon executed in compliance with the Probate Codeâ€™s 
  requirement that one be executed whenever distribution is made in kind.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-907 (Supp. 1987).
At the time George Stoudemayerâ€™s estate was administered, 
  the Code did not give deeds of distribution the effect of conveying title.Â  
  From 1987 to 2000, the Probate Code provided as follows: 
  [1] 

If distribution in kind (whether real or personal property) 
  is made, the personal representative must execute an instrument or deed of distribution 
  assigning, transferring, or releasing the assets to the distributee as evidence 
  of the distributeeâ€™s title to the property.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-907 (1987).Â  Giving the statute 
  its plain meaning, the deed of distribution is â€œevidenceâ€ of a distributeeâ€™s 
  title; it is not the method by which a distributee takes title. 
Moreover, through its use of the words â€œassigning, 
  transferring, or releasing,â€ the Probate Code plainly anticipates deeds of distribution 
  as having three possible effects.Â  As relates to distributions of real property, 
  however, that function can neither be one of assignment nor of transfer because 
  the Probate Code unmistakably establishes that title to real property is transferred 
  at the time of the testatorâ€™s death.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-101 (Supp. 1987).Â  
  Thus, as relates to real property, the deed of distribution carries the third 
  functionâ€”that of release.Â  That is, the deed of distribution acts as an official 
  declaration that the property is no longer subject to the personal representativeâ€™s 
  handling of administrative costs, creditorsâ€™ claims, and the like.
In sum, title to the real property passed to Stoudemayer 
  immediately upon the death of his father.Â  The subsequently executed deed of 
  distribution merely evidenced Stoudemayerâ€™s title to the land while also acting 
  as an official release of the land from the personal representativesâ€™ administrative 
  control.Â  As a consequence, the right of first refusal described in the codicil 
  remains in full effect. 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and
CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
     
    [1]    Effective August 17, 2000, the General Assembly amendedÂ  Â§ 62-3-907 
    such that the entire former section was redesignated Â§ 62-3-907(A) and subsections 
    (B) and (C) were added to address specific distributions of real property.Â  
    These amendments, however, took effect after the execution of the deed of 
    distribution.Â  As such, the 2000 amendments have no bearing on the case at 
    bar.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
St. Helena Congregation of Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The Heirs at Law and the Distributees of Joe Major, a/k/a Joe Major, 
        Sr., Louise Major, and the Following Individuals or Entities Believed 
        to be Living or in Existence:Â  Joe Major, Jr. a/k/a Joe Major, II, James 
        L. Daise, Elizabeth Anderson, Ruth D. Terry, Mamie Washington, Margaret 
        P. Fraser, James C. Sang, Ibis, Inc., Joy Logan, Beaufort County Treasurer, 
        John Doe and Mary Roe,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-013
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 15, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gary Lewis, of Beaufort, for Appellant. 
No Appearance by Respondents.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  St. Helenaâ€™s Congregation of Jehovahâ€™s 
  Witnesses appeals the order of the master in equity refusing to quiet title 
  to certain property in the City of Beaufort.Â  We affirm. [1]   
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
St. Helenaâ€™s brought an action to quiet title and 
  confirm boundaries to two separate, adjoining lots in the City of Beaufort.Â  
  All named defendants were served, failed to answer, and were held in default. 
  Â The circuit court referred the matter to the master in equity with finality.Â  
  During the hearing, the master noted the complaint mentioned two lots but only 
  described one and permitted counsel to amend as to every person served under 
  the order of publication to conform to proper notice requirements.Â  
Shortly into the hearing, the master suggested 
  the case was proven and that he was inclined to sign a final decree in St. Helenaâ€™s 
  favor. Â Counsel for St. Helenaâ€™s relied on these favorable comments and informed 
  both St. Helenaâ€™s and a prospective purchaser of the lots that the case had 
  been proven and the matter would be concluded shortly.Â  The purchaser, in reliance 
  on counselâ€™s assurances, proceeded to tear down a house located on one of the 
  lots.Â  Unfortunately, the master later realized he could not quiet title in 
  favor of St. Helenaâ€™s based upon the evidence before him and issued an order 
  denying the request to quiet title.Â  
Prior to drafting the order, the master telephoned 
  counsel for St. Helenaâ€™s, giving him the choice of an adverse ruling or accepting 
  a voluntary dismissal.Â  Counsel responded by letter reminding the master of 
  his remarks at trial and of the partiesâ€™ reliance on counselâ€™s relay of those 
  remarks.Â  Counsel also insisted the masterâ€™s concerns about whether the property 
  consisted of two lots rather than one and whether the tax deed was accurate 
  were resolved in post-trial discussions among counsel, the master, and a title 
  abstractor. Â 
Upon receipt of the order, counsel wrote to the 
  master, claiming a factual inaccuracy in the order in the identification of 
  a predecessor in title, and urging reconsideration. Â The master returned the 
  letter requesting counsel make a formal motion for reconsideration.Â  A motion 
  for reconsideration was made and promptly denied. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
St. Helenaâ€™s argues the master erred by issuing 
  a written order inconsistent with his remarks at the reference hearing and by 
  refusing to reopen the case â€œto allow Plaintiff to convince him that he should 
  not have changed his mind.â€Â  We disagree.
St. Helenaâ€™s acknowledges in its brief that the 
  master was entitled to change his mind, merely claiming such a reversal is uncommon.Â  
  Uncommon or not, â€œ[n]o order is final until it is written and entered.â€Â  First 
  Union Natâ€™l Bank v. Hitman, Inc., 306 S.C. 327, 329, 411 S.E.2d 681, 682 
  (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Rule 58(a), SCRCP).Â  â€œUntil written and entered, the 
  trial judge retains discretion to change his mind and amend his oral ruling 
  accordingly.â€Â  Ford v. State Ethics Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 
  821, 823 (2001); Case v. Case, 243 S.C. 447, 451, 134 S.E.2d 394, 396 
  (1964) (holding even if the trial judge made an oral ruling in favor of one 
  party, â€œsuch pronouncement is not a final ruling on the merits nor is it binding 
  on the parties until it has been reduced to writing, signed by the judge, and 
  delivered for recordationâ€); First Union Natâ€™l Bank, 306 S.C. at 329, 
  411 S.E.2d at 682.Â  
A trial judgeâ€™s decision not to reopen a case for 
  additional testimony is a matter within his sound discretion, and the decision 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Wright v. 
  Strickland, 306 S.C. 187, 410 S.E.2d 596, 597 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  We find 
  no abuse of discretion under the circumstances.Â  St. Helenaâ€™s made no proffer 
  of testimony or documents it sought to present.Â  As the master indicated, there 
  is nothing in the transcript indicating St. Helenaâ€™s had further evidence it 
  would have offered but for the masterâ€™s remarks.Â  St. Helenaâ€™s argues a new 
  hearing would permit the introduction of another deed into evidence that would 
  clarify the description of the property in question.Â  The master addressed this 
  deed in his original order and determined it would only further confuse the 
  issues.Â  Thus, St. Helenaâ€™s made no showing that additional documents would 
  make a difference in the outcome of the case.Â  
St. Helenaâ€™s argues the master erred on the merits 
  when he denied its claim to quiet title and confirm boundaries for two lots.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
Since this action was heard by a master in equity 
  who entered final judgment, we must review the entire record and make our own 
  findings of fact in accordance with our view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Townes Associates, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 
  773 (1976).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard 
  the findings of the master, who saw and heard the evidence and was in a better 
  position to evaluate its credibility.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 
  301 S.C. 229, 391 S.E.2d 538 (1989).Â  
St. Helenaâ€™s argues a deed it informally presented 
  to the master subsequent to trial reveals St. Helenaâ€™s predecessors in title 
  held two lots despite the fact that the complaint references a deed showing 
  the conveyance of only one lot.Â  St. Helenaâ€™s also attempts to advance new arguments 
  supporting the validity of a tax sale in opposition to the masterâ€™s finding 
  that the tax deed revealed the transfer of substantially less than two lots.Â  
  Again, St. Helenaâ€™s urges that but for the masterâ€™s favorable comments at the 
  trial, it would have entered supporting documentation into evidence and advanced 
  these arguments at the hearing.Â  
We agree with the masterâ€™s ruling that St. Helenaâ€™s 
  relied upon a deed referenced in its complaint which clearly conveyed only one 
  lot to a predecessor in its chain of title.Â  Moreover, the single lot was later 
  held as tenants in common due to a death.Â  A tax deed indicates that one of 
  the tenantâ€™s shares became subject to a tax levy, was sold, and later passed 
  by quitclaim deed to St. Helenaâ€™s.Â  Thus, St. Helenaâ€™s held, at most, a one-half 
  undivided interest with the other tenant or his heirs.Â  Nothing else appearing 
  in the record, we cannot say the master erred in determining he could not quiet 
  title in favor of St. Helenaâ€™s for two lots.Â  We also agree that the production 
  of a deed subsequent to trial describing a transfer of two adjacent lots within 
  St. Helenaâ€™s chain of title is insufficient to overcome the problems created 
  by the deed referenced in the original complaint.Â  The new deed does not expand 
  the original grant of one lot nor does it sweep in the one-half share not transferred 
  by the tax deed.Â  
Finally, St. Helenaâ€™s requests that the masterâ€™s 
  order be vacated because of purported bias against counsel.Â  In response to 
  counselâ€™s request, which occurred almost a year after the master issued his 
  final order in this case, he recused himself from all of counselâ€™s cases.Â  Counsel 
  claims the master admitted to bias against him by agreeing to his request; however, 
  the master merely did as he was asked, in a routine order and without acrimony.Â  
  There is simply nothing in the record to indicate the master was in violation 
  of any canon of judicial conduct and should have recused himself.Â  His later 
  recusal was purely voluntary.Â  See Canon 3(E)(1)(a) of the Code of Judicial 
  Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR (requiring a judge to recuse himself when â€œhe has a 
  personal bias or prejudice concerning a party. . . .â€).Â  We accordingly find 
  any claim of bias in this case frivolous.
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,

v.

  
    
      
Norwood, Allen Jefferson       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-014
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  15, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, and Richard Harold Warder, both of 
  Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, 
  of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Norwood appeals from his convictions 
  for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, 
  arguing the Stateâ€™s reference to a prior bad act in a portion of its questioning 
  and closing argument was improper.
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
During Norwoodâ€™s trial for murder and possession 
  of a firearm in connection with the May 27, 2001 murder of Carl Anthony Armstrong, 
  the State informed the court it had knowledge of a prior incident involving 
  Norwood and the victim in which Norwood attempted to shoot the victim.Â  In response, 
  the court instructed the State it could attack Norwoodâ€™s character on rebuttal 
  if the defense brought in the character issue.Â  The defense did not introduce 
  the character issue; however, the State referred to the prior incident during 
  its cross-examination of Norwood and his wife, as well as during its closing 
  argument.Â  Although Norwood now argues the Stateâ€™s reference to the prior incident 
  was improper under Rule 404(a), SCRE (stating â€œevidence of a personâ€™s character 
  or trait of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in 
  conformity therewith on a particular occasionâ€), Norwoodâ€™s counsel never objected 
  to this line of questioning at trial, nor did counsel object to the closing 
  argument statements referencing the prior bad act.Â  Norwood raises this issue 
  for the first time on appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
We affirm pursuant to 
  Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:
As to the failure to object to the prior 
  bad act evidence: see State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 69, 406 
  S.E.2d 315, 328 (1991) (holding a contemporaneous objection is required at trial 
  to preserve an error for appellate review); State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 
  386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1994) (noting an issue which is not properly 
  preserved cannot be raised for the first time on appeal); Wilder Corp. v. 
  Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (stating an issue cannot 
  be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled 
  upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); State v. Black, 
  319 S.C. 515, 522-23, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995) (determining a failure 
  to object when the evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to 
  object).
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Kenneth R.
Whitcraft,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-018
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 15, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John B. Williams, of Moncks Corner, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General Treva Ashworth, Assistant Attorney General 
  Deborah R. J. Shupe, Assistant Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson, all 
  of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â  A jury found that Appellant was a sexually violent predator. 
  We affirm.
 FACTS
Kenneth Whitcraft pled guilty to criminal sexual 
  conduct with a minor (second degree) in 1990. Whitcraft had been convicted on 
  similar charges in Pennsylvania as early as 1985. He was given a 16-year sentence. 
  In March of 2001, as Whitcraft was approaching his parole date, the state petitioned 
  Judge Dennis to declare Whitcraft a sexually violent predator. At trial, the 
  stateâ€™s expert witness testified that Whitcraft had a â€œhistory, â€¦ severe difficulty 
  controlling his impulsesâ€; that Whitcraft suffered from pedophilia, alcohol 
  abuse, and anxiety disorder; that Whitcraft could have great difficulty controlling 
  his impulses if he started abusing alcohol again; that Whitcraft was in â€œthe 
  moderate to higher risk to reoffendâ€ group of sex offenders; and that Whitcraft 
  met the statutory definition of a â€œsexually violent predator.â€ After both sides 
  presented testimony, Whitcraft moved for a directed verdict. The trial judge 
  declined. The Berkeley County jury found that the state had proven beyond a 
  reasonable doubt that Whitcraft was a sexually violent predator under S.C. Ann. 
  Code Â§ 44-48-30. The trial judge then committed Whitcraft to the Department 
  of Mental Health â€œlong term.â€ Whitcraft appeals.
ISSUES

(1) Did the trial court err in not ruling that 
  the state failed to carry its burden under Kansa v. Crane? 
(2) Does the Sexual Violent Predator Act violate 
  the Ex Post Facto clauses of the U.S. and the South Carolina constitutions?
(3) Does restraining Whitcraft even after he has served 
  his sentence constitute cruel and unusual punishment?

Â ANALYSIS 
â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried 
  by a jury, the [j]urisdiction of this Court extends merely to the correction 
  of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not be disturbed unless 
  a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably 
  supports the jury's findings.â€ Townes Assoc., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 8, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (citing Odom v. Weathersbee, 
  225 S.C. 253, 81 S.E.2d 788 (1954)).Â Â  
Whitcraft first argues that the state failed to 
  carry its burden under Kansas, as adopted in South Carolina. 
  [1]  The South Carolina Act defines a sexually violent predator as a â€œperson 
  likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined â€¦.â€ S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§44-48-30(1) (2002). In In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Luckabaugh, 
  351 S.C. 122, 144, 568 S.E.2d 338, 349 (2002), the court declared that under 
  the Act, â€œthe individual can only be committed if he suffers from a mental illness 
  which he cannot sufficiently control without the structure and care provided 
  by a mental health facility, rendering him likely to commit a dangerous act.â€ 
  In re Luckabaugh clearly mandates, among other elements, a finding that 
  the defendant requires residential treatment in order to control his impulses 
  before he can be committed to a long-term state facility.
Whitcraft argues that no such evidence was adduced at trial. 
  We disagree. At trial, the stateâ€™s expert testified that Whitcraft suffered 
  from three illnesses: alcohol abuse, anxiety disorder, and â€œmore seriousâ€ or 
  â€œsevereâ€ pedophilia that could cause him extreme difficulty in controlling his 
  impulses. The stateâ€™s expert witness also specifically agreed that â€œWhitcraft 
  suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that â€¦ give[s] him 
  the propensity to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure 
  facility for long-term care and treatment.â€ Based on that testimony, the jury 
  found that Whitcraft is a sexually violent predator as defined under the Act. 

It is true that the evidence against Whitcraft 
  was less than overwhelming. [2]  And there was contradicting testimony 
  from Whitcraftâ€™s expert. However, when ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, 
  a trial court considers the existence of the evidence, not its weight. State 
  v. Glaser, 349 S.C. 545, 548, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002). Here, the jury found 
  that Whitcraft was a sexually violent predator. There was sufficient evidence 
  to reasonably support that finding. Therefore, we cannot disturb the finding.
Whitcraft also argues that the Act violates the 
  ex post facto clause of both the U.S. and the South Carolina Constitutions. 
  That contention, however, is without merit since our supreme court has already 
  ruled that the Act is constitutional. The court held in In re: Luckabaugh, 
  351 S.C. at 135, 568 S.E.2d at 344 that â€œthe Act is a civil, non-punitive scheme.â€ 
  The court explained that a â€œstatute creating two types of civil commitment is 
  not per se punitive in violation of the ex post facto clause.â€ 
  Id. at 138, 568 S.E.2d at 246.
Since the Act is constitutional, Whitcraftâ€™s third 
  argument must necessarily fail.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, J.J., concur. 

 
    [1]  Our Supreme Court has held that the stateâ€™s Sexual 
    Violent Predator Act is essentially similar to the Kansas statute addressed 
    in Kansas. In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Allen, 
    351 S.C. 153, 156, 568 S.E.2d 354, 355 (2002) (citing In the Matter of 
    the care and Treatment of McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 91, 551 S.E.2d 235, 
    238 (2001); In the Matter of the care and Treatment of Matthews, 354 
    S.C. 638, 649, 550 S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001)). 

 
    [2]  The stateâ€™s expert indicated that 
    Whitcraft suffers from a serious form of pedophilia that could lead 
    to further offenses; that would be severe if left untreated; that he 
    could be treated in a non-residential facility; that Whicraft had cooperated 
    with the psychologist and accepted â€œsomeâ€ responsibility for his actions.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Real Estate Unlimited, L.L.C.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Rainbow Living Trust, Lelie Rae M. Foster aka Leliaree Foster aka Lelia 
        Ree Foster, Stephen Ford, as Delinquent Tax Collector for Spartanburg 
        County, and Steve Arthur Foster, Defendants,
        of whom Rainbow Living Trust is       
        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Roger L. Couch , Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-019
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 15, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Felix A. Bulsa, of Inman, for Appellant.
Leonard R. Jordan, Jr., Berry Quackenbush, of Columbia, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action to set aside 
  a tax deed, Felix Bulsa appeals on behalf of Rainbow Living Trust asserting 
  the master-in-equity in determining that as trustee, Bulsa cannot represent 
  the Trust in the action because he is not an attorney.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Trust was the high bidder at a tax 
  sale for the subject property held November 4, 1997.Â  Stephen Ford, the Delinquent 
  Tax Collector for Spartanburg County issued a tax deed to the Trust dated November 
  30, 1998 and recorded January 22, 1999.Â  
On June 21, 2000, Real Estate Unlimited, 
  L.L.C., which had purchased the property at a mortgage foreclosure sale by deed 
  dated April 23, 1998, brought an action to set aside the tax sale.Â  Bulsa, as 
  trustee for the Trust, filed an answer to Real Estate Unlimitedâ€™s complaint 
  and asserted a counterclaim.Â  In its reply to the counterclaim, Real Estate 
  Unlimited asserted that because Bulsa is not an attorney licensed to practice 
  law in South Carolina, he should not be allowed to represent the Trust in this 
  matter.Â  
At the beginning of the hearing before 
  the master-in-equity, counsel for Real Estate Unlimited again raised an objection 
  to Bulsa appearing on behalf of the Trust.Â  The master ruled he would not allow 
  Bulsa to argue on the Trustâ€™s behalf.Â  In his written order, the master again 
  stated that Bulsa could not represent the Trust because he is not an attorney.Â  
  He held that as the pleadings served and filed by Bulsa were a nullity, the 
  Trust was deemed to be in default, and he would not address the issues raised 
  in the counterclaim.Â  In the same order, the master vacated the tax deed holding 
  the Delinquent Tax Collector for Spartanburg County failed to send the proper 
  owners of record the requisite notices.Â  Bulsa filed this appeal on behalf of 
  the Trust.Â  
DISCUSSION
Bulsa argues the master erred in holding Bulsa 
  was not allowed to represent the Trust.Â  We disagree. [1]   
South Carolina Code Annotated Section 
  40-5-310 (2001) provides, â€œNo person may practice or solicit the cause of another 
  person in a court of this State unless he has been admitted and sworn as an 
  attorney.â€Â  However, a citizen may prosecute or defend his own cause, if he 
  so desires.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-5-80 (Supp. 2002).Â  Although Bulsa maintains 
  the Trust is a â€œspecial legal entity,â€ he claims he was merely representing 
  himself by appearing on behalf of the Trust.Â  
The issue of whether a non-attorney trustee may 
  appear in court on behalf of the trust is novel in South Carolina.Â  However, 
  numerous other jurisdictions have addressed the issue and found a trusteeâ€™s 
  appearance in court on behalf of the trust would constitute the unauthorized 
  practice of law.Â  
The Supreme Court of Arkansas held a trustee who 
  is not a licensed attorney cannot practice law in matters relating to his trusteeship 
  on the theory that he is practicing for himself.Â  Arkansas Bar Assoc. v. 
  Union Natâ€™l Bank of Little Rock, 273 S.W.2d 408, 410 (Ark. 1954).Â  The court 
  explained that a trustee is not acting for himself and in connection with his 
  own business affairs but on the contrary is acting for others who ordinarily 
  would be the beneficiaries. Id. at 411.Â  
The Supreme Court of Nebraska noted that, â€œ[A]s 
  a general rule, a trust is not a legal personality, and the trustee is the proper 
  person to sue or be sued on behalf of suchÂ  trust.â€ Back Acres Pure Trust 
  v. Fahnlander, 443 N.W.2d 604, 605 (Neb. 1989).Â  However, the court found, 
  â€œthat a trusteeâ€™s duties in connection with his or her office do not include 
  the right to present argument pro se in courts of the state, because 
  in this capacity such trustee would be representing interests of others and 
  would therefore be engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.â€Â  Id.Â  

Similarly, the United States Court of Appeals for 
  the Ninth Circuit held a personâ€™s status as trustee did not include the right 
  to present arguments pro se in federal court.Â  C.E. Pope Equity Trust 
  v. U.S., 818 F.2d 696, 697 (9th Cir. 1987).Â  It stated the trusteeâ€™s 
  status is that of fiduciary and his statutory responsibility was the orderly 
  administration of assets.Â  Id.Â  Although it noted the record did not 
  identify the trustâ€™s beneficiaries, it held because â€œ[the trustee] is not the 
  actual beneficial owner of the claims being asserted by the Trusts (so far as 
  one can tell from the record), he cannot be viewed as a â€˜partyâ€™ conducting his 
  â€˜own case personallyâ€™ within the meaning of [28 U.S.C. Â§ 1654]â€.Â  Id. 
  at 697-98.Â  See also Maisano v. Welcher, 940 F.2d 499 (9th 
  Cir. 1991) (finding that if property belonged to the trust, the trustees had 
  no standing to sue); Ziegler v. Nickel, 75 Cal.Rptr.2d 312 (Cal. Ct. 
  App. 1998) (stating a non-attorney trustee who represents the trust in court 
  is representing and affecting the interests of the beneficiary and is thus engaged 
  in the unauthorized practice of law); Lazy â€˜Lâ€™ Family Preservation Trust 
  v. First State Bank of Princeton, 521 N.E.2d 198 (Ill. App. Ct. 1988) (finding 
  that even if trust document purported to authorize person to represent trust 
  in court, it cannot empower him to practice law without a license); Salman 
  v. Newell, 885 P.2d 607 (Nev. 1994) (while taking no position on the validity 
  of trusts, holding non-attorney trustee may not represent trust in district 
  court or appellate court); Williams v. Global Constr. Co., 498 N.E.2d 
  500, 502 (Ohio Ct. App. 1985) (finding where trustee brought action in the name 
  of a trust, he was acting as an attorney for the trust and engaged in the unauthorized 
  practice of law); Life Science Church, Bible Camp & Christian Liberty 
  Academy v. Shawano County, 585 N.W.2d 625, 334 (Wis. 1998) (â€œ[T]rustees 
  may appear in Wisconsin courts without licensed legal counsel only to represent 
  their own legal interests in their individual capacities, not to represent the 
  legal interests of their trusts or trust beneficiaries in their representative, 
  fiduciary capacities as trustees.â€).
We find these cases persuasive and hold section 
  40-5-80 does not authorize a non-attorney trustee of a valid trust to represent 
  the trust in the court of common pleas because the action would not be the trusteeâ€™s 
  â€œown causeâ€ but rather that of the trust and its beneficiaries.Â  Accordingly, 
  when assuming the Trust in this matter is valid, we hold the master did not 
  err in ruling Bulsa may not represent the Trust in his court.Â  
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY concur.Â  

 
   [1] Â Â  For this opinion, we assume the Trust is a valid 
    trust.Â

text:

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Carmilla C. Simpkins,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joshua Bennett,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-020
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
John P. Riordan, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Carmilla 
  C. Simpkins sued Joshua Bennett for damages allegedly arising from an automobile 
  accident.Â  The jury awarded Simpkins $14,000.00.Â  Simpkins appeals.Â  We affirm.Â  

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On February 18, 1998, the Corvette Bennett 
  was driving rear-ended the Pontiac Bonneville driven by Simpkins.Â  Bennett was 
  issued a ticket for the accident.Â  At the accident scene neither party complained 
  of injuries or requested an ambulance.Â  That night, Simpkins went to the emergency 
  room at Easley Medical Center.Â  She later sought treatment with Stephenson Chiropractic 
  Offices and Dr. Downey with Augusta Pain Management.Â  She also received physical 
  therapy and consulted with a surgeon.Â  At trial she submitted medical bills 
  totaling $10,272.00.Â  She also claimed $10,810.00 in lost wages from the date 
  of the accident until January 1999.Â  
After the jury returned a verdict in favor 
  of Simpkins in the amount of $14,000.00, she moved for a new trial or new trial 
  nisi additur.Â  The court denied these motions.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  

DISCUSSION 
Simpkins argues the trial court should 
  have granted her a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine because the 
  jury disregarded the trial courtâ€™s instructions and did not properly include 
  all of her damages in its verdict.Â  
Under the thirteenth juror doctrine, the trial 
  court may grant a new trial if the court believes the evidence does not justify 
  the verdict.Â  Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254, 387 S.E.2d 265, 267 
  (1990).Â  â€œThis ruling has been termed a granting of a new trial on the facts.â€Â  
  Id. at 254, 387 S.E.2d at 267.Â  In addition, the court may grant a new 
  trial if the verdict is inconsistent and reflects the juryâ€™s confusion.Â  Sorin 
  Equip. Co. v. The Firm, 323 S.C. 359, 364, 474 S.E.2d 819, 822 (Ct. App. 
  1996).Â  In ruling on a new trial motion as the thirteenth juror, the trial court 
  may weigh the evidence and rely on his or her view of the circumstances.Â  Id.Â  
  Basically, the doctrine permits the judge as the thirteenth juror to hang the 
  jury.Â  Folkens, 300 S.C. at 254, 387 S.E.2d at 267.Â  
When reviewing the denial of a motion for a new 
  trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine, this court considers only whether 
  there is any evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  Haselden v. 
  Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 506, 534 S.E.2d 295, 306 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In order 
  to reverse the trial court when it denies a new trial under the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine, we must find the moving party was entitled to a directed verdict during 
  the trial.Â  Id.Â  Thus, this court must affirm the denial of the new trial 
  when viewing the evidence, and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom in 
  the light most favorable to the nonmoving party, we find the evidence yields 
  more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina 
  State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  Neither the 
  trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues 
  or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 
  350 S.C. 303, 308, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).
Simpkins argues that because she submitted evidence 
  of medical bills and lost wages incurred totaling $21,082.00, the verdict should 
  have been at a minimum that amount.Â  She asserts the juryâ€™s failure to award 
  her at least that amount demonstrates its failure to follow the trial courtâ€™s 
  instruction on the calculation of damages.Â  
While Simpkins did submit evidence of damages totaling 
  over $21,000.00, it was within the juryâ€™s province to determine that not all 
  of the claimed damages were proximately caused by the accident.Â  Simpkins acknowledged 
  Bennettâ€™s Corvette was smaller than the Pontiac Bonneville she was driving.Â  
  Corporal Page, the reporting officer, testified the accident caused at the most 
  minimal damage to either automobile and neither car was towed from the scene.Â  
  Simpkins did not complain of any injuries at the scene of the accident and did 
  not request an ambulance.Â  
Simpkins had been involved in two prior automobile 
  accidents in which she had sustained severe whiplash.Â  The more recent one occurred 
  in July of 1997.Â  As a result of that accident, her doctor assigned her a six 
  percent impairment rating to the entire body.Â  Simpkinsâ€™ discharge sheet from 
  the Easley Baptist Medical Center emergency room instructed her to see her family 
  doctor if she had any problems.Â  Rather than returning to the doctor who treated 
  her for the prior accidents, Simpkins sought treatment from a chiropractor.Â  
  After the chiropractor released her in May of 1998, Simpkins sought treatment 
  from Dr. Downey with the Augusta Pain Management Center.Â  In reporting her prior 
  health history, she failed to disclose the prior accidents.Â  She also failed 
  to disclose the 1997 accident to her physical therapist.Â  
Dr. Downey acknowledged that when considering Simpkinsâ€™ 
  medical records, which Bennettâ€™s attorney provided him on the day of his deposition, 
  he could not determine whether Simpkins cervical nerve root problem came from 
  the most recent accident or was preexisting.Â  Dr. Downey also stated hypothyroidism, 
  a condition from which Simpkins suffers, could cause some of the symptoms Simpkins 
  experiences such as muscle aches and headaches.Â  In addition, Dr. Downey stated 
  chiropractic treatment could cause problems like Simpkins experiences.
A surgeon, Dr. Estes, to whom Dr. Downey referred 
  Simpkins wrote back that it was difficult to tell whether Simpkins was using 
  full effort with her right arm and leg.Â  He stated that although she gave the 
  impression of generalized right-sided weakness, this did not fit her history.Â  
  Bennett testified that in his previous meetings with Simpkins, she had not used 
  a cane when she walked.Â  
The record reveals no evidence to support Simpkinsâ€™ 
  claim for lost wages other than her testimony.Â  Prior to the accident, Simpkins 
  had lost her job with the post office.Â  She stated in her deposition that she 
  would return to that job if her pending claim with the Equal Employment Opportunity 
  Commission was resolved in her favor.Â  She claimed that after she lost her job, 
  she performed housekeeping services for two people earning $250.00 a week.Â  
  Although she testified her chiropractor released her to return to work in May 
  of 1998, Simpkins claimed lost wages through January of 1999.Â  There is no other 
  evidence of a medical excuse from work in the record.Â Â Â  

The fact that testimony is not contradicted directly does 
  not render it undisputed.Â  There remains the question of the inherent probability 
  of the testimony and the credibility of the witness or the interests of the 
  witness in the result of the litigation.Â  If there is anything tending to create 
  distrust in his or her truthfulness, the question must be left to the jury.Â  


Black v. Hodge, 306 S.C. 196, 198, 410 S.E.2d 
  595, 596 (Ct. App. 1991) (internal citations and quotation marks omitted).Â  

It was the right of the jury to consider the witnessesâ€™ 
  testimonies and determine that not all of the damages Simpkins claimed were 
  attributable to what was described by the reporting officer and Bennett as a 
  minor accident.Â  We cannot find from the juryâ€™s verdict, which was lower than 
  Simpkins expected, that the jury disregarded the trial courtâ€™s charge on damages.Â  
  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in denying Simpkinsâ€™ motion 
  for a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  
Simpkins also argues the trial court erred in denying 
  her motions for new trial nisi additur or new trial absolute.Â  She asserts 
  the verdict was unreasonably low and that the jury was acting out of prejudice 
  or caprice. 
The trial court alone has the power to 
  grant a new trial nisi when it finds the amount of the verdict to be 
  merely inadequate or excessive.Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 526, 
  431 S.E.2d 555, 557 (1993). The denial of a motion for a new trial nisi 
  is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  On appeal of the denial of a motion for 
  a new trial nisi, this court will reverse only when the verdict is grossly 
  inadequate or excessive requiring the granting of a new trial absolute.Â  Id.Â  

The trial courtâ€™s decision to deny a 
  motion for new trial absolute is within its discretion and will not be reversed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali 
  Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 9, 466 S.E.2d 727, 731 (1996).Â  When deciding a motion 
  to grant a new trial, the court must look at the testimony and inferences raised 
  in favor of the nonmoving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302-03, 
  536 S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œThe trial court must set aside a verdict 
  only when it is shockingly disproportionate to the injuries suffered and thus 
  indicates that passion, caprice, prejudice, or other considerations not reflected 
  by the evidence affected the amount awarded.â€Â  Id. at 302, 536 S.E.2d 
  at 420.Â  A juryâ€™s determination of damages is entitled to substantial deference 
  by this court.Â  Knoke v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 
  324 S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996).Â  
As stated above, the jury had the right 
  to weigh the evidence and the credibility of the witnesses and determine that 
  not all of the damages Simpkins claimed were proximately caused by the 1999 
  accident.Â  We find the verdict was not grossly inadequate or the result of passion, 
  caprice, prejudice, or some other influence.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial 
  court did not abuse its discretion in denying Simpkinsâ€™ motions for new trial 
  nisi and new trial absolute.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-021
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant. 

Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Legal Counsel 
  Tommy Evans, Jr. and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  William Edward Taylor appeals the 
  revocation of his probation, arguing the trial court erred when it considered 
  his arrest record during the revocation hearing.Â  We affirm. 
  [1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Taylor was sentenced as a habitual traffic offender 
  to five years imprisonment suspended to two years imprisonment and three years 
  probation.Â  During his probationary sentence, a probation arrest warrant was 
  issued charging him with failing to follow his agentâ€™s instructions and advice, 
  failing to report, failing to pay the public defender fund, and failing to pay 
  his supervision fees.Â  Taylor admitted the allegations in the warrant were true.Â  
  In asking for mercy from the court, Taylor said he had â€œpretty much cleaned 
  up [his] act.â€Â  The court told Taylor it had his NCIC report and to be careful 
  not to contradict it.Â  When Taylor later admitted he previously had a drug problem 
  but that he had â€œbeen clean now for awhile, for a couple of years now,â€ the 
  court mentioned Taylorâ€™s arrests in multiple jurisdictions while on probation.Â  
  At the conclusion of the hearing, the court revoked Taylorâ€™s probation in full, 
  reinstating the remainder of his suspended sentence.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Taylor argues the court erred in considering his arrest 
  record in imposing the maximum revocation.Â  We find no error.Â  
Probation is a matter of grace, rather than a right 
  and revocation is a means to enforce the terms of probation.Â  State v. Hamilton, 
  333 S.C. 642, 648, 511 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The decision to revoke 
  probation is addressed to the circuit courtâ€™s discretion.Â  State v. Lee, 
  350 S.C. 125, 129, 564 S.E.2d 372, 374 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  This court will not 
  reverse the circuit courtâ€™s revocation of probation unless the decision was 
  influenced by an error of law, lacked evidentiary support, or constituted an 
  abuse of discretion.Â  Taylor admitted to violating several terms of his probation.Â  
  State v. Knapp, 338 S.C. 541, 543, 526 S.E.2d 741, 742 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  Thus, the revocation clearly has evidentiary support.Â  
Additionally, the courtâ€™s decision does not appear 
  to have been an abuse of discretion or the product of a legal error.Â  Although 
  the court mentioned Taylorâ€™s arrest record, it did not do so until after it 
  had already made the determination on the record that the violations that Taylor 
  readily admitted to were substantial.Â  The court did not mention the arrests 
  when it announced its decision on revocation.Â  Our reading of the record does 
  not indicate the court considered any improper matters in its decision to revoke 
  Taylorâ€™s probationary sentence in full.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed

Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor D. Cleary, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Allen Bullard, all 
  of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kris Kollyns appeals the dismissal 
  of his petition for habeas corpus.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Kollyns, an inmate at McCormick Correctional Institution, 
  filed a petition for habeas corpus in the circuit court seeking the return of 
  20 good time days allegedly taken from him at a South Carolina Department of 
  Corrections minor disciplinary hearing.Â  It is unclear from the petition whether 
  Kollyns actually lost good time credits or was barred from earning them for 
  a period of time.Â  In his petition, Kollyns asserts he appealed the departmentâ€™s 
  ruling to the Administrative Law Judge Division (ALJD), but that the ALJD dismissed 
  his appeal pursuant to an en banc order regarding inmate appeals.Â  In its return, 
  the State moved to dismiss Kollynsâ€™ petition noting, among other things, the 
  only proper inquiry in a habeas corpus action is the legality of the petitionerâ€™s 
  present detention.Â  After a hearing, the circuit court dismissed the petition 
  on the grounds argued in the Stateâ€™s return.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
We first note the circuit court properly dismissed 
  Kollynsâ€™ petition because the relief he sought, the return of good time credits, 
  was outside the scope of an action for habeas corpus.Â  Gibson v. State, 
  329 S.C. 37, 40, 495 S.E.2d 426, 427 (1998) (noting the purpose of habeas corpus 
  is to determine the legality of the petitionerâ€™s present detention and the only 
  relief that can be granted is release from custody). 
On appeal, Kollyns for the first time seeks a remand 
  of his case to the ALJD.Â  He claims the ALJD has jurisdiction over his appeal 
  from the department of corrections pursuant to Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 
  S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (1999).Â  However, because this issue was never raised 
  to the circuit court it is not proper for our review.Â  State v. McKnight, 
  352 S.C. 635, 646, 576 S.E.2d 168, 174 (issue must be raised to and ruled on 
  by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review), cert. denied, 
  124 S. Ct. 101 (2003).Â  
For the reasons set forth above, Kollynsâ€™ 
  appeal is
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.  

 
   [1]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy

  H. Richardson, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Meyers, of Lexington, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Richard Ellisor was indicted 
  of and subsequently pled guilty to committing or attempting a lewd act upon 
  a child under the age of 16.Â  Ellisorâ€™s appellate counsel submitted a petition 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating he has reviewed the record and has concluded 
  Ellisorâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Ellisor did not file a pro se brief 
  with the court.
After a review of the record as required by Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues 
  that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Ellisorâ€™s appeal 
  and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. [1] 
 APPEAL DISMISSED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and CURETON, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1] Â  
    Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, 
    we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 and 220(b)(2), 
    SCACR.
