THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Gina Marlowe McDowell,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kevin L. McDowell,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
James F. Fraley, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-028
Heard December 11, 2003 â€“Filed January 
  16, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
J. Michael Taylor, of Columbia, and Joseph O. Burroughs, 
  Jr., of Conway, for Appellant.
Michael W. Self, of Sumter, and Robert L. Widener, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:       
This 
  is a post-divorce relocation case in which Gina Marlowe McDowell (Mother) remarried 
  and seeks to move to Raleigh, North Carolina with the partiesâ€™ two children.Â  
  The family court denied her relocation request and ordered that if Mother relocated 
  to Raleigh, custody of the children would transfer to Kevin L. McDowell (Father).Â  
  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
The parties were married in 1989 and 
  their two children were born in 1991 and 1993.Â  In 1998, a divorce decree was 
  filed which incorporated and merged into it an agreement resolving child custody, 
  visitation, and support.Â  The agreement designated Mother as the primary custodial 
  parent for the two children. Â Throughout the marriage and subsequent 
  to the divorce, the parties have resided in Conway, South Carolina. 
The agreement specified Fatherâ€™s visitation 
  schedule, which included:Â  1) alternating weekends from Friday at 6:00 p.m. 
  until Monday morning; 2) one weeknight per week; 3) four weeks in the summer; 
  4) splitting Christmas holidays and spring break; 5) alternating Easter, Thanksgiving 
  and Halloweens; and 6) providing Fatherâ€™s Day and Fatherâ€™s birthday visitation 
  to Father.Â  The agreement also provided that the parties believed it is in the 
  best interest of the children for both parents to be actively involved in their 
  lives.Â Â  Finally, the agreement placed no restrictions on relocation.Â  
Motherâ€™s new husband is a member of 
  a band, which is based in Raleigh, North Carolina.Â  She brought this action 
  seeking to modify the custody agreement to allow her to relocate to Raleigh 
  due to her remarriage and because she believes it in the best interest of the 
  children.Â  Father sought to maintain the current visitation arrangements and 
  argued his visitation would be diminished, as would his ability to remain active 
  in the childrenâ€™s activities.Â  Father sought a change of custody and a restraining 
  order prohibiting Mother from relocating with the children. 
A temporary restraining order was issued 
  prohibiting Mother from relocating.Â  Additionally, the order required psychological 
  evaluations of the parties and children, and it appointed a Guardian ad Litem.  

The family court entered its final ruling 
  enjoining Mother from relocating the children from the State of South Carolina.Â  
  The order further provided custody would change to Father if Mother moved to 
  North Carolina.Â  The order also adjusted the amount of child support to be paid 
  by Father.Â  Finally, the order required Mother to pay $5,000.00 towards Fatherâ€™s 
  attorneyâ€™s fees. Â Motherâ€™s motion for reconsideration was denied. 
Mother filed an emergency motion to 
  stay the decision.Â  The family court denied the stay.Â  Mother subsequently filed 
  with this Court a petition for writ of supersedeas, which was also denied.Â  
  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from all equity actions 
  including those from the Family Court, the appellate court has authority to 
  find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of evidence.â€ 
  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  
  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the family 
  courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 
  616, 617 (1981).Â  Similarly, we are not obligated to ignore the fact the family 
  court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their testimony.Â  Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 453, 486 S.E.2d 516, 
  519 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œThis is especially true in cases involving the welfare 
  and best interests of children.â€Â  Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilcox, 
  304 S.C. 90, 93, 403 S.E.2d 142, 144 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Moreover, our broad scope 
  of review does not â€œrelieve the appellant of the burden of convincing this Court 
  that the family court committed error.â€Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 
  523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
DISCUSSION
I.         
Relocation
Mother maintains 
  the family court erred in issuing the restraining order prohibiting her from 
  relocating the children to Raleigh, North Carolina.Â  She contends the court 
  imposed too harsh of a burden on her to prove it was in the best interest of 
  the children to move, and the facts of the case demonstrate it was in their 
  best interest. [1] Â  We disagree, 
  and find the court correctly denied Motherâ€™s request to relocate and conditioned 
  her custody of the children on her remaining in Conway.
â€œ[I]n the absence of a change of circumstances 
  affecting the welfare of the child, â€˜a final decree of divorce awarding custody 
  in accordance with an agreement of the parties is conclusive between them.â€™â€Â  
  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 143, 245 S.E.2d 612, 616 (1978) (quoting 
  Sharpe v. Sharpe, 256 S.C. 517, 521, 183 S.E.2d 325, 327 (1971)). â€œIn 
  order for a court to grant a change of custody based on changed circumstances, 
  the party seeking the change must meet the burden of showing changed circumstances 
  occurring subsequent to the entry of the order in question.â€Â  Hollar v. Hollar, 
  342 S.C. 463, 473, 536 S.E.2d 883, 888 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œA change in circumstances 
  justifying a change in the custody of a child simply means that sufficient facts 
  have been shown to warrant the conclusion that the best interests of the child 
  will be served by the change.â€Â  Skinner, 272 S.C. at 523, 252 S.E.2d 
  at 892-93.Â  â€œ[T]he change of circumstance relied on for a change of custody 
  must be such as would substantially affect the interest and the welfare of the 
  child, not merely the parties, their wishes or convenience.â€Â  Sharpe v. Sharpe, 
  256 S.C. 517, 521, 183 S.E.2d 325, 327 (1971).Â  Remarriage alone is not sufficient 
  to warrant modification of a custody decree.Â  Pitt v. Olds, 333 S.C. 
  478, 481, 511 S.E.2d 60, 61 (1999).
â€œâ€˜The welfare of the child and what is in his/her 
  best interest is the primary, paramount and controlling consideration of the 
  court in all child custody controversies.â€™â€Â  Davis v. Davis, 356 S.C. 
  132, 135, 588 S.E.2d 102, 103-04 (2003) (quoting Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 
  136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978)).Â  â€œCustody decisions are matters left 
  largely to the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Henggeler v. Hanson, 
  333 S.C. 598, 602, 510 S.E.2d 722, 725 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œ[T]he appellate court 
  should be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child 
  custody for that of the trial court.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 
  10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).
In terms of the procedural requirements necessary 
  for a partyâ€™s request for relocation, our Supreme Court has held that there 
  is a presumption in child custody cases against removing children from the state.Â  
  McAlister v. Patterson, 278 S.C. 481, 483, 299 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1982).Â  
  The courts of this state have consistently recognized the decision in McAlister.Â  
  See, e.g., Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 449, 453, 517 S.E.2d 220, 222 
  (Ct. App. 1999); Henggeler v. Hanson, 333 S.C. 598, 604, 510 S.E.2d 722, 
  726 (Ct. App. 1998); VanName v. VanName, 308 S.C. 516, 519, 419 S.E.2d 
  373, 374 (Ct. App. 1992); Eckstein v. Eckstein, 306 S.C. 167, 169, 410 
  S.E.2d 578, 580 (Ct. App. 1991); Sealy v. Sealy, 295 S.C. 281, 284, 368 
  S.E.2d 85, 87 (Ct. App. 1988); Marshall v. Marshall, 282 S.C. 534, 541, 
  320 S.E.2d 44, 48-49 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  A party may rebut this presumption by 
  showing that the move will benefit the child.Â  Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 
  449, 454, 517 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Therefore, â€œthe question of 
  whether relocation will be allowed requires a determination of whether the relocation 
  is in the best interest of the children, the primary consideration in all child 
  custody cases.â€Â  Id.Â  
This Court has discussed the relevant 
  factors a court may consider in making a decision regarding whether to allow 
  relocation.Â  Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 449, 457-58, 517 S.E.2d 220, 224-25 
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In Rice, the parties married and had three children.Â  
  Throughout the marriage, the parties primarily resided in Conway, South Carolina.Â  
  After several separations, the parties separated a final time after approximately 
  five and a half years of marriage.Â  During the separation, but before either 
  party requested temporary relief, Mother and the children moved to Maine in 
  an area that was twenty miles from Motherâ€™s two brothers and her sister.Â  At 
  the conclusion of the divorce proceedings, the family court granted custody 
  of the children to Mother.Â  The court, however, determined that Motherâ€™s move 
  to Maine would jeopardize the childrenâ€™s relationship with Father and that the 
  childrenâ€™s best interest would be served by requiring Mother to return from 
  Maine.Â  The court ordered Mother to return to South Carolina or any other location 
  within 250 miles of Conway as long as Father resided there.Â  
On appeal, this Court considered whether the family 
  court properly required Mother to return to South Carolina or to within 250 
  miles of Conway.Â  In deciding this issue, we recognized that in this state there 
  exists a presumption in child custody cases against removing children from the 
  state.Â  Id. at 453, 517 S.E.2d at 222.Â  We also noted that this presumption 
  might be rebutted by a showing that the move will benefit the child. Id. 
  at 454, 517 S.E.2d at 222.Â  Because South Carolina case law provided limited 
  guidance â€œas to how a court should determine whether an out-of-state move is 
  in the best interest of the children,â€ this Court considered cases from other 
  jurisdictions.Â  Id. at 456, 517 S.E.2d at 224-25.Â  After gleaning certain 
  guiding principles from these cases, we applied the established factors to the 
  facts of the Rice appeal.
This Court found most important that the quality 
  of life for the children would be greatly increased by allowing Mother to relocate 
  to Maine.Â  Id. at 459, 517 S.E.2d at 225.Â  In Maine, Mother would be 
  able to obtain training, find better long-term employment, receive childcare 
  from the state, and qualify for subsidies allowing the family to move into a 
  four-bedroom apartment.Â  Additionally, the children would be moving closer to 
  family, who could help care for the children while Mother was receiving her 
  training.Â  Id.Â  The Court found Motherâ€™s motives were purely to benefit 
  her children and not to frustrate the visitation of Father.Â  Id. at 460, 
  517 S.E.2d at 226.Â  Finally, this Court found that the benefits to the children 
  and Mother must be balanced with the detrimental effect the move would have 
  on Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â  Id. at 461, 517 S.E.2d at 226.Â  This Court stated:Â  
  â€œWhile the Fatherâ€™s relationship with the children is extremely important, it 
  is but one of the factors that goes into the sometimes nebulous best-interest 
  determination.â€Â  Id. at 462, 517 S.E.2d at 227.Â  We concluded the best 
  interest of the children would be served by allowing relocation.
In the instant case, we find the family 
  court properly applied the Rice factors in reaching its decision that 
  the best interest of the children would not be served by allowing the relocation.Â  
  While Motherâ€™s income would increase slightly, there would not be a significant 
  difference.Â  Additionally, Mother attempts to articulate quality of life improvements 
  that would result from a move, including better cultural opportunities, better 
  schools, and better healthcare.Â  The record provides little evidence of any 
  significant upgrade from the familyâ€™s current situation in Horry County if the 
  relocation to Raleigh is allowed.Â  The only major change would be the benefit 
  of being able to live with Motherâ€™s new husband closer to his job.Â  Moreover, 
  the record reflects the children are both performing well in their studies and 
  on standardized tests in their respective Horry County schools. 
Next, we agree with the courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that neither Motherâ€™s nor Fatherâ€™s actions were motivated by an improper purpose.Â  
  Based on our review of the record, we find no evidence that Motherâ€™s request 
  to relocate was intended to frustrate Fatherâ€™s visitation rights.Â  Instead, 
  it stemmed from her desire to live with her new husband near his job.Â  Furthermore, 
  we believe Father provided legitimate reasons for his opposition to the move 
  that were based on his good-faith desire to maintain a relationship with his 
  children.Â  
Any move would come at an expense to 
  the visitation and relationship Father enjoys with his children.Â  While some 
  of his weekday visitation is reduced by his need to work late, he has actively 
  participated in the childrenâ€™s lives.Â  He has attended lunches at school and 
  after-school activities.Â  His ability to participate on a regular basis would 
  be greatly reduced.Â  This detrimental aspect of the relocation was the focus 
  of the determination by the Guardian ad Litem that relocation was not in the 
  childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  Fatherâ€™s participation in many areas of the childrenâ€™s 
  lives is too meaningful to allow the move simply on the basis of Motherâ€™s remarriage.Â  
  Furthermore, a move would also limit the childrenâ€™s contact with the extended 
  family members who reside in the Conway area. Â Significantly, there is 
  no such support system in terms of extended family in North Carolina.Â  
In her argument on this issue, 
  Mother focuses upon Fatherâ€™s sexual history and activities.Â Â  She expresses 
  concern that he has admitted in the past to being a sex addict.Â  However, Dr. 
  Saylor, the court-appointed psychologist, noted there was nothing to prevent 
  Father from being a qualified parent. Â Additionally, Mother believed 
  he was a good Father and offered additional time in the summer to compensate 
  him for the time lost during the school year.Â  As the Guardian concluded, it 
  is hard to believe Mother would offer additional time for the children to spend 
  with Father if his behavior was seen as a detriment to their development. 
Additionally, in assessing the best 
  interest of the children, we have specifically considered the opinions of the 
  Guardian and Dr. Saylor with regard to relocation.Â  The Guardian recommended 
  that the children not be allowed to relocate.Â  He felt it to be in the childrenâ€™s 
  best interest to remain in Horry County under the current custodial and visitation 
  arrangement.Â  Dr. Saylor seemed to suggest that the children could benefit from 
  the move and the move would be â€œcompatible with their needs and best interest.â€Â  
  However, when questioned further, Dr. Saylor did not give a conclusive opinion 
  as to whether it would in fact be in the childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  He believed 
  that such a determination could not be done â€œjust from a psychological evaluation.â€ 
  Â Instead, he agreed with the assessment that there was â€œno indication 
  that relocation would be contrary to the childrenâ€™s best interest.â€Â  He 
  also acknowledged that there would be no long-term negative impact on the children 
  if they moved with Mother. 
We recognize that â€œa determination of the best 
  interest of the children is an inherently case-specific and fact-specific inquiry.â€Â  
  Rice, 335 S.C. at 458, 517 S.E.2d at 225; see Davenport v. 
  Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975) (In child custody 
  cases, â€œthe totality of circumstances peculiar to each case constitutes the 
  only scale upon which the ultimate decision can be weighed.â€).Â  As the family 
  court found, the facts of this case weigh strongly in favor of maintaining the 
  current custody and visitation arrangements with both parents residing in Horry 
  County. Â Motherâ€™s interest in relocating is primarily based upon her remarriage, 
  and the relocation does not have the effect of greatly improving the childrenâ€™s 
  quality of life.Â  Under the facts of this case, we find the best interest of 
  the children is served by living in close proximity to Father.Â  See Pitt 
  v. Olds, 333 S.C. 478, 481-82, 511 S.E.2d 60, 62 (1999) (holding remarriage 
  alone was insufficient to modify existing decree under which Mother, as custodial 
  parent, was required to remain in South Carolina); McAlister, 278 S.C. 
  at 483-84, 299 S.E.2d at 323 (affirming family courtâ€™s denial of Motherâ€™s request 
  to move where childâ€™s best interest and welfare would best be served by remaining 
  in South Carolina near Father, friends, and other relatives).Â  
Accordingly, we find Mother has not rebutted the 
  long-established presumption against removing the children from South Carolina.Â  
  Although Mother disagrees with this presumption, we have no authority to overrule 
  or modify the decision in McAlister.Â  See Bain v. Self Memâ€™l 
  Hosp., 281 S.C. 138, 141, 314 S.E.2d 603, 605 (Ct. App. 1984), overruled 
  on other grounds by McCall v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 
  (1985). (â€œWhere the law has been recently addressed by our Supreme Court and 
  is unmistakably clear, this court has no authority to change it.â€); Shea 
  v. State Depâ€™t of Mental Retardation, 279 S.C. 604, 608, 310 S.E.2d 819, 
  821 (Ct. App. 1983) (â€œThe maintenance of a harmonious body of decisional law 
  is essential to the efficient administration of justice.Â  Therefore, if the 
  judicial system is to operate efficiently, this court must be bound by decisions 
  of the Supreme Court.â€). Â Therefore, the family courtâ€™s order regarding relocation 
  and custody is affirmed.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Child Support 
  Calculation
Mother asserts the family court erred 
  in considering $49.00 in payment for the childrenâ€™s health insurance when calculating 
  the child support owed by Father.Â  Father agrees that he does not separately 
  pay for the childrenâ€™s insurance because it is included in his union payments 
  for his own insurance.Â  
In considering the insurance, the court concluded 
  Father owed $681.00 in support. As such, we find the court incorrectly calculated 
  the amount of child support owed to Mother.Â  The correct amount should be $700.26 
  per month in child support.Â  The family courtâ€™s order is modified to the extent 
  that child support is set at $700.26 per month, with the same provisions for 
  payment as articulated in the trial courtâ€™s order.
III.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Mother contends the family court erred 
  in requiring her to pay $5,000.00 of Fatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  She maintains 
  that this was a close case and that she also received beneficial results in 
  the modified child support.Â  We find the court properly assessed a portion of 
  Fatherâ€™s fees to Mother.
In Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 
  S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991), our Supreme Court established the factors for 
  the family court to consider in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court 
  is to consider:Â  â€œ(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the 
  time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; 
  (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; (6) customary 
  legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Id. at 161, 403 S.E.2d at 315.Â  
In the instant case, the court expressly 
  considered the Glasscock factors.Â  While child support was an issue, 
  there is little doubt that the issue of Motherâ€™s attempt to relocate was the 
  predominant reason for litigation.Â  The court found that Father obtained beneficial 
  results in the main issue tried before the court.Â  Additionally, the court found 
  the hourly rate and the time spent on the case by Fatherâ€™s counsel was reasonable 
  and consistent with rates charged in the area for similar services.Â  As it is 
  clear the court considered the relevant factors, and those factors favor Father, 
  we affirm the award of $5,000.00 attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
We find the family court properly found 
  the relocation was not in the best interest of the children.Â  As such, the court 
  properly denied Motherâ€™s request to relocate and conditioned her custody of 
  the children on her remaining in Conway.Â  We conclude the courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees was proper.Â  We modify the courtâ€™s award of child support to correct for 
  the error in calculation.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  In her brief, Mother raises three separate arguments regarding 
    the relocation issue.Â  In the interest of clarity, we have consolidated these 
    arguments under one heading.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
City of Myrtle Beach,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Dept. of Transportation, and
Topp, Inc. d/b/a Mr. Sub,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-029
Heard November 6, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  16, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles B. Jordan, Jr., of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Howell V. Bellamy, Jr. and Rob Shelton, both of Myrtle Beach; 
  John B. McCutcheon, Jr., Mary Ruth Baxter and Arrigo P. Carotti, all of Conway; 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this declaratory judgment 
  action, the master-in-equity ruled the South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (SCDOT) was authorized by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-190(E) (Supp. 2002) of the 
  Highway Advertising Control Act to relocate a non-conforming sign owned by Topp, 
  Inc, d/b/a Mr. Sub, (Mr. Sub), which absent the statute would lose its grandfathered 
  status under the City of Myrtle Beachâ€™s zoning ordinances upon relocation. Â The 
  City appeals, arguing SCDOT failed to fully comply with section 57-25-190(E).Â  
  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Mr. Sub is a restaurant located where 
  Broadway and U.S. Highway 17 intersect, in the vicinity of 10th Avenue 
  North in Myrtle Beach.Â  Mr. Sub constructed a freestanding on-site outdoor advertising 
  sign prior to the City passing an ordinance governing the size and placement 
  of outdoor advertising signs.Â  Mr. Subâ€™s sign became a grandfathered nonconforming 
  use because its height and area are greater than the ordinance allows.Â  According 
  to the ordinance, if the sign is relocated, it loses its grandfathered status.Â  

As part of a highway improvement project to widen 
  and realign 10th Avenue North, SCDOT condemned the portion of Mr. 
  Subâ€™s property that contained the sign and proposed to move the sign.Â  The City 
  filed a declaratory judgment action seeking a ruling that SCDOT did not have 
  the authority to move the sign.Â  It asserted the sign would lose its grandfathered 
  status if moved and SCDOT did not have the authority to violate the Cityâ€™s zoning 
  ordinances.Â  It also sought an injunction prohibiting SCDOT from relocating 
  the sign.Â  SCDOT answered asserting it had statutory authority to relocate the 
  sign notwithstanding the Cityâ€™s ordinance.Â  It asked the City be enjoined from 
  interfering with its relocation of the sign.Â  The circuit court granted SCDOTâ€™s 
  motion enjoining the City from enforcing its ordinances and referred the case 
  to the master-in-equity.Â  SCDOT relocated the sign eight feet back from its 
  original location.Â  
After a hearing on the merits, the master 
  found that the Highway Advertising Control Act provides SCDOT with express authority 
  to relocate applicable signs, such as the Mr. Sub sign, regardless of any municipal 
  ordinance to the contrary.Â  He held SCDOT fully complied with section 57-25-190(E) 
  in its relocation of the sign.Â  Accordingly, he enjoined the City from interfering 
  with SCDOTâ€™s relocation of the sign.Â  In response to the Cityâ€™s motion to alter 
  or amend, the master amended his order to state, â€œSCDOTâ€™s relocation of the 
  sign is in violation of the Cityâ€™s zoning/sign ordinance.â€Â  He denied the remainder 
  of the motion. [1] Â  The City appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen an appeal involves stipulated or 
  undisputed facts, an appellate court is free to review whether the trial court 
  properly applied the law to those facts.â€Â  WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 
  342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000).Â  A dispute regarding the interpretation 
  of a statute is a matter of law for the court.Â  Stewart v. Richland Memâ€™l 
  Hosp., 350 S.C. 589, 593, 567 S.E.2d 510, 512 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The City argues the master erred in finding 
  S.C. Code Ann. 57-25-190(E) (Supp. 2002) gave SCDOT authority to move Mr. Subâ€™s 
  nonconforming sign.Â  We disagree.Â  
As part of the Highway Advertising Control Act, 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-110 et seq. (1991 & Supp. 2002) the general 
  assembly enacted section 57-25-190(E), which provides:

Notwithstanding a county or municipal zoning plan, ordinance, 
  or resolution, outdoor advertising signs conforming to [the Highway Advertising 
  Control Act] affected by state highway projects may be relocated . . . to a 
  position which is perpendicular to the right of way of the original sign site, 
  or may be altered so that no portion of the sign overhangs the right of way.

The cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.Â  Mid-State Auto 
  Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 
  (1996).Â  The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning 
  without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand its operation.Â  
  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 
  843, 846 (1992).Â Â  The language of the statute must also be read in a sense 
  which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  
  Id.Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair 
  interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  
  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 
  503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he construction of a statute by 
  the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful 
  consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.â€ Dunton 
  v. South Carolina Bd. of Examiners in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 
  S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987).Â  
The first subsections of S.C. Code Ann. 57-25-190 (Supp. 
  2002) concern the requirement that SCDOT provide landowners with compensation 
  for the removal of outdoor advertising signs.Â  Subsection (E) provides a mechanism 
  for SCDOT to avoid paying compensation by relocating the sign, even when the 
  relocation would violate local ordinances.Â  Section 57-25-190(E) clearly contemplates 
  allowing the movement of a sign when SCDOT commences road projects that require 
  its removal.Â  
The City argues SCDOT was not in strict compliance 
  with the statute and therefore it could not relocate the sign in violation of 
  the Cityâ€™s ordinances.Â  It asserts that under its interpretation of the statute, 
  the line formed by connecting the two points represented by the original sign 
  site and the relocated position must be perpendicular to the right of way.Â  
  We find this strained interpretation does not comport with the purpose of the 
  statute. 
Rather, we agree with SCDOT engineer, 
  Michael Dennis, who testified he considers the face of the sign in determining 
  whether the sign is perpendicular.Â  The trial courtâ€™s interpretation of the 
  statute also focused on the location of the face of the sign.Â  Relocating the 
  sign where the signâ€™s face is perpendicular to same right of way of its original 
  site enables the same traffic to view the sign.Â  Thus, the owner of the sign 
  receives the same benefit as it did from the signâ€™s original location, eliminating 
  the need for SCDOT to provide the owner with compensation.Â  
Dennis testified that before the relocation, 
  the Mr. Sub signâ€™s face was perpendicular to Highway 17.Â  After the relocation, 
  the signâ€™s face was still perpendicular to Highway 17.Â  We agree with the trial 
  court that SCDOT fully complied with all statutory provisions concerning the 
  relocation of the Mr. Sub sign.Â  Thus, SCDOT has the right and authority to 
  relocate the Mr. Sub sign to its present location.Â  
AFFIRMED. 2
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  The master also denied Mr. Subâ€™s request for 
    attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  

 
   
    [2] Â Â  In its Respondentâ€™s brief, Mr. Sub states that its motion for reconsideration 
    of its petitions for fees and costs has been stayed pending this appeal.Â  
    Mr. Sub then argues fees and costs are warranted under the circumstances and 
    continue to accrue during this appeal.Â  We do not address this contention 
    as it is not properly before this court.Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jerry Meehan,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mary Elizabeth Meehan, Paul Embler, Richard J. Hurst, William L. Hendrix, 
        Jr., Betty H. Deal, Robert K. Hendrix, Virginia H. McEntyre, First Baptist 
        Church of Pendleton, First Baptist Church of Twin Falls, Idaho, First 
        Baptist Church of Anderson, J. Louie Hendrix, Diane Hendrix, F. Ben Hendrix, 
        Jr., Barbara E. Beach, of Whom, J. Louie Hendrix, Paul Embler and Barbara 
        Beach are,        Respondents,
In the matter of:Â  Sammie Bruce, Deceased.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-030
Heard November 6, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  16, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Calhoun Pruitt, Jr., of Anderson, for Appellant.
Michael F. Mullinax, of Anderson, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case involves whether 
  a conformed copy of a will should be admitted to probate.Â  Jerry Meehan as Personal 
  Representative of the estate of Sammie Bruce, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s reversal 
  of the probate courtâ€™s order, which accepted the conformed copy of the will 
  for probate.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Bruce died on July 8, 1999 from cancer after a period 
  of hospitalization and recuperative care at National Healthcare between mid-April, 
  1999 and her death.Â  During this time period she appointed her great-nephew 
  Paul Embler as power of attorney to handle her affairs.Â  As part of his duties, 
  Mr. Embler secured Bruceâ€™s residence by changing the locks, handled her finances, 
  and made specific gifts at her request.Â  Repeatedly, Embler asked Bruce about 
  updating her â€œpaperworkâ€ and about the location of her â€œpaperwork.â€Â  She told 
  him that her â€œimportant papers were in a dresser drawer.â€Â  
Before Bruceâ€™s death, Mr. Embler went with his 
  aunt Ella Hendrix to the residence to search for the â€œimportant papers.â€Â  They 
  found a dresser drawer with various documents in it that they then removed.Â  
  One of the documents that appeared to Mr. Embler to be a will was opened and 
  read by him.Â  It stated that Meehan, another great-nephew of Bruce, was named 
  as Personal Representative of Bruceâ€™s estate.Â  At the funeral, Mr. Embler gave 
  the documents to Meehan.Â  The documents included a conformed copy of Bruceâ€™s 
  will and not an original executed will.
Meehan petitioned the probate court for formal 
  testacy and appointment as Personal Representative.Â  All testate heirs of Bruceâ€™s 
  estate and intestate heirs not listed as beneficiaries under the will were listed 
  as Respondents.Â  The probate court admitted the conformed copy of the will to 
  probate. The Probate Court Judge granted formal testacy and appointed Meehan 
  as Personal Representative of the estate.
The Respondents appealed the probate court findings 
  to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court found that there was no clear and convincing 
  evidence in the record to overcome the presumption that the original will had 
  been destroyed.Â  The court found that the will was not entitled to probate and 
  Bruceâ€™s estate must be administered as an intestate estate.Â  The circuit court 
  reversed and remanded the probate courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Meehan appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appeal from the probate court to the 
  circuit court regarding the validity of a will is a matter of law.Â  Golini 
  v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 338, 482 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In an 
  action at law decided in the probate court, the circuit court may not disturb 
  the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless there is no evidence to support 
  them.Â  Matter of Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993).Â  
  On appeal, this court will examine the record to see if there is any evidence 
  to reasonably support the factual findings of the probate court.Â  Dean v. 
  Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 259, 437 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct.App. 1993).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Meehan argues the circuit court erred 
  when it reversed the probate court because the evidence in the record supported 
  the probate courtâ€™s finding that Bruce did not intend to revoke her will.Â  We 
  disagree.
â€œWhen the testator takes possession of 
  his will and it cannot be found at his death, the law presumes that the testator 
  destroyed the will animo revocandi.â€ Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 
  333, 340, 482 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In arguing the presumption of 
  revocation does not apply, Meehan relies on Golini, asserting that the 
  facts of that case and the present one are similar.Â  In Giolini, the 
  probate court found that the will had not been revoked because the will had 
  been returned to the attorneyâ€™s office.Â  The attorneyâ€™s usual procedure was 
  to keep some executed wills for clients in his lock-box.Â  The probate court 
  held that as the testator never had possession of the will, the presumption 
  of revocation never arose.Â  It admitted a conformed copy of the will to probate.Â  
  The probate courtâ€™s findings were affirmed by the circuit court and this court.Â  
  We find Golini factually distinguishable from this case because the attorney 
  here did not take possession of Bruceâ€™s will after execution.
Sammie Bruce executed her will and took possession 
  of it on October 7, 1988.Â  Richard Ruele, the attorney who prepared a will for 
  Bruce on October 7, 1988, stated that it was routine practice for him at that 
  time to prepare an original will for his clients as well as a conformed copy.Â  
  He stated that Bruce would have been given the only original will as well as 
  a conformed copy such as the one under discussion here.Â  We find the presumption 
  of revocation does arise in the present case.
This presumption, however, is a presumption of 
  fact and can be rebutted.Â  Bauskett v. Keitt, 22 S.C. 187, 191 (1885). 
  The burden of rebutting the presumption with clear and convincing evidence belongs 
  to the proponent of the will.Â  Estate of Mason v. Mason, 289 S.C.273, 
  277, 346 S.E.2d 28, 31 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  The presumption of fact must be rebutted 
  by showing evidence â€œthat the will existed at the time of his [the testatorâ€™s] 
  death, was lost subsequent thereto, or had been destroyed by another without 
  authority to do so.â€Â  Lowe v. Fickling, 207 S.C. 442, 447, 36 S.E.2d 
  293, 295.
Sammie Bruce had the copy of the will in her possession 
  from its execution in 1988 until she was hospitalized in 1999.Â  No original 
  will was found at her death.Â  In the drawer where Bruce said her important papers 
  were kept, there was no original will.Â  There were, however, only copies of 
  the 1988 will and a copy of a previous will.Â  Meehan produced no evidence, that 
  the original will was lost after Bruceâ€™s death.Â  Furthermore there was no evidence 
  presented of a third party destroying the will without her knowledge.Â  The probate 
  court speculated on the possibility that the decedentâ€™s will may have been destroyed 
  by a third party while Bruce was in the hospital.Â  However, the law does not 
  presume illegal acts.Â  Lowe v. Fickling, 207 S.C. 442, 447, 36 S.E.2d 
  293, 295.Â  
Reviewing the record, we find that Meehan did not 
  succeed in rebutting the presumption that Sammie Bruce destroyed the will by 
  clear and convincing evidence.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court was correct 
  when it determined the probate court erred in admitting the copy of the will 
  to probate. [1] Â  
 AFFIRMED
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  The respondents contend the probate court erred 
    when it decided to admit Emblerâ€™s testimony because the testimony violated 
    the Dead Manâ€™s Statute. S.C. Code Ann. Â§19-11-20 (Supp. 2002).Â  We need not 
    address this issue because even if the evidence was not properly admitted 
    the record still fails to rebut the presumption that Bruce revoked her will.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Wedgefield Plantation Association,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cindy M. Chavis and Charles J. Chavis,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
David J. Mills, Special Referee, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004- UP-033
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert J. Moran, of Murrells Inlet, for Appellant. 
Jack M. Scoville, Jr., of Georgetown, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Wedgefield Plantation Association sued 
  homeowners Cindy M. and Charles J. Chavis to enforce a provision of a restrictive 
  covenant requiring pre-approval by the Associationâ€™s Architectural Review Committee 
  of various structures on their property.Â  The referee ruled the Chavises were 
  in violation of the covenant and ordered the barriers removed, but denied the 
  Associationâ€™s request for costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The Association appeals 
  this one issue.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Equity Development Corporation ("EDCâ€), the original 
  developer, established Wedgefield Plantation as a gated community in the early 
  1970s.Â  Title to each of the single family lots was conveyed by indenture deed 
  which containing twenty-five specific restrictions and covenants.Â  Covenant 
  1 requires approval from EDC prior to the erection of any structure on a lot.Â  
  EDC also organized the Association at the beginning of the project, and all 
  property owners were required to join pursuant to covenant 10. Â The indenture 
  deed also contained a number of provisions granting authority to EDC to enforce 
  the restrictions.Â  The indenture deed contained no provision for recovery of 
  costs and attorneyâ€™s fees. 
The Chavises purchased their home in 1999 by deed 
  that explicitly referenced the indenture deed.Â  At some point they installed 
  barriers at either end of their drive without seeking approval from the Associationâ€™s 
  Architectural Review Committee.Â  Because EDC went bankrupt and has been defunct 
  for many years, this action to enforce the covenants and restrictions was brought 
  by the Association to enforce covenant 1 of the indenture deed.Â  The referee 
  found the Chavises were in violation of the restrictions, but denied the Associationâ€™s 
  request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  In denying the request, the referee 
  noted the indenture deed and not the by-laws constituted the contract between 
  the parties.Â  The referee also held that the right to recover attorneyâ€™s fees 
  was controlled by the indenture deed, it contained no such provision, and there 
  had been no amendment consented to by the parties to include such a provision.Â  
  The Association appeals the refereeâ€™s denial of costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
As a threshold issue, a question was raised at 
  the hearing as to the authority of the Association to enforce the restrictions 
  because the recorded covenants and restrictions only specifically refer to EDC 
  as having that authority.Â  However, there has been no appeal from the refereeâ€™s 
  ruling that the Association has standing and the authority to enforce the provisions 
  of the restrictions in the same fashion that EDC could have had EDC still been 
  in existence.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, LP v. Deloitte & Touche, 
  327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (holding an unappealed ruling 
  is the law of the case and cannot be later challenged).Â Â Â  
The Association further argues that its by-laws 
  are enforceable as a contract between the Association and its members and among 
  its members and, therefore, provisions within the by-laws authorizing costs 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees should be given effect.Â  We disagree.
It is well established that "[a]ttorneyâ€™s fees 
  are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.â€Â  Dowaliby 
  v. Chambless, 344 S.C. 558, 544 S.E.2d 646, 647-648 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting 
  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 307, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 (1997)); see 
  also Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 
  660 (1993) ("The general rule is that attorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless 
  authorized by contract or statute.â€). 
The referee held that the Association succeeded 
  to the rights of EDC and had standing to enforce the covenants as its assign.Â  
  McLeod v. Baptiste, 315 S.C. 246, 433 S.E.2d 834, 835 (1993) ("[A] person 
  seeking to enforce a covenant must be benefited by that actâ€). Â However, that 
  enforcement authority was limited to the powers reserved to EDC as outlined 
  in the indenture deed.Â  At common law, an assigneeâ€™s rights and powers can be 
  no greater than those of his assignor.Â  Rosemond v. Campbell, 288 S.C. 
  516, 523, 343 S.E.2d 641, 645 (Ct. App. 1986) (citing Dixie Wood Preserving 
  Co. v. Albert Gersten & Associates, 244 S.C. 57, 135 S.E.2d 368 (1964)).Â  
  Here, the original grantorâ€™s authority was derived from the indenture deed referenced 
  in each property ownerâ€™s deed.Â  The indenture deed was the contract between 
  the homeowners and EDC, and makes no mention of any right to an award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs.Â  Accordingly, the original grantor could not have collected 
  fees and costs and therefore neither may the Association.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Sherman Woodson and Mary Ann 
  Woodson appeal from a family court order denying their request for court-ordered

  to be unfit by clear and convincing evidence, or there must be evidence of compelling 
  circumstances).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD and KITTRIDGE, JJ., concur.

    to Rule 215, SCACR.

Jessica Forelifer and Christopher Ashton Boyer, and Caitlyn Boyer, DOB

of whom Christopher Ashton Boyer is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-035
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert N. Hill, of Newberry, for Appellant. 
Daniel W. Luginbill, of Bamberg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher Boyer appeals the 
  termination of his parental rights to his minor child born July 21, 1999.Â  The 
  family court found that Boyer had failed to support, visit, or contact the child.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3), (4), and (8) (Supp. 2002).Â  The family court 
  also found it to be in the childâ€™s best interests to terminate Boyerâ€™s parental 
  rights.Â  
Pursuant to Ex parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 
  354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), Boyerâ€™s counsel attached to the record of the family 
  court proceedings an affidavit stating his belief that the appeal lacks merit.Â  
  Boyer did not file a pro se response to counselâ€™s affidavit.
Upon reviewing the record and the family courtâ€™s determination 
  in its entirety, we find no meritorious issues warranting briefing.Â  Accordingly, 
  the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jonathan Toney, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-038
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 20, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Patrick McFadden Killen, of Sumter, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs Jr., all of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â  Jonathan Toney appeals his 
  assault and battery conviction, arguing that the trial judge erred by declining 
  to continue the trial and by allowing into evidence a picture depicting an injury 
  to the victimâ€™s head.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In January 2002, a Sumter county jury 
  convicted Defendant Jonathan Toney of assault and battery with intent to kill. 
  The indictment was based on events that took place in February 2001. On January 
  22, 2002, the day the trial was to start, Toney sought a continuance, arguing 
  that Toney had not received some key evidence from the prosecution in a timely 
  manner. The trial had been continued at least once before at Toneyâ€™s request, 
  but Toney wanted more time for his expert to scrutinize a SLED report Toney 
  reviewed on January 8. That report showed that the DNA retrieved from the alleged 
  crime weapon was inconclusive because of the insufficient quantity. Toney also 
  wanted more time for an "Evidence Processing Reportâ€ he received on January 
  18. That report had apparently been completed as early as August 2000 and listed 
  some crime-related items, including swabs from a tire iron, clothing belonging 
  to Toney, and a pair of gray tennis shoes. 
The prosecution responded that Toneyâ€™s attorney 
  was already aware of those items, and that, at any rate, the state had either 
  already conducted some tests that yielded no results or had decided not to test 
  the items. The prosecutor declared, "every [test] that is going to be done has 
  been done.â€ The state also argued that Toney and his expert had been told to 
  contact SLED directly if they wanted more details about the evidence. The judge 
  denied the motion to continue the trial, ruling that "the defense has been afforded 
  sufficient time to analyze, to evaluate, and to be ready for trial.â€ 
Additionally, the judge overruled Toneyâ€™s objection 
  to stateâ€™s exhibit #36, a picture depicting an injury to the victimâ€™s head. 
  The judge allowed the picture, finding that "the probative value is not outweighed 
  by the prejudicial effect.â€ Toney appeals both rulings.
ISSUES

  (1)   Â Did the trial court abuse its 
  discretion in denying Toneyâ€™s motion for continuance?
  (2)   Did the trial court abuse its 
  discretion in allowing stateâ€™s exhibit #36?

ANALYSIS
"It is well-settled in South Carolina 
  that a trial court's denial of a motion for continuance â€˜will not be disturbed 
  absent a clear abuse of discretion.â€™â€ State v. McKennedy, 348 S.C. 270, 
  280, 559 S.E.2d 850, 855 (2002) (citing State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 
  459, 469 S.E.2d 49, 51 (1996)). Moreover, reversals are granted very rarely. 
  Id. Appellate courts have "repeatedly upheld denials of motions for continuances 
  where there is no showing that any other evidence on behalf of the defendant 
  could have been introduced, or that any other points could have been raised, 
  if more time had been granted to prepare for trial.â€ Id.
Here, the trial judge held a hearing and ascertained 
  the arguments of both parties. He specifically asked counsel for Toney if in 
  fact he had had a chance to review the evidence at SLED â€“ counsel responded 
  that he had. The trial judge asked whether Toneyâ€™s expert needed more time to 
  conduct his own testing â€“ counsel responded "I donâ€™t know that â€¦ he necessarily 
  needs more time to evaluate any additional documentation that is provided.â€ 
  The trial judge asked whether the trial had been continued before â€“ counsel 
  said yes. What is more, counsel admitted that the state had "been very candid 
  with providing an open-file policy.â€ Counsel provided no indication that the 
  continuance would provide additional exculpatory evidence. The judge then made 
  his ruling "based on all the information presented.â€ The judge clearly did not 
  abuse his discretion.
Toneyâ€™s second objection is equally meritless. 
  "The relevancy, materiality, and admissibility of photographs as evidence are 
  matters left to the sound discretion of the trial court. State v. Johnson, 
  338 S.C.114, 122, 525 S.E.2d 519, 523 (2000) (citing State v. Kornahrens, 
  290 S.C.281, 288, 350 S.E.2d 180, 185 (1986). "However, photographs calculated 
  to arouse the sympathy or prejudice of the jury should be excluded if they are 
  irrelevant or unnecessary to the issues at trial.â€ Id. (citing State 
  v. Middleton, 288 S.C. 21, 24, 339 S.E.2d 692, 693 (1986)).Â  
The state argued that the photograph was relevant, 
  since it showed an injury on top of the victimâ€™s head, corroborating her testimony 
  that she was kneeling when Toney struck her. The trial judge ruled that the 
  photograph was relevant and that its prejudicial effect was less than its probative 
  value. We cannot say that the judge abused his discretion.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, J.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        SPD Investment Company, LLC, a South Carolina Limited Liability Company,       
          Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        The County of Charleston, a body politic, and TransAm Financial Group 
          d/b/a Advantage 99 TD,        Defendants,
        of whom The County of Charleston, a body politic is the       
          Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-039
  Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Benjamin Goldberg, of Charleston, for Appellant. 
        Bernard Eugene Ferrara, Jr., and Joseph Dawson, III, both 
          of N. Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  SPD Investment Company, LLC, 
  sued the County of Charleston seeking the return of money it spent to redeem 
  a property sold at a tax sale that was later deemed void.Â  The master granted 
  the Countyâ€™s motions for summary judgment.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, 
  and remand. 
BACKGROUND

  SPD was formed in 1997.Â  SPDâ€™s organizing documents listed Robert 
    Shuman and Sunbelt Business Brokers Network, Inc. as its members and Shuman 
    as its manager.Â  SPDâ€™s place of business was listed as 2 Amherst Street in 
    Charleston, property the corporation purchased simultaneously with its formation.Â  
    The deed to the property on 2 Amherst Street stated the granteeâ€™s address 
    as 42 Savage Street in Charleston, which was Shumanâ€™s personal residence.Â  
    In July 1998, Shuman left SPD and transferred his ownership interest in SPD 
    to Sunbelt.Â  SPD filed amended organizing documents in which it continued 
    to show 2 Amherst Street as its place of business.Â  
  The 1998 property taxes were not paid for 2 Amherst Street.Â  In 
    April 1999, the delinquent tax collector for Charleston County mailed an execution 
    notice to Shumanâ€™s residence, notifying SPD that the 1998 taxes were past 
    due.Â  Shuman had moved to Boston and the execution notice was returned to 
    the delinquent tax collector marked either "Forwarding Time Expired, Return 
    to Senderâ€ or "Forwarding Address Expired, Return to Sender.â€Â  Pursuant to 
    statute, the delinquent tax collector mailed a second notice by certified 
    restricted delivery to Shumanâ€™s residence.Â  That notice informed SPD the 1998 
    property taxes must be paid by October 1, 1999 to avoid the tax sale scheduled 
    for October 4, 1999.Â  Shumanâ€™s wife signed the return receipt.Â  
  The Amherst Street property was sold to TransAm Financial Group 
    for $300,000 at a tax sale.Â  SPD learned the property was sold after the tax 
    sale.Â  SPDâ€™s attorney communicated with the County, contending the tax sale 
    was void because SPD had not received notice.Â  The County refused to void 
    the tax sale and SPD paid $43,413.47, of which $36,000 was interest, to redeem 
    the property.Â  SPD paid this amount under protest.Â  
  SPD filed suit against the County alleging the tax sale was void 
    because the County failed to give SPD proper notice, and sought the return 
    of the money it spent to redeem the property.Â  SPD also asked for interest 
    it paid to borrow the money necessary to redeem the property.Â  The complaint 
    was amended to include TransAm and TransAm filed a cross-claim against the 
    County seeking payment of the interest SPD paid to redeem the property.Â  SPD 
    moved for summary judgment on its cause of action to declare the tax sale 
    void and obtain the return of the redemption money it paid.Â  The County filed 
    summary judgment motions on both of SPDâ€™s causes of action.Â  
  After a hearing on the motions, the master denied SPDâ€™s motion and 
    granted the County summary judgment on both of SPDâ€™s causes of action.Â  In 
    his original order, the master partially based granting the Countyâ€™s motions 
    on mootness.Â  After receiving SPDâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the master 
    issued an amended order deleting mootness as a ground supporting his decision 
    to grant the Countyâ€™s motions but still found the grant of summary judgment 
    proper.Â  SPD appeals.Â  
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of 
    material fact and the moving party is entitled to summary judgment as a matter 
    of law.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 462, 560 S.E.2d 
    606, 610 (2002).Â  When determining whether triable issues of fact exist, all 
    evidence and reasonable inferences drawn from the evidence are viewed in the 
    light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 
    S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  An appellate court uses the same standard 
    applied by the trial court when reviewing the grant of summary judgment.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 451 n.5, 548 S.E.2d 868, 873-74 n.5 
    (2001).Â  If the facts and the inferences indicate triable issues exist, those 
    issues must be presented to the jury.Â  Worsley Cos. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 
    339 S.C. 51, 55, 528 S.E.2d 657, 660 (2000). 


  LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.Â  Return of Redemption Money
  SPD argues the master erred when he granted the County summary judgment 
    on its cause of action seeking return of the money it spent to redeem 2 Amherst 
    Street because the tax sale was void and it was entitled to a return of the 
    money.Â  We agree that summary judgment on this claim was improper.

The masterâ€™s order found for the purposes of the 
  summary judgment motions that the tax sale was void "because the delinquent 
  tax collector did not exercise due diligence in attempting to obtain a better 
  address for SPD after it received the April 1, 1999 execution notice back from 
  the Postal Service with notice that the address was no longer valid.â€Â  Because 
  the County has not appealed this ruling, it is the law of the case.Â  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 
  241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (holding an unappealed ruling is the law of 
  the case and cannot later be challenged).Â  
SPDâ€™s claim for a return of the money 
  it used to redeem property sold at a void tax sale presents a novel legal issue.Â  
  Our courts have never addressed what entity is responsible when a taxpayer redeems 
  property that was sold at a tax sale that is later deemed void.Â  Although summary 
  judgment is not inappropriate merely because of the novelty of the legal issue 
  involved, it is improper where, as here, "further inquiry into the facts is 
  desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund 
  L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 320 S.C. 143, 153, 463 S.E.2d 618, 
  624 (Ct. App. 1995), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 327 S.C. 238, 489 
  S.E.2d 476 (1997).Â  Thus we reverse the grant of summary judgment on this claim 
  and remand so that the facts and legal theories may be fully developed.Â  
II.Â  Return of Interest on Money Borrowed 
  to Redeem

  SPD argues the master erred in granting the County summary judgment 
    on its cause of action for interest it paid on money borrowed to redeem the 
    property from the County.Â  We disagree.
  This court addressed a similar situation in H & K Specialists 
    v. Brannen, 340 S.C. 585, 532 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In H & 
    K, the master found a tax sale void after the statutory redemption period 
    expired because the county failed to provide sufficient notice of the tax 
    sale to the taxpayer.Â  The county sent the taxpayers a new deed but did not 
    refund the purchase price plus statutory interest to H & K, the successful 
    tax sale bidder.Â  Instead, the county mistakenly sent the money to the taxpayer.Â  
    H & K sued the county seeking return of the purchase price and statutory 
    interest.Â  Id. at 586, 87, 532 S.E.2d at 618-19.Â  The county asserted 
    section 15-78-60(11) as a defense.Â  Section 15-78-60(11) provides:Â  a "governmental 
    entity is not liable for a loss resulting from:Â  (11) assessment or collection 
    of taxes or special assessments or enforcement of tax laws.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 15-78-60(11) (Supp. 2003).Â  This court rejected the countyâ€™s argument stating: 


  
    In order for [the county] to be immune under Section 
      15-78-60(11), H & Kâ€™s loss would have to be the result of the countyâ€™s 
      "assessment or collection of taxes or . . . enforcement of tax laws.â€Â  In 
      this case, H & Kâ€™s loss is a direct result of the [countyâ€™s] failure 
      to refund H & K the purchase price when a tax sale was set aside, a ministerial 
      act separate and distinct from assessing, collecting, or enforcing tax laws 
      against a taxpayer.
  


  H & K Specialists, 340 S.C. at 587, 532 S.E.2d 
    at 619.
  However, H & K states the purpose of section 
    15-78-60(11) is to shield the County from liability when taxpayers lose property 
    as a result of a faulty tax sale.Â  Id.Â  SPDâ€™s action against the County 
    for interest fees incurred by borrowing the money to redeem the property is 
    the type of damages precluded by section 15-78-60(11).Â  Here, the County was 
    enforcing the tax laws against SPD.Â  The money SPD paid in interest on funds 
    borrowed to redeem the property were losses incurred pursuant to a faulty 
    tax sale and the legislature has precluded recovery by SPD for these damages.

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert C. Spinner and Shirley Spinner,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William Adams and Celeste Adams,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-040
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Douglas F. Gay, of Rock Hill, for Appellants. 
Lucy London McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert and Shirley Spinner 
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision ruling they failed to prove the barking of 
  the dogs of William and Celeste Adams constituted a nuisance.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
  The Spinners 
  brought this action against the Adamses alleging the barking of the Adamses 
  four dogs constituted a nuisance.Â  They sought damages and an injunction.Â 
  At trial, Robert Spinner testified the dogs began 
    barking immediately after the Adamses moved into their home. Â He explained 
    he repeatedly asked his neighbors to quiet the dogs and although he initially 
    received reassurances, he was later told he would have to live with the situation.Â  
    Spinner claimed his work as a truck driver was affected because the barking 
    interfered with his sleep.Â  Shirley Spinner testified she was once so upset 
    about the barking and about her husband working without sleep that she thought 
    she was having a heart attack.Â  Tests later revealed she did not suffer any 
    cardiac event.Â  The Spinners called animal control, made numerous complaints 
    to the York County Sheriffâ€™s Office, swore out warrants against the Adamses, 
    and sued the Adamses on more than one occasion.Â  One deputy who responded 
    to some of the Spinnersâ€™ calls testified the Adamses dogs were barking at 
    all times when she was there and that she spoke with the Adamses, advising 
    them of the county noise ordinance and asking them to quiet their dogs.Â  
  Celeste Adams testified she tried to keep her dogs 
    from bothering the neighbors.Â  She testified she tried keeping them indoors 
    at night, putting special collars on them, and directing a sprinkler at their 
    doghouse so they would stay inside.Â  She testified the barking continued at 
    times and that in a final effort to end the strife, approximately one year 
    before the hearing, she had the dogsâ€™ vocal cords surgically notched so they 
    could no longer bark.Â  
  The Adamses also presented evidence the Spinners 
    were unduly sensitive.Â  A county attorney testified all parties attending 
    a mediation hearing were willing to work out a solution except for Robert 
    Spinner.Â  Other neighbors testified the dogs were not a problem and some alleged 
    the Spinners had harassed them regarding even occasional mild barking by their 
    own dogs. Â One neighbor stated that when Robert Spinner called to complain 
    about her dog barking she noticed he had his windows open.Â  Spinner himself 
    testified he did not think he should have to close his windows in order to 
    lessen his disturbance by his neighborsâ€™ dogs.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  The Spinners argue the trial court erred in refusing 
    to consider a tape of the Adamsesâ€™ dogs barking.Â  They also argue the court 
    erred in failing to apply county provisions that require pet owners to prevent 
    their pets from becoming a public nuisance.Â  Neither issue is preserved.
  Although Robert Spinner testified he brought tape 
    recordings of the Adamsesâ€™ dogs to court with him, the record does not reflect 
    an attempt to mark or submit the tapes as evidence or to proffer their contents 
    to the court.Â  Thus, it does not appear the court was asked to consider the 
    tapes.Â  The court was also not asked to consider or apply any particular county 
    ordinance.Â  The Spinners did not mention any specific ordinance in their pleadings, 
    in their hearing before the trial court, or in their brief to this court.Â  
    To be preserved for appellate review, an issue must be raised to and ruled 
    upon by the trial court.Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 399, 570 
    S.E.2d 176, 180 (2002).Â  Furthermore, short conclusory statements without 
    supporting legal authority, such as the Spinnersâ€™ two-paragraph argument regarding 
    the York County Code, are deemed abandoned on appeal.Â  Glasscock, Inc. 
    v. U.S. Fidelity & Guaranty Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 
    691 (Ct. App. 2001).
  The Spinners also argue the court erred in finding 
    they failed to produce sufficient evidence to prove the existence of a nuisance.Â  
    We disagree.Â  To establish a nuisance, a landowner traditionally must demonstrate 
    the defendant unreasonably interfered with the ownership or use of the plaintiffâ€™s 
    land.Â  FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 352 S.C. 408, 413-14, 
    574 S.E.2d 228, 231 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Determining whether one landownerâ€™s 
    use of his property is a legal infringement on the property rights of another 
    requires delicate balancing of the parties conflicting interests and rights.Â  
    Winget v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 242 S.C. 152, 159, 130 S.E.2d 363, 
    367 (1963).Â  Although landowners must not unreasonably interfere with the 
    rights of their neighbors to enjoy their property, not every annoyance or 
    disturbance created by the landownerâ€™s use of his property constitutes a nuisance.Â  
    Oâ€™Cain v. Oâ€™Cain, 322 S.C. 551, 560-61, 473 S.E.2d 460, 466 (Ct. App. 
    1996).Â  The inquiry is not whether the plaintiffs have been annoyed or disturbed 
    but whether their legal rights have been injured.Â  
  Here, we agree with the trial court that the Spinners 
    have failed to establish their claim that the Adamsesâ€™ dogs constituted a 
    private nuisance.Â  Although the Spinners testified they were bothered and 
    disturbed by the dogsâ€™ barking, they failed to prove the barking rose to a 
    level where their rights were injured.Â  There was evidence showing the Adamses 
    made several attempts to lessen the disturbance to the Spinners, including 
    having the dogs surgically â€œdebarked.â€ There was also evidence the Spinners 
    were unusually sensitive and unwilling to mitigate the annoyance they suffered.Â  
    Other homeowners in the neighborhood testified they had no problems with the 
    Adamsesâ€™ dogs.Â  
  AFFIRMED.
   HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Randall Theodore

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Craig L. Atchison # 1,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-045
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Craig L. Atchison, 
  was convicted of burglary in the second degree and petit larceny.Â  The trial 
  judge sentenced Atchison to consecutive terms of fifteen years on the burglary 
  charge and three years on the larceny charge.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Atchison was tried before a jury on January 17, 
  2002, for burglary and larceny involving the home and personal goods of Jodi 
  Sutton.Â  Following jury selection, Atchison objected and made a Batson 
  motion requesting the solicitor give race-neutral explanations for the striking 
  of three black males, jurors 23, 52 and 22.Â  The solicitor responded that he 
  struck juror number 23 "because he does have a magistrateâ€™s court conviction 
  of public intoxication, DUI.â€ And that he struck juror number 52 "because he 
  had a magistrateâ€™s court conviction for multiple counts of fraudulent checks 
  and also a DUI.â€Â  As to juror number 22, the following colloquy occurred:

[Solicitor]:Â  And number 22 was Edward Chalmers.Â  I donâ€™t 
  have any indication Mr. Chalmers has a record.Â  But in my discussions with Lieutenant 
  Boland, Lieutenant Boland tells me that he has been on several calls regarding 
  Mr., Mr. Chalmersâ€™ niece and on those calls Mr. Chalmers was there and Mr. Boland 
  dealt with him.Â  He essentially, for lack of a better term, he hangs with the 
  wrong crowd and heâ€™s not the type of individual the State would prefer to have 
  on this jury to hear this case.
[The Court]:Â  All right.Â  Mr. Jenkins, you want to be heard 
  on any or all of those?
[Defense Counsel]:Â  Yes, sir, your Honor.Â  On number 22.
[The Court]:Â  23?Â  22, Chalmers.
[Defense Counsel]:Â  The last one, Mr. Chalmers.Â  The Solicitor 
  indicated that the defendant hangs with the wrong crowd and indicated that the 
  officer had some type of interaction with him.Â  He did not allege any improper 
  conduct or anything that would lead the court to believe that it was a racially 
  neutral reason.Â  The hanging with the wrong crowd is simply saying that heâ€™s 
  been where officers have been before.Â  They didnâ€™t offer any information as 
  to his actions or interactions.Â  I would submit that the reason for striking 
  him is not racially neutral.
[The Court]:Â  All right.Â  Mr. Peace, you want to be heard?
[Solicitor]:Â  Well, your Honor, I donâ€™t have to give any other 
  facts, I mean, on its face is the fact that the police have dealt with him and 
  they inform me based on those dealings that heâ€™s not the type of individual 
  that we want sitting on the jury.Â  I donâ€™t care if heâ€™s black or white.Â  If 
  they dealt with him and the dealings havenâ€™t been satisfactory, I think thatâ€™s 
  a sufficient reason for us to exercise a challenge.Â  And I think thatâ€™s a racial 
  neutral reason.
[The Court]:Â  All right, Mr. Jenkins, anything further?
[Defense Counsel]:Â  No, sir, your Honor.
[The Court]:Â  All right.Â  I find that the State has given 
  sufficient racially neutral reasons for having exercised the strikes on juror 
  number 23, 52, and 22.Â  And the jury as selected will stand.

Following submission of the case to the jury, Atchison 
  was convicted of second-degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Atchison contends the trial judge erred 
  in refusing to quash the jury, as it was seated in violation of Batson v. 
  Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  He asserts the explanation given by the solicitor 
  was not racially neutral, but it was akin to saying the venireman "shucked and 
  jived,â€ an explanation which has been found to demonstrate an impermissible 
  subjective intent to discriminate.Â  We disagree.Â  
In State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 515 S.E.2d 
  88 (1999), our Supreme Court set forth the following relevant law where a Batson 
  motion is concerned:

A Batson hearing is conducted in the following 
  manner.Â  First, the trial judge must hold a Batson hearing when members 
  of a cognizable racial group or gender are struck and the opposing party requests 
  a hearing.Â  Second, the proponent of the strike must present a race- or gender-neutral 
  explanation.Â  At this second step, the proponent of the strike no longer is 
  required to offer a reason that is race or gender-neutral and clear, 
  reasonably specific, and legitimate.Â  The reason must only be race- or gender-neutral.Â  
  Third, the opponent of the strike must show that the race- or gender-neutral 
  explanation given was mere pretext.Â  The burden of persuading the court that 
  a Batson violation has occurred remains at all times on the opponent 
  of the strike.
*Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *
Whether a partyâ€™s proffered reason for exercising 
  a peremptory strike is discriminatory must be determined by examining the totality 
  of the facts and circumstances in the record.

Id. at 629, 515 S.E.2d at 90-91 (citations 
  omitted).Â  
Unless a discriminatory intent is inherent in the 
  proponentâ€™s explanation at the second step, the reason offered will be deemed 
  race-neutral.Â  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 8, 512 S.E.2d 99, 102 (1999).Â  
  Further, a trial judgeâ€™s determination regarding purposeful discrimination rests 
  largely on his evaluation of demeanor and credibility, and because the demeanor 
  of the challenged attorney is often the best and only evidence of possible discrimination, 
  the evaluation lies peculiarly within the trial judgeâ€™s province.Â  State 
  v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 615-16, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  Thus, the 
  appellate court must give the trial judgeâ€™s findings great deference, and review 
  the judgeâ€™s ruling under a clearly erroneous standard.Â  Id. at 615, 545 
  S.E.2d at 810.
The Solicitor explained he struck Mr. Chalmers because 
  (1) he "hangs with the wrong crowd and heâ€™s not the type of individual the State 
  would prefer to have on this juryâ€ and (2) the investigating officer on the 
  case had dealt with him and those dealings had been unsatisfactory.Â  We discern 
  no discriminatory intent inherent in the Solicitorâ€™s explanation.Â  See 
  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. at 630, 515 S.E.2d at 91 (prosecutorâ€™s primary 
  reason for striking potential juror, because lead detective in case knew her 
  to be a high-strung, critical person who would be a polarizing force on the 
  jury, was a race-neutral reason for the strike); State v. Smith, 321 
  S.C. 471, 474, 469 S.E.2d 57, 59 (Ct. App. 1996) (trooperâ€™s personal contact 
  with the venirepersons or family members on previous occasions and his obvious 
  belief they may be biased against law enforcement or otherwise partial to defendant 
  were legitimate and racially neutral, and were related to his views concerning 
  the outcome of the case to be tried); State v. Richburg, 304 S.C. 162, 
  163-64, 403 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1991) (officerâ€™s apparent knowledge that venireperson 
  had anti-law enforcement bias found to be legitimate race-neutral reason for 
  strike); State v. Johnson, 302 S.C. 243, 246, 395 S.E.2d 167, 168-69 
  (1990) (following explanations were found to be racially neutral and sufficient 
  to withstand Batson inquiry:Â  (1) jurorâ€™s neighbor had been arrested by one 
  of the officers involved in the case; (2) juror lived near and frequented an 
  establishment which has had great conflict with the law enforcement of the county; 
  (3) juror lived next door to and had a close relationship with a man who had 
  recently been convicted of a drug offense).
For the foregoing reasons, Atchisonâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, 
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.
