THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Albert Gerald Graham,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joyce Carlene Graham,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Mary E. Buchan, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-046
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed January 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Scott A. Graustein, of Conway, for Appellant.
Charles Edward Parrish, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Joyce Carlene Graham (Wife) appeals from the family courtâ€™s 
  order of separate support and maintenance, in which the court determined child 
  custody and support, equitable division of the marital estate, and attorneysâ€™ 
  fees.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Wife and Albert Gerald Graham (Husband) 
  were married February 16, 1996.Â  They have one child together, who was born 
  May 20, 1995.Â  On September 6, 2001, the Husband was arrested for criminal domestic 
  violence.Â  At this time, the Wife moved with the child to Haines City, Florida.Â  
  She filed a petition for an injunction for protection against domestic violence 
  in Polk County, Florida on September 19, 2001.Â  The Florida court issued a temporary 
  order that same day granting the wife temporary custody of the child.
The Husband brought this action September 
  28, 2001 in the Horry County, South Carolina family court seeking a divorce 
  on the ground of habitual drunkenness.Â  In the alternative, he requested an 
  order of separate support and maintenance.Â  He also requested custody of and 
  support for the child, equitable distribution of the marital estate, including 
  possession of specific items, and attorneysâ€™ fees and costs.
After conferring with the Florida court, 
  the South Carolina family court determined it had jurisdiction of this matter 
  in regards to custody, visitation, child support, and possession of any marital 
  assets, as well as other related matters.Â  Accordingly, an evidentiary hearing 
  scheduled for December 12, 2001 in Florida was cancelled.Â  The South Carolina 
  family court held a temporary hearing November 27, 2001.Â  The Wife was not present.Â  
  The court granted the Husband temporary custody of the child with the wife receiving 
  visitation.Â  
The Wife subsequently filed an answer 
  to the Husbandâ€™s complaint requesting custody of and support for the child, 
  equitable distribution, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  She also requested 
  the court grant her a divorce on the grounds of physical abuse. 
A final hearing was scheduled for May 
  20, 2002.Â  Prior to the hearing, the partiesâ€™ attorneys informed the court that 
  a settlement had been reached.Â  However, upon questioning of the Wife, the court 
  determined that she was not entering into the agreement freely and voluntarily.Â  
  The court adjourned the hearing and a new trial date was set for August 12-13, 
  2002.Â  During the May 20 hearing, the wife asked that her attorney be relieved 
  as counsel.Â  The court granted the request, but warned her that the securing 
  of additional counsel would not be grounds for a continuance nor would the hearing 
  be continued at the new counselâ€™s request.Â  In its order, the court reiterated 
  that the wife would not receive a continuance to find counsel or for her new 
  counsel to prepare.
In this order, the court retroactively 
  appointed the guardian ad litem who had already been working on the case.Â  It 
  ordered the Husband to pay $600.00 of the guardianâ€™s fees and the Wife to pay 
  $1200.00 of the fees within 30 days of the hearing.Â  It also ordered the Wife 
  to pay $2,337.00 of the Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees incurred in preparation of 
  the postponed hearing.Â  
At the hearing held August 12, 2002, the Wife informed 
  the family court that she had been unable to obtain counsel and requested that 
  she be allowed to find representation.Â  The Husband opposed the request for 
  a continuance and the guardian ad litem took no position on the issue.Â  The 
  family court denied the request and proceeded with the hearing.Â  
In its final order, the family court held the Husband 
  had failed to carry his burden of proof in regards to a divorce on the grounds 
  of habitual drunkenness.Â  Therefore, it granted the parties an order of separate 
  support and maintenance.Â  It awarded the Husband custody of the child with the 
  Wife receiving visitation.Â  It ordered the Wife to pay child support through 
  the court.Â  It set the partiesâ€™ responsibilities for the childâ€™s medical care 
  costs.Â  The court divided the marital estate and provided for set-offs from 
  the estate of funds the Wife owed the Husband.Â  The court authorized either 
  party to request a drug test from the other, with the requesting party being 
  responsible for the cost of the test unless the results were positive.Â  The 
  court ordered the Husband to pay $2,300.00 of the guardianâ€™s fees and the wife 
  pay $800.00 of the fees within 30 days of the trial.Â  Finally the court ordered 
  that the parties are "restrained from contacting, harassing, threatening, or 
  molesting one another.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this 
  court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of 
  the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 
  157, 160 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to 
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings or relieve the appellant of the burden 
  of convincing us the lower court committed error.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor do we ignore the fact that 
  the trial court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  
  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
DISCUSSION

  I.   Continuance

The wife argues the family court erred in denying 
  her request for a continuance to allow her to find representation.Â  We disagree.Â  

A decision whether to grant or deny a motion for 
  continuance rests within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Jackson 
  v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 309, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997).Â  We will not reverse 
  the trial court without a clear showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.
The final hearing in this matter would have been 
  held May 20, 2002 except the Wife balked at entering into the settlement agreement 
  and asked that her attorney be relieved as counsel.Â  Although the family court 
  granted this request, it warned the Wife that the securing of additional counsel 
  would not be grounds for a continuance nor would the hearing be continued at 
  the new counselâ€™s request.Â  In its order, the court reiterated, "[I]n the event 
  the [Wife] retains an attorney for the August 12th and 13th 
  hearing, she must do so in a timely fashion, and the hiring of a new attorney 
  will not be grounds for the [Wife] to seek another continuance.â€Â  The Wife had 
  almost three months to secure new counsel, but failed to do so.Â  She stated 
  she had spoken to seven different attorneys, five of whom had conflicts and 
  the other two were on vacation at the time of the hearing.Â  We find the Wife 
  was aware that she would not receive additional time to either search for new 
  counsel or for new counsel to prepare for the hearing.Â  Considering the adequate 
  time the Wife had to obtain new counsel, we find the family court did not abuse 
  its discretion in denying the Wifeâ€™s request for a continuance.Â  
The Wife also argues the family court erroneously 
  held that it was bound by the prior order and did not exercise its own discretion.Â  
  As the wife failed to raise this argument to the family court, it is not preserved.Â  
  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997) (issue 
  must be raised to and ruled on by family court to be preserved for review).

  II.    Due process

The Wife argues the family court denied her federal 
  right to procedural due process because she did not receive adequate notice 
  that she would be required to proceed pro se at the August 12, 2002 hearing.Â Â Â  
  The issue was not raised to the family court.Â  Therefore, it is not preserved.Â  
  In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 551 S.E.2d 235 (2001) (stating constitutional 
  claim must be raised and ruled upon to be preserved for appellate review). 

  III.   Jurisdiction

The Wife argues the family court granted the parties 
  a limited divorce, which it lacks jurisdiction to do.Â  We disagree.Â  
The family court has exclusive jurisdiction to 
  hear and determine actions: 

For divorce a vinculo matrimonii, separate support and maintenance, 
  legal separation, and in other marital litigation between the parties, and for 
  settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the parties in the actions in 
  and to the real and personal property of the marriage and attorneyâ€™s fees, if 
  requested by either party in the pleadings.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(2) (Supp.2003).
In support of her argument that the family 
  court acted outside of its jurisdiction, the Wife calls this courtâ€™s attention 
  to where in the hearing the family court noted, "It is obvious that the parties 
  can not live together.â€Â  However, the court did not grant the parties a limited 
  divorce.Â  As it clearly stated in its order, it granted them an order of separate 
  support maintenance, which is certainly within its jurisdiction to do.Â  

  IV.   Failure to advise wife.Â  

The Wife argues the family court erred in failing 
  to advise her of the consequences of not testifying at the hearing.Â  The Wife 
  never raised this argument to the family court.Â  Accordingly, it is not preserved.Â  
  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997) (issue 
  must be raised to and ruled on by family court to be preserved for review).
Furthermore, a pro se litigant has full 
  responsibility for complying with substantive and procedural requirements of 
  the law.Â  State v. Burton, ___ S.C. ___, ___, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 n.5 (2003); 
  Goodson v. American Bankers Ins. Co of Fla., 295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 
  687, 689 (Ct. App. 1988) (" Lack of familiarity with legal proceedings is unacceptable 
  and the court will not hold a layman to any lesser standard than is applied 
  to an attorney.â€).
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM: Earl Brooks, a/k/a Earl Lawrence 
  Brooks, Jr. appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s judgment of foreclosure and sale.Â  
  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Register

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Daniel Moorer,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-048
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, Office of Appellate Defense,
of Columbia, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, ChiefÂ 
Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of 
  Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Walter M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Moorer appeals from his conviction on a first degree burglary 
  charge, arguing that the house he broke into was not a "dwellingâ€ within S.C.Code 
  Ann. Â§ 16-11-10 (2003). We affirm.
FACTS
Appellant Daniel Moorer broke into a house located 
  in St. George onÂ  March 27, 2001. At the time, the house was empty. The owner 
  of the house had died, but the decedentâ€™s daughters had used the house "three 
  times, four time[s] out of the year two or three weeks at a time.â€ In 2002, 
  a jury convicted Moorer of first degree burglary. The trial judge then sentenced 
  Moorer to fifteen years in prison.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
ISSUESÂ Â Â Â  

  (1)   Did the court err in denying Moorerâ€™s 
  motion for directed verdict, ruling that the house was a dwelling as required for first 
  degree burglary? 
  (2)   Did the court err in limiting 
  Moorerâ€™s closing concerning whether the house was a dwelling?

ANALYSIS:Â  
"On a motion for a directed verdict in a criminal 
  case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or non-existence of evidence, 
  not its weight.â€ State v. Robinson, 344 S.C. 220, 223, 543 S.E.2d 249, 
  250 (App. Ct. 2001). And the appellate court must interpret the evidence in 
  the light most favorable to the state. State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 
  46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). 
A dwelling is "any house â€¦ [or] building â€¦ in which 
  there sleeps a proprietor, tenant, watchman, clerk, laborer or person who lodges 
  there with a view to the protection of property. . . .â€ S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-10 
  (2003). A house can be a dwelling even if it is empty, so long as the dweller 
  has the intention of returning there. State v. Ferebee, 273 S.C. 403, 
  405, 257 S.E.2d 154, 155 (1979). Therefore, a "[t]emporary absence from a â€˜dwellingâ€™ 
  is irrelevant to the charge of first degree burglary.â€ State v. White, 
  349 S.C. 33, 36, 562 S.E.2d 305, 306 (2002).
At trial, there was evidence that the decedentâ€™s 
  daughters came to the house three or four times year and had maintained its 
  water, electricity, and telephone services. They had last visited the house 
  about four months before the break-in. The house had not been abandoned. Taking 
  the evidence in the most favorable light for the state, we cannot say that the 
  trial judge erred when she ruled that the house was a dwelling. 
Moorer also argues that he should have been allowed 
  to raise the dwelling issue in his closing argument. During his closing, Moorerâ€™s 
  counsel said: "Mr. Moorer lived on Washington Heights. Heâ€™s familiar with this 
  property, lived there all his life, 57 years old. He knew nobody was living 
  there.â€ The state objected on the ground of "facts not in evidence.â€ A conference 
  ensued among the judge, the prosecutor, and the defense counsel, but the conference 
  was off the record. When the defense counsel continued his closing argument, 
  he did not object on the record to the judgeâ€™s apparent decision to sustain 
  the stateâ€™s objection. Therefore, the issue was not preserved for appeal. See 
  York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 173, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997) 
  ("An objection made during an off-the-record conference which is not made part 
  of the record does not preserve the question for review.â€). 
Affirmed.
Huff, Stilwell, and Beatty, J.J., concur.

title: Fried v. Fried
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ann Fried,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dennis A. Fried,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-049
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald Jay Budman, of Charleston, for Appellant
Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Husband appeals from a family courtâ€™s trial order requiring 
  him to pay the full sum stipulated in the divorce settlement to Wife, in spite 
  of the decrease in the value of the accounts due to market fluctuations. We 
  affirm.
FACTS
Ann and Dennis Fried were divorced in 2002. The 
  parties reached, and the family judge accepted, a settlement concerning the 
  division of the marital estate. In the divorce order dated March 13, 2002, Husband 
  was ordered to give to Wife â€œby QDRO, to be prepared within thirty (30) days 
  from the date of [the] order, an amount equal to One Hundred Thirty Thousand 
  ($130,000.00) Dollars, payable from all of the funds contained in a SEP-IRA 
  held by Morgan-Stanley Dean Witter and the balance from annuities held in a 
  â€˜Putnam Fundâ€™ at USB Paine Webber, both presently titled in [Husbandâ€™s] name.â€ 

By a first QDRO, the sum of $95,000.00 from the 
  Morgan Stanley account was assigned to Wife on April 7, 2002. A second QDRO 
  assigned $35,000.00 to Wife from the Putnam account. The Morgan Stanley account 
  subsequently decreased to $77,816.00 due to market fluctuations. Husband was 
  willing to transfer those funds to Wife, but refused to add the lost $17,184.00 
  from the Putnam account to makeup the difference. Both parties moved for a Rule 
  to Show Cause. The judge found that the divorce decree clearly mandated that 
  Husband pay Wife $130,000.00, market fluctuations notwithstanding. The judge 
  ordered Husband to pay $52,184,00 from the Putnam account. The judge also held 
  Husband in contempt of court and granted attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife. 
ISSUES

  (1)   Did the family court err in finding 
  that Husband should bear the risk of devaluating securities transferred to Wife pursuant 
  to the divorce decree?
(2) Did the family court err in awarding 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife?

ANALYSISÂ Â  
This Court can determine facts in accordance with 
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence when reviewing matters from 
  the family court. Wooten v. Wooten, 354 S.C. 242, 248, 580 S.E.2d 765, 
  768 (Ct. App. 2003). Husband argues that Wife should bear the burden of the 
  market fluctuations because she acquired equitable title to the accounts upon 
  the filing of the divorce decree. For that argument, Husband cites Calhoun 
  v. Calhoun, 331 S.C. 157, 501 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 1998). However, Calhoun 
  is easily distinguishable from the present case. There, the wife had been awarded 
  the actual lots at issue, But here, the divorce decree did not assign 
  the two accounts to Wife. Instead, the divorce decree ordered that Wife be paid 
  the sum certain of $130,000.00 from â€œall the fundsâ€ in the two accounts. The 
  two subsequent QDROâ€™s were used simply â€œ[i]n furtherance of the agreement to 
  the transfer [of] the $130,000.00,â€ only â€œto effectuate the agreement of the 
  parties as contained in the Divorce Decree.â€ That more money had to come from 
  the Putnam account and less from the Stanley Morgan account is of no import.
Husband also appeals the family courtâ€™s decision 
  to award attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife. â€œAn award of attorney's fees will not be overturned 
  absent an abuse of discretion.â€ Wooten, 354 S.C. at 254, 580 S.E.2d at 
  771. â€œIn deciding whether to award attorney's fees, the family court 
  should consider the parties' ability to pay their own fee, the beneficial results 
  obtained by counsel, the respective financial conditions of the parties, and 
  the effect of the fee on each party's standard of living.â€ Id. Here, 
  the family court found that Wife had not received â€œany significant assets incident 
  to the partiesâ€™ divorceâ€ and was unemployed at the time of the hearing. Based 
  on these and other facts, the court awarded her attorneyâ€™s fees. We cannot say 
  that the family court abused its discretion.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Lindsey,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Spartan Roofing Company, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-050
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kirby D. Shealy III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Norman Douglas Brannon, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:   The Lindseys sued Spartan Roofing, alleging breach of contract. 
  The jury found for the Lindseys; Spartan Roofing appeals. We affirm. 
FACTS
Homeowners James and Polly Lindsey sued Spartan 
  Roofing for negligence and breach of contract after Spartan failed to repair 
  the Lindseysâ€™ home to the Lindseysâ€™ satisfaction. The Lindseys alleged that 
  the roof of their home was still leaking, even after Polly Lindsey pointed out 
  the problem to Spartan. The Lindseys then consulted Mr. Burgess of Cannon Roofing. 
  Mr. Burgess determined that the roof was leaking in two places. Polly Lindsey 
  asked Mr. Burgess if he "could repair the leaks and provide a warrantyâ€ on it. 
  Mr. Burgess replied that he could warrant only a whole new roof, not one he 
  repaired in part. However, when asked whether the whole roof had to be replaced 
  because of the two leaks, Mr. BurgessÂ  declined to offer an opinion. At trial, 
  the Lindseys attempted to introduce into evidence Mr. Burgessâ€™s estimate to 
  replace the whole roof and to warrant it for two years. Spartan objected. 
Spartan argued that the Lindseys were attempting 
  to arrive at a better position than where they were before; that the Lindseys 
  would in essence have a brand new roof with a two-year warranty, not just a 
  repaired roof. Spartan insisted that the measure of damages was the cost of 
  fixing the two leaks, not of replacing the whole roof. The Lindseys countered 
  that they had "contracted to replace the entire roofâ€ originally with Spartan, 
  and were therefore entitled to the replacement and the warranty. 
The trial judge first indicated that he might sustain 
  the objection. However, Mr. Albert, the owner of Spartan, subsequently testified 
  that the Lindseys had indeed contracted with Spartan to "install a new roofing 
  system.â€ Mr. Albert also testified that that work carried a two-year workmanship 
  warranty. The trial judge then allowed into evidence Mr. Burgessâ€™s estimate 
  for the replacement and warranty of the whole roof. The jury found for the Lindseys 
  and awarded them $11,393 in "actual damages.â€ 
 ISSUESÂ  

(1) Did the trial court err in allowing Mr. Burgessâ€™s 
  estimate since there was no testimony that the whole roof needed to be replaced?Â  
  
(2) Did the trial court err in denying Spartanâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial since there was no evidence to substantiate the juryâ€™s 
  award of damages?

ANALYSIS
"The admission or exclusion of evidence 
  at trial is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose discretion 
  will not be disturbed on appeal in the absence of an abuse of such discretion 
  amounting to a manifest error of law.â€ Cooks v. S.C Dept. of Hwys. and Pub. 
  Transp., 309 S.C. 179, 184, 420 S.E.2d 847, 849 (1992) (citing Grand 
  Strand Constr. Co. v. Graves, 269 S.C. 594, 595, 239 S.E.2d 81, 81 (1977)). 
  "The grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the 
  trial judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings 
  are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled 
  by error of law.â€ Vinson v. Harley, 324 S.C. 389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 
  723 (Ct. App. 1996) (citing Umhoefer v. Bollinger, 298 S.C. 221, 224, 
  379 S.E.2d 296, 297 (Ct. App. 1989)). "In deciding whether to assess error to 
  a court's denial of a motion for a new trial, [appellate courts] consider the 
  testimony and reasonable inferences to be drawn therefrom in the light most 
  favorable to the nonmoving party.â€ Id.  
Spartan Roofing argues that the trial judge erred 
  when he allowed Mr. Burgess to introduce into evidence the estimate to replace 
  the whole roof. We disagree. At trial, Mr. Albert himself admitted that Spartan 
  had been hired to "install a new roofing systemâ€ and that Spartan "was paid 
  $14,218 for a new roof.â€ Mr. Albert also testified that a new roof carried a 
  two-year warranty. That testimony is bolstered by the Lindseysâ€™ contention that 
  they contracted with Spartan to replace the roof completely. (R.179). There 
  is ample evidence to suggest that the Lindseys contracted for a new, warranted 
  roof with Spartan, and therefore were entitled to obtain the same. See 
  Minter v. GOCT, Inc., 322 S.C. 525, 528, 473 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 
  1996) ("The purpose of an award of damages for breach of contract is to put 
  the plaintiff in as good a position as he would have been in if the contract 
  had been performed.â€).Â Â  
Since the evidence supports the juryâ€™s award, we 
  need not address Spartanâ€™s other issues.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David J. Frantzis,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kristen B. Frantzis,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-051
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David J. Frantzis, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Kristen B. Frantzis, of Goose Creek, for Respondent.
D. Allen Badger, of Charleston, for Guardian Ad Litem
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â David Frantzis appeals the family courtâ€™s decision to 
  not modify the custody order concerning the Frantzis child. We affirm.
FACTS
Kristen (â€œthe motherâ€) and David (â€œthe fatherâ€) Frantzis 
  divorced in August of 2000. In the divorce order, the family court (â€œthe courtâ€) 
  granted sole custody of the Frantzis child to the mother. The court granted 
  visitation rights to the father and ordered him to pay child support. The court 
  also ordered the father to â€œstay awayâ€ from the mother and to not harass her. 

In May of 2001, the father petitioned the court 
  to modify the custody arrangement. The father alleged that the mother had used 
  illegal drugs in front of the child and had exposed the child to â€œmultiple malesâ€ 
  who were â€œnot family members.â€ The mother responded in a letter, saying that 
  she had never in her life used cocaine, but admitted to living with her â€œfiancÃ©.â€ 
  In July of 2001, the court appointed a GAL. The court also ordered the mother 
  to stop living with her fiancÃ©, as he was still married to another woman. In 
  September of 2002, the court held a hearing about the husbandâ€™s request. The 
  parties represented themselves at the hearing. 
The judge heard testimony from the father, the 
  mother, the motherâ€™s fiancÃ©, and the GAL. He found that (1) the mother and her 
  fiancÃ© had an â€œillegal and immoralâ€ relationship; (2) their continued living 
  arrangement violated a previous court order. However, the judge maintained custody 
  with the mother, warning her that she would be held in contempt of court and 
  lose custody of her child if she continued living with her fiancÃ©. The husband 
  appeals.
ISSUESÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

(1) Did the family court err in not finding that 
  the father was the more fit custodial parent?
(2) Did the family court err in not enforcing its 
  prior order that required the wife to not expose the child to the â€œadulterousâ€ 
  relationship?

ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œWhen reviewing the factual determinations of the 
  family court, an appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.â€ Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 
  623 (2003) (citing Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 
  157 (1996)). But â€œthe appellate court â€˜should be reluctant to substitute its 
  own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the [family] court.â€™â€ 
  Id. And â€œwhere there is disputed evidence, the appellate court may adhere 
  to the findings of the family court.â€ Id.  
Here, the judge heard the testimonies of all parties. 
  The judge then decided that, the motherâ€™s living arrangement notwithstanding, 
  the situation did not warrant changing the original custody order. The GALâ€™s 
  report had reached the same conclusion. The father failed to provide persuasive 
  evidence that the father would provide a better environment for the child. There 
  is no reason to disturb that finding.
The father also argues that the trial court erred 
  in not holding the mother in contempt after finding that the mother had violated 
  a prior order by continuing to live with her fiancÃ©. This matter was not raised 
  before the family court judge and therefore we cannot review it. See 
  Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) 
  (â€œHusband neither raised these issues to the court at trial nor through a Rule 
  59(e) motion to amend the judgment [so] the issues are not properly before this 
  Court for review.â€);(Cash v. Cash, 320 S.C. 388, 392, 465 S.E.2d 371, 
  373 (Ct. 1995) (holding that when a family courtâ€™s order does not specifically 
  address an issue and no Rule (59)(e) motion to alter or amend the courtâ€™s order 
  is made, then the issue is not preserved for appellate review).Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH 
    CAROLINA
  In The Court of 
    Appeals
  
    
      
        
  Joe Louis Miller, Sr., Individually and as Legal Guardian 
          of Joe Louis Miller, Jr., and Sophia Miller, both Minors,       
  Appellant,

  Sherah L. Stark,       
  Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From York County
  Lee S. Alford, Circuit 
    Court Judge
  
  Unpublished Opinion 
    No. 2004-UP-052
  Submitted November 
    19, 2003 â€“ Filed January 22, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
  R. Thayer Rivers, Jr., of Ridgeland, for Appellants. 
  Ronnie Fred Craig, of Charlotte, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Joe Louis 
    Miller, Sr., individually and as legal guardian of Joe Miller, Jr. and Sophia 
    Miller, both minors, appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a 
    new trial absolute and challenges the sufficiency of the additur award.Â  We 
    affirm. [1]   
  FACTS
  Miller brought a personal 
    injury action against Sherah Stark following a minor traffic accident.Â  The 
    case was tried to a jury and verdicts were returned in favor of Miller and 
    his two children in the amounts of $316, $202 and $202, respectively.Â  Miller 
    moved post-trial for a new trial nisi additur or, in the alternative, for 
    a new trial absolute. The judge denied his motion for a new trial, but granted 
    an additur of $35 to Miller and both of his two children.Â  Miller appeals 
    the courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a new trial absolute and challenges the 
    sufficiency of the additur award.Â  
  Stark testified she was a few 
    cars back from the traffic signal behind Millerâ€™s Cadillac when the light 
    turned green.Â  She let her foot off the brake without accelerating and looked 
    over her shoulder to check on a crying child when she rolled into the Cadillac.Â  
    After the accident, Miller got out of the car, checked his rear bumper and 
    walked to a nearby service station to telephone the police. Â Stark testified 
    Millerâ€™s children continued to play and behave normally in the back seat of 
    his vehicle.Â  
  EMS responded but no 
    one was taken to the hospital and Miller later drove his vehicle from the 
    scene.Â  Afterward, Miller and his children visited the emergency room.Â  Millerâ€™s 
    head was examined and found to be atraumatic and normal.Â  Neither of the children 
    was given any medication.Â  
  In her answer, Stark answer admitted 
    that a collision occurred, but denied that Miller and his children sustained 
    injuries to the extent they alleged in the complaint.Â  At the trial, Stark 
    essentially admitted liability while continuing to question the damages as 
    claimed by Miller.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Miller argues the trial 
    court erred by failing to grant a new trial absolute based on inadequacy of 
    the verdict.Â  We disagree.
  The amount of the verdict 
    is not so shockingly disproportionate to the injuries Miller or his children 
    sustained as to indicate â€œpassion, caprice, prejudice, or some other influence 
    outside the evidenceâ€ motivated the juryâ€™s decision.Â  O'Neal v. Bowles, 
    314 S.C. 525, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993). 
  Testimony revealed neither 
    Miller nor his children suffered any serious injury.Â  Indeed, Millerâ€™s children 
    continued to play undisturbed in the rear seat of his car immediately after 
    the accident.Â  Although EMS was called to the scene, no one was taken to the 
    hospital.Â  Millerâ€™s later trip to the emergency room revealed he suffered 
    no head injury and the children required no medication.Â  The jury awarded 
    damages to cover the cost of the initial emergency room visit and included 
    the EMS trip in Millerâ€™s verdict.Â  The jury simply concluded that Miller did 
    not deserve costs for later medical treatments and awarded damages accordingly.Â  
    As Miller noted in his brief, â€œthe range of damages could have been from zero 
    to the sky.â€Â  See Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 
    406 S.E.2d 350 (1991) (citing Fennell v. Littlejohn, 240 S.C. 189, 
    125 S.E.2d 408 (1962)) (The award of actual and punitive damages remains within 
    the discretion of the jury, as reviewed by the trial judge.)Â  
  Miller also challenges 
    the sufficiency of the trial courtâ€™s additur award, arguing the trial court 
    abused its discretion by â€œspeculating as to the methodology of the jury verdict.â€Â  
    We disagree.
  A motion for a new trial nisi 
    additur is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Graham 
    v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 321 S.E.2d 40 (1984).Â  We find no abuse of 
    discretion by the trial judge in determining an additional award of $35 for 
    Miller and the children.Â  It is clear to us that the trial judge carefully 
    considered Millerâ€™s motion.Â  After all, he granted the amounts of the EMS 
    transport fees as part and parcel of costs directly arising out of the events 
    of the accident but, consistent with the juryâ€™s reasoning, declined to extend 
    additur to cover later medical bills.Â  
  AFFIRMED.
   HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Leroy Canzater,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
City of Columbia,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-054
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Dwight Christopher Moore, of Sumter, for Appellant.
W. Allen Nickles, III, and Carl L. Solomon, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this action for malicious 
  prosecution, false imprisonment, and bad faith termination, Leroy Canzater asserts 
  the trial court erred in dismissing the false imprisonment and bad faith termination 
  causes of action as barred by the statute of limitations and in ruling that 
  an arrest warrant conclusively barred an action for 
  malicious prosecution.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â 
FACTS
The City of Columbia (â€œthe Cityâ€) employed 
  Canzater in the Wastewater Maintenance Division.Â  Believing that Canzater had 
  for more than a year knowingly received overtime payments from the City in excess 
  of the hours actually worked, the City terminated his employment and sought 
  warrants for his arrest.Â  On December 2, 1998, a grand jury indicted Canzater 
  for grand larceny.Â  The court issued a warrant for his arrest.Â  Canzater was 
  arrested the following day.Â  On May 4, 1999, Canzater was again arrested and 
  indicted, this time on charges of conspiracy to commit embezzlement in connection 
  with the overtime payments. 
The circuit court dismissed all charges against 
  Canzater on September 22, 2000.Â  Thereafter, on November 5, 2001, Canzater initiated 
  the instant action against the City.Â  He asserted claims for false imprisonment, 
  malicious prosecution, and bad faith termination.Â  In his complaint, Canzater 
  alleges the City pursued the prosecution against him without probable cause 
  and without conducting a proper investigation to determine whether he engaged 
  in the alleged criminal conduct. 
The trial court granted the Cityâ€™s motion to dismiss 
  all three counts pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  Specifically, the court 
  ruled that Canzaterâ€™s claims for false imprisonment and bad faith termination 
  were barred by the statute of limitations and the malicious prosecution claim 
  failed as a matter of law because the existence of probable cause was established 
  by the issuance of arrest warrants.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.Â  False Imprisonment
  Canzater contends the trial court erred in holding 
    his false imprisonment action was barred by the statute of limitations because 
    the two-year statutory period did not begin to run until the charges against 
    him were dismissed.Â  We disagree.
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-550 (Supp. 2002)
  Â provides 
    that the statute of limitations for a false imprisonment claim is two years.Â  
  
  We embrace the rule adopted by other jurisdictions 
    that the statute of limitations for false imprisonment begins to run when 
    the plaintiff is released following an arrest.Â  Campbell v. Hyatt Regency, 
    388 S.E.2d 341, 342 (Ga. Ct. App. 1989)  (â€œAn 
    action for false imprisonment â€˜must be brought within two years of its accrual 
    . . . which is from the release from imprisonment.â€™ â€); Stafford v. Muster, 
    582 S.W.2d 670, 680 (Mo. 1979) Â (â€œ[F]or false 
    imprisonment in particular, the authorities overwhelmingly hold that a cause 
    of action for false imprisonment accrues on the discharge from imprisonment.â€); 
    M.C. Dransfield, When Statute of Limitations Begins to Run Against Action 
    for False Imprisonment or False Arrest, 49 A.L.R.2d 922 (1956) Â (stating 
    the general rule is that the statute of limitations for false imprisonment 
    â€œbegins to run from the termination of the imprisonment and not from the time 
    when the proceedings under which the plaintiffâ€™s arrest occurred ended . . 
    . .â€); see Miller v. Dickert, 259 S.C. 1, 3, 190 S.E.2d 459, 
    460 (1972) Â (noting that both parties conceded the 
    cause of action in a false imprisonment case accrued from the time of the 
    arrest); 8 S.C. Juris. False Imprisonment Â§ 17 (1991).
  Following the return of indictments charging 
    Canzater with larceny and conspiracy to commit embezzlement, two different 
    circuit judges issued warrants for his arrest on December 3, 1998, and May 
    12, 1999, respectively.Â  According to the complaint, Canzater was released 
    from custody on his own recognizance after each arrest.Â  Using these two dates 
    as the dates of his discharge from imprisonment, it is clear that an action 
    brought on November 5, 2001 fails to satisfy the two-year statute of limitations. 
  
  II. 
  Bad Faith Termination
  
   
  
  Canzater also asserts the trial 
    court erred in barring his cause of action for bad faith termination under 
    the statute of limitations.Â  Specifically, Canzater argues his claim of bad 
    faith termination is a contract claim rather than a tort claim and therefore 
    beyond the scope of the South Carolina Torts Claims Actâ€™s two-year statute 
    of limitations.Â  
  
  Canzater did not raise this issue to the trial 
    court and the trial court did not rule upon it.Â  We therefore decline to address 
    it.Â  See Holy Loch Distribs., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 
    24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000) Â (â€œIn order to preserve 
    an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled 
    upon by the trial court.â€) .Â  
  III. 
  Malicious Prosecution 
  Canzater contends the trial court erred in granting 
    the Cityâ€™s motion to dismiss and determining the existence of an arrest warrant 
    conclusively establishes probable cause for prosecution.Â  We agree.
  â€œA ruling on a 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss must be 
    based solely upon the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint and 
    the motion cannot be sustained if facts alleged and inferences reasonably 
    deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to any relief on any theory 
    of the case.â€Â  Toussaint v. Ham, 292 S.C. 415, 416, 357 S.E.2d 8, 9 
    (1987).
  Although â€œSouth Carolina has long embraced the 
    rule that a true bill of indictment is prima facie evidence of probable cause 
    in an action for malicious prosecution,â€ Kinton v. Mobile Home Indus., 
    Inc., 274 S.C. 179, 182, 262 S.E.2d 727, 728 (1980) , 
    it is only prima facie evidence and not conclusive.Â  See 54 C.J.S. 
    Malicious Prosecution Â§ 34 at 555 (1987) (stating that â€œwhere the result 
    of the preliminary examination before a magistrate or other judicial officer 
    is unfavorable to the accused, and he is held, or committed . . . this is 
    prima facie evidence of probable cause, but not conclusive.â€).Â  
  In Melton v. Williams, 281 S.C. 182, 
    314 S.E.2d 612 (Ct. App. 1984) , we concluded 
    that, even though an arrest warrant was issued, â€œ[u]nder the circumstances 
    it was for the jury to say whether or not there was probable cause for the 
    swearing out of the warrant by Williams.â€ Id. at 187 , 314 S.E.2d at 
    615 ; see also Parrott v. Plowden Motor Co., 246 S.C. 318, 323, 
    143 S.E.2d 607, 609 (1965) ; Millhouse v. Food 
    Lion, Inc., 289 S.C. 203, 203, 345 S.E.2d 739, 739 (Ct. App. 1986) ; 
    cf. Gist v. Berkley County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 336 S.C. 611, 616, 
    521 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 1999) Â (finding 
    error in a trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in an action for false 
    imprisonment because the arrest warrant was insufficient and did not establish 
    probable cause).
  The trial court, therefore, erred in dismissing 
    Canzaterâ€™s claim for malicious prosecution because the existence of an arrest 
    warrant does not conclusively establish probable cause for prosecution.Â  
  AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
  GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
    concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Spartanburg County Building Codes Board of Appeals,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Samuel T. D. Lancaster,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-055
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  28, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel T.D. Lancaster, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
William McBee Smith, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Samuel Lancaster appeals from 
  the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of his appeal from the Spartanburg County Building 
  Codes Board of Appeals (the Board).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In June 2001, Spartanburg County (the 
  County) informed Lancaster that the storage of inoperable vehicles and appliances 
  on his property was in violation of a County ordinance.Â  To that end, the County 
  served Lancaster with a â€œNotice of Violation and Order,â€ which ordered Lancaster 
  to comply with the ordinance.Â  In response, Lancaster filed a request for a 
  variance with the Board.Â  The Board subsequently denied Lancasterâ€™s request 
  for a variance.Â Â Â  
Lancaster appealed the Boardâ€™s ruling to the circuit 
  court.Â  The circuit court judge dismissed Lancasterâ€™s appeal, finding (1) Lancasterâ€™s 
  allegations of collusion and equal protection violations were not preserved 
  for review and (2) there was substantial evidence to support the Boardâ€™s conclusions.Â  
  The final order also instructed Lancaster to comply with the Boardâ€™s final decision 
  within thirty days, and authorized County law enforcement officers to enter 
  Lancasterâ€™s property to determine compliance with the order.Â  Lancaster appeals. 

LAW/ANALYSIS
 Lancaster argues the circuit court erred 
  in upholding the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  We do not agree.
Initially, we note the circuit court was 
  correct in finding Lancasterâ€™s collusion and equal protection arguments were 
  procedurally barred.Â  As Lancaster had not raised these arguments to the Board, 
  he was prohibited from subsequently presenting these issues to the circuit court.Â  
  See, e.g.,Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. 
  Control, 348 S.C. 507, 519, 560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002) (finding issues not 
  raised to and ruled on by an administrative agency are not preserved for judicial 
  consideration) (citations omitted).
Therefore, the sole issue before this court is 
  whether the circuit court erred in dismissing Lancasterâ€™s appeal and upholding 
  the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  As Lancaster failed to appear for the Boardâ€™s hearing 
  on this matter, the hearing was held in his absence.Â  The inspector who issued 
  the Notice of Violation for Lancasterâ€™s property testified that Lancasterâ€™s 
  storage of eight inoperable motor vehicles, appliances, shelving, and pipe on 
  his property violated the Property Maintenance Code.Â  The inspector also stated 
  â€œthe property is obviously in violation of the Code,â€ and added that a neighbor 
  had lodged an informal complaint about Lancasterâ€™s property approximately four 
  months earlier.Â  The Board then viewed the inspectorâ€™s videotape of the debris 
  on Lancasterâ€™s property.Â  After agreeing with the inspector that Lancasterâ€™s 
  property was in clear violation of the Code, the Board unanimously voted to 
  deny Lancasterâ€™s motion for a variance.Â  
We find the circuit court was correct in affirming 
  the Board.Â  There was more than enough evidence presented at the Board hearing 
  to support the Boardâ€™s decision to deny the variance and hold Lancaster in violation 
  of the Code.Â  Further, other than presenting a brief to the Board, Lancaster 
  did not present any other evidence to support his motion for a variance.Â  As 
  the arguments in Lancasterâ€™s brief cannot be considered as evidence and Lancaster 
  did not appear at the hearing, Lancaster effectively did not present any evidence 
  to the Board.Â  
Similar to our review of zoning appeals, 
  we employ an abuse of discretion standard of review in the instant case.Â  See 
  Peterson Outdoor Adver. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 327 S.C. 230, 235, 489 
  S.E.2d 630, 633 (1997) (â€œ[T]he decision of the zoning board will not be upheld 
  where it is based on errors of law, . . .Â  or where there is no legal evidence 
  to support it, or where the board acts arbitrarily or unreasonably, . . . or 
  where, in general, the board has abused its discretion.â€) (citation omitted).Â  
  As such, we find (1) there is substantial evidence to support the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order dismissing Lancasterâ€™s appeal and (2) the Board neither acted arbitrarily 
  nor abused its discretion in denying Lancasterâ€™s motion for a variance.Â  Accordingly, 
  the circuit court did not err in dismissing Lancasterâ€™s appeal from the Boardâ€™s 
  ruling.
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order dismissing Lancasterâ€™s appeal is 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
George C. Greene, III and Molly F. Greene,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jack W. Griffith,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

and

  
    
      
The State of South Carolina,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-056
Heard December 12, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  29, 2004

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Desa A. Ballard, of W. Columbia and George H. McMaster, of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Deputy Attorney General 
  Treva G. Ashworth, Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., all 
  of Columbia andÂ  W. Foster Gaillard and Thomas L. Harper, Jr., both of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: This case involves the disputed 
  ownership of real property.Â  George C. Greene, III and Molly F. Greene sought 
  to prove they owned a disputed tract of land and that Jack W. Griffith had slandered 
  the title to their property by causing a plat to be recorded that showed Griffith 
  as the disputed tractâ€™s owner.Â  Griffith denied these allegations and brought 
  a third-party action against the State of South Carolina seeking to quiet title 
  to other, adjoining property.Â  The trial court ruled in favor of the Greenes 
  and the State, finding title to the disputed properties rested with the Greenes 
  and the State, respectively.Â  Griffith appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This action arose when Griffith claimed ownership of 
  a twelve-foot strip of land held by landowners George and Molly Greene.
In 1984, the Greenes purchased a lot known as 134 
  East Edgewater Park Drive in Charleston County by deed from Inez R. Bradham.Â  
  This deed describes the boundaries of the property by reference to a plat dated 
  February 6, 1984, that indicates the high water mark along Wappoo Creek serves 
  as the lotâ€™s eastern boundary.Â  The deed was properly recorded.Â  In 1985, the 
  Greenes built a home on the lot, where they have lived continuously since.Â  

Griffith claims to have acquired adjacent property 
  known as â€œMarsh Islandâ€ by deed in 1964. Â The Marsh Island deed references 
  a 1913 plat (McCrady Plat) that depicts the property as being surrounded on 
  all sides by creeks or bodies of water.Â  One of these creeks separates Marsh 
  Island at its western edge from the area that now comprises the Edgewater Park 
  Subdivision, where the Greenesâ€™ lot is located.
In 1997, Griffith commissioned Hagar E. Metts to 
  perform a survey ofÂ  the Marsh Island property.Â  Metts prepared a plat (Metts 
  Plat) that showed a strip of highland extending from the northeastern corner 
  of Marsh Island across the northern property line of the Greenesâ€™ lot, suggesting 
  that a narrow twelve-foot strip of land on the eastern edge of the Greenesâ€™ 
  lot was actually owned by Griffith.Â  The Metts Plat was recorded.
The Greenes learned of the Metts Plat when Griffithâ€™s 
  son offered to â€œtradeâ€ the disputed strip of land with the Greenes in exchange 
  for a grant of an access easement to Marsh Island over the Greenesâ€™ lot.Â  The 
  Greenes refused to accept the proposed trade and brought this action to quiet 
  title to the disputed portion of their lot or, alternatively, seeking a declaration 
  that they owned the disputed area by adverse possession. 
  [1] Â  They also sought damages for slander of title.Â  Griffith denied the 
  Greenesâ€™ allegations and asserted a counterclaim, seeking an easement by necessity 
  across the Greenesâ€™ property. 
The trial court determined the Greenes had title 
  to the disputed strip of land adjacent to Marsh Island.Â  Alternatively, it found 
  the Greenes had ownership of the disputed strip by virtue of adverse possession. 
  Â The court also found the Greenes were entitled to $55,676.62 in damages 
  for slander of title caused by Griffith.Â  Griffithâ€™s counterclaim for an easement 
  by necessity was denied.
Though this case was 
  originally an action to determine title between the Greenes and Griffith, the 
  trial court determined that all or a portion of the Marsh Island property might 
  be subject to a claim of title by the State. Consequently, the State was joined 
  as a party.
In Griffithâ€™s amended pleadings, he filed a third 
  party complaint in which he alleged he had superior title over the State to 
  the highlands on Marsh Island.Â  The State answered, denying Griffithâ€™s claim 
  of superior title.Â  The trial court found title to the highland portions of 
  the Marsh Island property rested solely with the State.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Concerning the dispute between the Greenes and 
  Griffith, the Greenesâ€™ complaint labels its first cause of action as one to 
  quiet title.Â  An action to quiet title is one in equity.Â  See Van 
  Every v. Chinquapin Hollow, Inc., 265 S.C. 474, 477, 219 S.E.2d 909, 910 
  (1975); Freeman v. Freeman, 323 S.C. 95, 98, 473 S.E.2d 467, 469 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  However, where, as here, one party asserts paramount title to the 
  disputed land to defeat the other partyâ€™s claims, it is an action at law.Â  Mountain 
  Lake Colony v. McJunkin, 308 S.C. 202, 204, 417 S.E.2d 578, 579 (1992); 
  see also Watson v. Suggs, 313 S.C. 291, 293, 437 S.E.2d 
  172, 173 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding that â€œ[a]n action brought for the primary 
  purpose of determining title to a disputed land is in the nature of a trespass 
  action to try title, which is an action at lawâ€).Â  
The Greenesâ€™ complaint also asserts causes of action 
  for slander of title and adverse possession â€“ both actions at law.Â  See 
  Miller v. Leaird, 307 S.C. 56, 61, 413 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1992) (noting 
  that an adverse possession claim is an action at law); Boehnlein v. Ansco, 
  Inc. 61 Or. App. 389, 393, 657 P.2d 702, 705 (1983) (holding that slander 
  of title is an action at law).Â  We also note the only damages sought or awarded 
  were under the slander of title claim.
We hold the action between Griffith and the Greenes 
  should be characterized as an action at law, and Griffith, through counsel, 
  so conceded at oral argument as to the slander of title claim.Â  As such, our 
  scope of review extends only to the correction of errors of law, and factual 
  findings of the trial court will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review 
  of the record discloses that there is no evidence that reasonably supports those 
  findings.Â  Crary v. Djbelli, 329 S.C. 385, 388, 496 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998) 
  (citing Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 
  221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976)).
We find Griffithâ€™s third party action 
  against the State concerning title to the highlands involves these partiesâ€™ 
  respective claims of paramount title.Â  The pleadings, having squarely placed 
  the issue of paramount title before the court, present a legal claim.Â  See 
  Van Every, 265 S.C. at 479, 219 S.E.2d at 911 (holding that where pleadings 
  present an issue regarding paramount title to land, the issue is a â€œpurely legal 
  issueâ€).Â  Our scope of review with respect to Griffithâ€™s third party action 
  against the State is, therefore, limited to the correction of legal errors and 
  determining if any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s factual findings. 
  [2] 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Slander of Title
Griffith first contends the trial 
  court erred in finding he slandered the title to Greeneâ€™s property.Â  We find 
  no error.
In South Carolina, slander of title has 
  been recognized as a common law cause of action.Â  See Huff v. Jennings, 
  319 S.C. 142, 148, 459 S.E.2d 886, 890 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that, although 
  the court was directly addressing a claim for slander of title for the first 
  time in South Carolina jurisprudence, â€œSouth Carolina law, through its incorporation 
  of the common law of England, recognizes a cause of action for slander of titleâ€).Â  
  To maintain a claim for slander of title, our courts have held â€œthe plaintiff 
  must establish (1) the publication (2) with malice (3) of a false statement 
  (4) that is derogatory to plaintiffâ€™s title and (5) causes special damages (6) 
  as a result of diminished value in the eyes of third parties.â€Â  Id. at 
  149, 459 S.E.2d at 891 (adopting the elements of slander of title outlined in 
  the Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 623A (1977)).
Here, Griffith contests the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling that he slandered the Greenesâ€™ title on the grounds that the Greenes 
  failed to establish Griffith acted with malice and that the Greenes failed to 
  prove they consequently suffered special damages.Â  We disagree.

A.Â Â Â Â Â  MaliceÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

We first find sufficient evidence to support the 
  trial courtâ€™s finding that Griffith acted with the requisite malice when he 
  recorded the Metts Plat.Â  This court held in Huff v. Jennings that â€œ[i]n 
  slander of title actions, the malice requirement may be satisfied by showing 
  the publication was made in reckless or wanton disregard of the rights of another, 
  or without legal justification.â€Â  Huff, 319 S.C. at 150, 459 S.E.2d at 
  891.
Sufficient evidence supports the finding that Griffith 
  acted in reckless or wanton disregard of the Greenesâ€™ rights to the disputed 
  strip and that he acted without legal justification.Â  Significantly, we note 
  Griffith admitted at trial that he owns no interest in the disputed strip of 
  land and that he never thought he held any interest in that land.Â  Despite this 
  admission, Griffith testified that he instructed Metts to prepare the plat and 
  stated, â€œI told [Metts] that the tax office said I owned [the strip of land 
  in question].â€Â  Metts testified that, when he prepared the plat, he had no evidence 
  that Griffith had any ownership interest in the disputed strip. 
Griffith counters that he did not record 
  the plat, and he did not have any knowledge of how the plat came to be recorded.Â  
  However, the record contains ample evidence supporting the trial courtâ€™s finding 
  to the contrary.Â  For example, Griffithâ€™s own testimony reveals that he had 
  the plat delivered to the Charleston County Planning Department, he had meetings 
  with the Planning Department that involved reference to the plat, and the plat 
  was returned to Griffith after it was recorded.Â  Notably, when asked at trial: 
  â€œDid you write a check to get that plat recorded?,â€ Griffith responded that 
  he â€œmight have.â€
 Without looking beyond Griffithâ€™s own 
  testimony, we find ample evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding he acted 
  with malice as defined under Huff.Â  Acknowledging he has never had any 
  legal claim to the disputed property, we find Griffith willfully ignored the 
  Greenesâ€™ rights in the property and had the plat prepared and recorded with 
  no legal justification.

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Special Damages

The trial court conducted a separate hearing to 
  determine the amount of damages the Greenes were entitled to receive under the 
  slander of title claim.Â  The court awarded as special damages $57,675.62 for 
  expenses incurred for attorney fees, expert fees and other litigation costs.Â  
  Huff, 319 S.C. at 151, 459 S.E.2d at 892 (stating that special damages 
  recoverable in a slander of title action include â€œthe expense of measures reasonably 
  necessary to counteract the publication [of slanderous statements of title], 
  including litigationâ€ (quoting 50 Am.Jur.2d Libel & Slander Â§ 560)).Â  
  Griffith challenges the propriety of awarding attorney fees and litigation expenses 
  in a slander of title action.Â  In response, the Greenes argue Griffith failed 
  to preserve this issue for appellate review.Â  We agree with the Greenes.
At trial, Griffith did not object to the 
  Greenesâ€™ entitlement to these litigation expenses.Â  Griffithâ€™s counsel merely 
  requested leave of court to â€œfile a brief â€¦ I just want to be able to review 
  the bills, and submit a brief if I do have a question of law concerning multiple 
  charges.â€Â  The trial court granted Griffithâ€™s request, observing, â€œI will leave 
  [the record] open for ten days to allow [Griffith] to file a memorandum on that.â€Â  
  Griffith filed no response and no Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion was filed challenging 
  the special damages in any respect.Â  Having failed to properly raise and preserve 
  this issue in the trial court, Griffith may not challenge the award of special 
  damages for the first time on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 
  330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue 
  cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to 
  and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â Â Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Adverse Possession
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Griffith next argues 
  the trial court erred in finding the Greenes held title to the disputed strip 
  by virtue of adverse possession.Â  However, by Griffithâ€™s own admission, he neither 
  claims nor holds any interest in the property.Â  Thus, no we find justiciable 
  controversy exists with respect to the adverse possession claim.Â  Accordingly, 
  we decline to address this issue.Â  See Mathis v. South Carolina State 
  Hwy. Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 714 (1973) (stating that 
  an appellate court will not â€œmake an adjudication where there remains no actual 
  controversyâ€).
III.Â Â Â  Title Dispute with the State
Griffithâ€™s dispute with the State involves the 
  highland portions of Marsh Island adjacent to the twelve-foot disputed strip 
  and lying to the east of the Greenesâ€™ property. 
  [3] Â  Griffith claims he holds title to all of the highland portions of 
  Marsh Island.Â  The State, however, asserts superior title to these highland 
  areas. [4]   

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Chain of Title

We first concur we the trial courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that Griffith does not own the portion of the marshlands in dispute, for the 
  contested portion is not part of Griffithâ€™s chain of title.Â  We further find 
  Griffith has abandoned this issue on appeal.Â  In his final brief, Griffith recites 
  in conclusory fashion under the section entitled â€œstatement of the caseâ€ that 
  in 1964 he acquired the property known as Marsh Island.Â  In the argument section 
  of the brief, Griffith merely finds fault with the trial courtâ€™s â€œlaborious 
  analysis of the chain of title of the Greenes and Griffith, none of which was 
  necessary â€¦ nor [is] any of the trial judgeâ€™s analysis regarding the chain of 
  title â€¦ relevant to Griffithâ€™s claim.â€Â  We find the detailed analysis of the 
  change of title not only relevant, but also dispositive of the issue before 
  us. Â The passing reference in Griffithâ€™s brief to the testimony of his expert, 
  with neither supporting authority nor argument, falls short of our issue preservation 
  rules.Â  See Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 
  439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating â€œan issue raised on appeal but 
  not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and will not be considered by the 
  appellate courtâ€);Â  Bell v. Bennett, 307 S.C. 286, 294, 414 S.E.2d 786, 
  791 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding that failure to argue issue in brief constitutes 
  abandonment of it); Toal, Vafai, & Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in 
  South CarolinaSearch Term End , 75-76 (S.C. Bar 2000) (stating â€œan issue 
  is deemed abandoned on appeal, and therefore, not presented for review, if it 
  is argued in a short, conclusory statement without supporting authorityâ€). [5] 
We find that the trial courtâ€™s chain of 
  title determination is, in any event, correct.Â  The land owned by the Greenes 
  and that portion of the disputed marshlands, known as Marsh Island, to the east 
  were originally part of a much larger tract of land known as Wappoo Hall Plantation.Â  
  Marsh Island is bounded on the north by Wappoo Creek, on the east by an unnamed 
  creek that separates it from Polly Island, on the south by Elliottâ€™s Cut and 
  on the west by an unnamed creek that separates it from Fickenâ€™s Island. [6] 
Wappoo Hall Plantation was conveyed to 
  John F. Ficken and Henry H. Ficken in 1898.Â  In 1902, the Fickens conveyed the 
  portion of the property on which Marsh Island is located to J. Martin Bottjer 
  (Bottjer Deed). [7] Â  When John F. Ficken purportedly conveyed this marshland to 
  Griffithâ€™s predecessor in title, Union Corporation, in 1913, Ficken no longer 
  had title to this marshland.Â  â€œA grantor of real property generally can transfer 
  no greater interest than he himself has in the property.â€Â  Von Elbrecht v. 
  Jacobs, 286 S.C. 240, 243, 332 S.E.2d 568, 570 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  We find 
  that these marshlands, therefore, are not properly included in Griffithâ€™s chain 
  of title.

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Entitlement to Land Accretion

Assuming Marsh Island is in Griffithâ€™s chain of 
  title, his claim for the highlands must nevertheless fail.
Resolution of a controversy as to ownership 
  of the wetlands in South Carolina and accompanying highlands must be examined 
  in light of special ownership rules.Â  In general, the State holds title to lands 
  lying between the mean high water mark and mean low water mark on tidal navigable 
  waterways.Â  Hobonny Club, Inc. v. McEachern Caning Co., 272 S.C. 392, 
  252 S.E.2d 133 (1979).Â  Lands, however, that form and surround our tidal estuaries 
  and marshlands are subject to constant change by the sometimes powerful ebb 
  and flow of the tidal waters.Â  Land that may lie below the high tide mark may 
  over time, after the gradual deposit of silt and other sediment, rise well above 
  the previous mark.Â  The converse is, of course, true because the tides may erode 
  highland property so that it eventually falls below the high tide mark.Â  Such 
  change may also occur artificially through the efforts of man, as wetland property 
  may be filled and no longer be affected by the tides.Â  Because of these changes, 
  it can be difficult to discern at any fixed point in time where the rights of 
  the State end and the rights of a contiguous, private landowner begin.Â  
Our courts further recognize certain legal 
  principles concerning accretions by alluvial or artificial action to riparian 
  or littoral lands.Â  Wetland areas that become dry land through the natural accumulation 
  of mud, sand and sediment generally do not remain in title to the State, for 
  â€œimperceptible additions to the shore from such deposits should follow title 
  to the shore itself.â€Â  Epps v. Freeman, 261 S.C. 375, 386, 200 S.E.2d 
  235, 241 (1973).Â  Significantly, however, where those accretions result from 
  the â€œexertions of man[,] â€¦ the principle that title to imperceptible additions 
  to the shore from such deposits should follow title to the shore itself has 
  no application.â€Â  Id.Â  The distinction resting on the source of the accretion 
  is premised on ownership of contiguous land to which the accretion can attach.Â  
  See Horry County v. Tilghman, 283 S.C. 475, 480, 322 S.E.2d 831, 
  834 (Ct. App. 1984) (stating â€œ[a]n ownerâ€™s right to accretion depends upon the 
  contiguity of his lands to navigable waters and it is indispensable that there 
  be an estate to which the accretion can attachâ€).Â  
Marsh Island derives its name from its 
  original state as marshland.Â  The McCrady Plat establishes that, as of 1913, 
  Marsh Island contained no highlands. [8] Â  Marsh Island, through the years, 
  did not remain an untouched piece of submerged property.Â  There is evidence 
  of man-made changes to the marshland.Â  For example, in approximately 1939, the 
  Intracoastal Waterwayâ€™s construction resulted in the filling of portions of 
  this area.Â  Even Griffithâ€™s expert, Hagar Metts, reluctantly acknowledged that 
  the area of these highlands â€œlooks likeâ€ fill.Â  Moreover, after he claims he 
  acquired title in 1964, Griffith had approximately one thousand loads of fill 
  dirt deposited.Â  To the extent highlands were created by Griffithâ€™s own efforts, 
  no ownership benefit may inure to him.Â  This necessarily follows from the settled 
  principle that accretions resulting from the â€œexertions of manâ€ preclude application 
  of the general rule that title follows the â€œshore itself.â€Â  Epps, 261 
  S.C. at 386, 200 S.E.2d at 241.Â  Pursuant to Horry County v. Tilghman:Â  

[I]f alluvion is formed artificially and not by [the upland 
  ownerâ€™s] direction, he should be entitled to its benefit. . . . [I]f a project 
  is undertaken by the State or any governmental agency in aid of navigation, 
  and it is essential that the State or agency thereof have the benefit of the 
  alluvion formed by the accretion in order to realize the goal undertaken by 
  the project, it must be held that the private rights yield to the interest of 
  the public. 

283 S.C. at 481, 322 S.E.2d at 834.
Griffith seizes upon the term â€œessentialâ€ 
  to argue that it was not essential for the State to â€œhave the benefit of the 
  alluvion formed by the accretionâ€ for which it may have been responsible.Â  For 
  two fundamental reasons, this argument does little to advance Griffithâ€™s claim 
  of title to the highlands.Â  First, Griffith overlooks the other sources, including 
  himself, responsible for the fill and the inability to ascertain the degree 
  to which the various contributing sources are responsible for the creation of 
  the highlands.Â  In light of his burden of proof, Griffith certainly cannot find 
  refuge in theÂ  inability to apportion responsibility for the artificial accretions 
  among the various contributors. Â Second, it is undisputed the State owns the 
  tidelands. [9] Â  In essence, Griffith 
  owns no contiguous land â€œto which the accretion can attach.â€Â  Tilghman, 
  283 S.C. at 480, 322 S.E.2d at 834.Â  While â€œtitle to imperceptible additions 
  â€¦ follow[s] the title to the shore itself[,]â€ Griffith has no â€œshoreâ€ to which 
  title can attach.Â  Epps, 261 S.C. at 386, 200 S.E.2d at 241.Â  
Accordingly, we find ample evidence in 
  the record to support the trial courtâ€™s determination that â€œit is doubtful that 
  Griffith has title to any of Marsh Island.â€Â  Our review of the record firmly 
  persuades us as well that Griffith failed to meet his burden of proof.Â  
CONCLUSION
We conclude that the 
  trial court correctly found Griffith liable for slandering the Greenesâ€™ title, 
  and we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s determination of title in favor 
  of the Greenes and the State, respectively.Â  The judgment of the trial court 
  is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Griffith also attempted to leverage the State with the 
    Metts Plat by seeking a deed from the State transferring to him its interest 
    in the property.Â  The State rejected Griffithâ€™s efforts.

 
   
    [2] Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Griffith contends on appeal that his action against the 
    State should be reviewed de novo as an appeal from a purely equitable 
    action.Â  While we disagree, our independent review of the record convinces 
    us of the correctness of the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Thus, a determination 
    of the appropriate standard of review is not critical to the outcome.

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The disputed tract is referenced in the record as â€œthe 
    lands shown on the [Metts Plat] located immediately to the east of the [d]isputed 
    [s]trip and immediately to the east of the Greenesâ€™ property.â€Â  The parties 
    have, for ease of reference, consistently referred to the property as Marsh 
    Island or the highlands.Â  We will do likewise.

 
   
    [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We reject Griffithâ€™s argument that the Stateâ€™s claim of 
    title was not before the trial court.Â  Because of Griffithâ€™s claim of superior 
    title to the highland portions of Marsh Island, the State was joined as a 
    party for the purpose of addressing and resolving Griffithâ€™s claim of paramount 
    title.Â  The Stateâ€™s pleading denies Griffithâ€™s claim of paramount title and 
    asserts that â€œit has prima facie fee simple title, in public trust, of all 
    lands now or formerly lying below the highwater mark of all tidal navigable 
    waters in the State, including the lands involved in this case which now lie 
    or formerly lay below the mean highwater mark.â€Â  The suggestion that the issue 
    of title was not before the trial court belies the record before us.Â  Indeed, 
    notwithstanding any purported deficiency in the Stateâ€™s pleadings, the competing 
    claims of title to the highlands were presented to the trial court.Â  â€œWhen 
    issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent 
    of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been 
    raised in the pleadings.â€Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  Finally, any error in affirmatively 
    finding in favor of the State would not inure to Griffithâ€™s benefit, for Griffith 
    in any event failed to prove his entitlement to the highlands in dispute.Â  
  

 
   
    [5]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We recognize â€œan appellant may not use the reply brief 
    as a vehicle to argue issuesÂ  not argued in the appellantâ€™sÂ  brief.â€Â  Appellate 
    Practice in South Carolina, at 75.Â  Nevertheless, we note Griffithâ€™s reply 
    brief makes no mention of the trial courtâ€™s chain of title determination, 
    although such issue is featured in the Respondentsâ€™ briefs.

 
   
    [6]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The eastern portion of Fickenâ€™s Island is now known as 
    the Edgewater Park subdivision.Â  The Greenesâ€™ lot is located in Edgewater 
    Park.

 
   
    [7]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Bottjer Deed transfers Fickens Island and its adjoining 
    marshes.Â  The accompanying plat clearly designates the adjacent marshes as 
    part of the conveyance.Â  The plat is recorded with the deed in the land records 
    office of Charleston County in Book X-23, P 663.Â  â€œWhere a deed describes 
    land as it is shown on a certain plat, such plat becomes part of the deed 
    for the purpose of showing the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of 
    the property conveyed.â€Â  Hobonny Club, Inc. v. McEachern Caning Co, 
    272 S.C. 392, 397, 252 S.E.2d 133, 136 (1979).

 
   
    [8]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  By contrast, the McCrady Plat depicts the nearby Polly 
    Island as containing a small area designated as highland.Â  

 
   
    [9]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  After acquiring a deed for Marsh Island in 1964, Griffith 
    had approximately one thousand loads of fill deposited.Â  The State filed suit 
    to enjoin the filling, asserting its claim to all of the wetlands areas of 
    Marsh Island.Â  The case progressed to the state supreme court, which held 
    the State had title to the â€œtidelands,â€ specifically the â€œland between the 
    lines of the ordinary high and low tides covered and uncovered by the daily 
    flow and ebb thereof.â€Â  State v. Griffith, 265 S.C. 43, 46, 216 S.E.2d 
    765, 766 (1975).
